2,"1","Welcome To Pop Galaxy","Bigger than the big bang -- and twice as destructive.","Welcome To Pop Galaxy!","Ignition!",,"

How did the universe begin? We have no idea. It happened very long time ago, though we heard it was a hell of an event. Big bang, huge party, the band was insane. Sorry you missed it...
However, you've arrived here just in time to witness the birth of an entirely NEW galaxy! Sounds rather lofty, doesn&rsquo
column3: s true. You can trust this as fact because you are reading it on the Internet.

column1:
What exactly is Pop Galaxy?
Think of it as a satellite&hellip
column2: orbiting a solar system of awesomeness.

column1: The largest planet in the system is WOWIO, a digital destination for eBooks, eComics and Graphic Novels featuring an incredible array of top publishers and over 100,000 titles for available to download for your iPad, Kindle, Nook&hellip
column2: or whatever futuristic device you choose.&nbsp
column3: The second planet in the system is the outpost Drunk Duck, an amazing webcomics community, featuring THOUSANDS of independently created comics and an entire community of enthusiastic creators and readers. And finally, is the newly discovered moon of WeVolt, a platform for creators, by creators.
s mission is to make contact with what lies beyond our star system, sharing the energy and excitement from our worlds with the pop cultural universe beyond.&nbsp

column1: 3,"0","Pop Icon: Grant Morrison","Talking With Gods","Grant Morrison","Influences",,"

I love Billy Corgan. The Smashing Pumpkins is one of my favorite bands of all time. From their first album ""Gish"" to the double punch of ""Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness."" Wait, that's not Billy Corgan?
column2:
Whoa. My bad. Is that Professor X?
Wait&hellip
column3:
that's Grant Morrison. Gotcha. And who is he again? (Suddenly a mysterious bullet from one angry comic book nerd splits my skull)

All kidding aside, Grant Morrison is the man. Just this week, he wraps one of the most memorable - and mind-bending runs any writer has had on Batman. Who else could get Bruce Wayne to drop a bomb this big on an unsuspecting Gotham City?

column1: And with the release of Patrick Meaney's documentary, ""Grant Morrison: Talking With Gods,"" you'll understand what a true visionary this legendary writer is... if you can understand what he's saying...

column1: I loved the movie ""Old School."" I loved ""The Hangover."" I love the ""Iron Man"" series. But a mash-up of the three wrapped up in a road trip movie? ""Due Date,"" starring Iron Man himself, Mr. Robert Downey Jr. and one of the funniest minds on the planet, Mr. Zach Galifianakis, is out in theaters today.

Road Trip. Polar opposites. Deadline. Gotta get home. Baby. Dog. Fart jokes. One or two scenes with Zach in stained underwear or jock strap. I'm a self centered asshole because I put my work before you, honey and our newborn child. I'm just the bearded asshole trying to give you a lift. But after a few fart and truck stop jokes, we start to work it out.
He makes to the hospital just in the nick of time to see his baby being born. The End.
And, if it doesn't flop horribly, we&rsquo
column2:
ll make a sequel.

Now, every movie studio loves the Internet to market a movie. Each movie now must have some sort of &ldquo
column5: s a bunch of video garbage you might find &ldquo
column8: s some really cool free wallpapers... or check out the latest cut of the movie trailer then play a flash game. Oh... remember to follow us on Facebook and Twitter.&nbsp

column1: The landing music is too loud... and everything you click through plays the stupid movie trailer again.
The flash animated video game was pretty cool. I guess?
And the ""Tremblay Yourself"" webcam photo booth thing was really confusing and super lame.
Brutal. I LOVE Zach Galifianakis, but this movie looks brutal.

Pop TV: The Cape on iPad
by Andy Dugan

The Cape is available right now, even though it doesn't premier until January 9.
column2: That's right, if you have an Apple iPad, you can download the pilot episode of NBC's new superhero drama series, THE CAPE.&nbsp
column3: This is a fun way to watch a new series, exclusive to iPad owners, and a sign of the times.&nbsp
column4: I learned of this from Mashable's Todd Wasserman, so click here to get more of his ""Exclusive"" scoop: http://mashable.com/2011/01/05/premiere-show-ipad/

column1: In the meantime, here is a promo for NBC's THE CAPE!

6,"0","Top Five Moustaches In Comic Book History","A Movember Special","","",,"

With the gallant mission of ""changing the face of men's health,"" the month of November has been taken over by the good people at ""Movember."" The rules are simple, start Movember 1st clean-shaven and then grow a moustache for the entire month. Think of the moustache as a manly version of the pink ribbon, raising awareness as well as important funds are raised for research to cure diseases such as prostate and testicular cancers.

As a symbol of true manliness, the moustache has a long and celebrated history in popular culture and comics and cartoons are no exception. Here now are the Top Five Moustaches in Comic Book History!

Dr. Strange

Marvel's master of the mystic arts has been balancing a somewhat questionable fashion statement of puffy, embroidered shirts and tights with a seriously bad ass 'stache. The cape doesn't hurt either&hellip

While Green Lantern's long-time nemesis never ceases to cause trouble for his emerald hued arch-enemy, he still manages to find the time to keep his upper lip groomed in a style that mixes a close-trimmed fade in the middle with fine, waxed tips. (While I would love adopt this style for myself as I grow my own 'mo this month, I've got to think it's next to impossible to pull this off in real life without looking like a total choad&hellip

Thor's good friends, Fandral, Hogun and Volstagg the Voluminous are not only Asgard's legendary The Warriors Three but also represent a triple threat of moustachery that cannot be equaled by mere mortals lest you hunger for the taste of death and yearn to end your days at the end of their wicked blade! (Yes, ladies - I speak perfect Asgardian hyperbole&hellip
column2:
but mostly to myself because it's so incredibly nerdy)

The Comedian

column1: The Watchmen's resident rapist is also the only member of the team to sport a moustache. Coincidence? Possibly. Either way, if you're going to rock a muscle shirt, with shoulder-pads and a smiley face - you'd best grow a moustache to show people you mean business. And carry some heavy weaponry as well&hellip

Now THIS is commitment to the cause! Yosemite Sam hasn't just grown a moustache, he's allowed the moustache to consume him. And while we credit him with having the courage to be so bold with his choice of facial accessory, we have to wonder why he's let the eyebrows get so out of hand&hellip

The dynamic duo of Snidely Whiplash of ""Bullwinkle"" fame and Dick Dastardly of ""The Wacky Races.""
Pencil thin, waxed to perfection and PERFECT for twisting as you hatch your next evil plot. Mwah-ha-ha-ha!

If you'd like to join the cause, it's not too late to get started on your own manly 'mo.
Learn more here
column2:
or consider making a donation here.

","

Pop Film: Lena Headey as Ma-Ma
by Andy Dugan

I've been a Lena Headey fan since seeing her in the movie ""Gossip,"" but she's definitely more awesome now! She has been cast as Judge Dredd's archrival Ma-Ma in the new ""Judge Dredd"" film, joining Karl Urban and Olivia Thirlby.

I personally miss seeing her on a weekly basis, like when she was in the TV show ""Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles."" She's so far proven to be pretty bad-ass, both in the TV show and ""300."" Let's hope she continues the streak, and brings something cool to this new ""Dredd"" film.
And on the Judge Dredd note, this is for you guys who loved Stallone is his ""amazing"" performance.

","

52,"0","Pop Music: Cake?!","Pop Music: Cake?!","","",,"

Pop Music: Cake?!
by Andy Dugan

This week I've discovered that a new album from the band CAKE is coming out. Yeah, Cake, that band that was on all the alternative radio stations back in the 90's with their hit song ""The Distance."" I guess I've not kept up with them over the years that have passed since going the distance, but I've checked out their new music video, and given a few of their new tracks a listen, and I've come to the conclusion that I am now a Cake fan again. Give their video ""Sick of You"" a view:

I find it very amusing that this new video takes place at an empty car dealership, but what's even more amusing is their web site, and how it is still stuck in the 90's with it's layout. Give it a view here: http://www.cakemusic.com

Buy Cake's new album: ""Showroom of Compassion,"" maybe with enough sales they will hire a new web designer.

","

53,"0","Pop Games: DC Universe Online","Pop Games: DC Universe Online","","",,"

Pop Games: DC Universe Online
by Andy Dugan

DC Universe Online is now officially on sale and live, so who are you going to be suiting up as? I've always been a Batman fan myself, but in the trailer you see below, Superman is looking pretty awesome.

If you are thinking of playing this game today on your PS3, I hope you have set up the download and install already, because depending on your bandwidth, this thing is going to take some time to get going. First you will have to download the 130MB PS3 patch, then install the 11GB worth of Universe, and then there will be another 2GB download before you start crushing the Joker's face in. Regardless, it looks like it will be worth the wait.

This game has cost $50M to produce, and looks like one of the most explosive and thought out games to hit the online universe ever. Warner Bros, DC, and Sony have high hopes for this online experience, and believe they can take on the World of Warcraft numbers. I have yet to dive into this Universe, so my enthusiasm is purely based on being a big fan of DC and hoping that this game lives up to the hype! I highly doubt the powers that be will ruin this one, but I did see The Green Lantern trailer, so I'm not saying they aren't capable of failure.
So yeah... here is that Green Lantern trailer:

","

54,"0","Pop Film: 007","Pop Film: 007","","",,"

Pop Film: 007
by Andy Dugan

When I first heard of James Bond being put on hiatus because of MGM's bankruptcy, I was crushed. I have really enjoyed Daniel Craig's two Bond films. Today, MGM has announced they are no longer in bankruptcy, and they have given us a date to see Bond back in action! November 9, 2012! Sure, this is a long time away, but having to play the new Goldeneye on Wii and Bloodstone on PS3 has been really painful thinking that it was Craig's last time as Bond. I am thrilled I can get back to those games and enjoy them, knowing there is a future 007 film on the way.
Check out the game trailers below, and even better, my favorite Bond Girl Olga Kurylenko!

","

Pop Film: Naomi Watts in Dark Knight Rises?
by Andy Dugan

It may just be a rumor, but word on the street is that Naomi Watts is being considered for Vicki Vale in ""The Dark Knight Rises,"" and on top of that, Eva Green could have a turn as Talia al Ghul.
I would be more than happy to see both of these women in the next Batman film! Let's hope it's true, but if not, here is Kim Basinger to heal the wounds.

If you need to learn more, I got my info here: http://www.thewrap.com/deal-central/column-post/are-naomi-watts-eva-green-mix-dark-knight-rises-23825

You guys know about the Weekly Rumble over on Wevolt.com don't you?
column3: How in the hell do you not know about the Weekly Rumble?&nbsp
column4: And you call yourself a nerd too? Ok.&nbsp
column5: Maybe I pulled out my nerd cred  whooping' stick a little too prematurely.&nbsp

column2: If you don't know what Wevolt's Weekly Rumble is? Well, with Zuda folding up shop, many webcomic creators and enthusiasts hung their heads low. Had all the opportunities for the little guys and indie lovers dried up, died, and been blown away in the wind? Absolutely not!

s Weekly Rumble. A straight forward contest wecomic creators. Upload your comic to WEvolt.com, get the most Facebook likes, win $100 for the week. On top of that, the CREATORS keep all rights to their work.

column1: The weekly winners for each bracket (there are 3 brackets at 3 weeks long) go head-to-head for the big prize, $500. Done and done. Check out this recap of weeks 1-3, so you can jump right in and keep up with the action.
Week 1 kicked off with 18 competitors, a few were already WEvolt heavy lifters like James Riot&rsquo
column3: s ""Phinmagic,"" but quite a few new guys came in and hit the ground running. Newcomer Scotty Richard&rsquo
column4: s ""Blaed Race"" took an early lead quickly followed by IsenMike&rsquo
column5: s ""The First Law of Mad Science.""

column1: In the end week 1 was SWEPT by James Mascia&rsquo
column2: s ""High School Heroes,"" followed by ""The Path"" and ""The First Law of Mad Science.""

column1: Week 2 saw new competitor, ""Acting Out Comics,"" enter the ring. Week 2 ran through much like Week 1 had, with a few of the new comics taking an early lead, holding their own with WeVolt veterans throughout the week. Despite an intense back and forth race throughout the week, Week 2 was won by ""High School Heroes,"" followed again by ""The Path"" and WEvolt veteran D.R. Croston&rsquo

column2: Week 3 is underway and everyone is watching closely.

column1: Voting closes Friday at midnight PST and we all anxiously await to see if there is an upset in the dynasty set up by High School Heroes. Or after 2 weeks of
column2: near wins if The Path rises up to take Week 3 for it&rsquo
s all up to YOU, head over to WEvolt.com, read some great comics and &ldquo
column4: your favs. Tune back Monday to see the winners announced.

Ok. I'll admit it. I loved the first Tron movie, and I'm kind of excited for the reboot ""Tron Legacy"" that hits theaters next month. What I'm not psyched about is the studio is full force on the movie marketing. From crappy toys to video games, Disney is JAMMIN' ""Tron"" down our throats.
After playing ""Tron: Evolution"" at this year's E3, I thought it was pretty solid, so I hope it doesn't SUCK because video games that come out before the movie is released... tend to SUCK!
Check out these Pop Galaxy Games Exclusives. Behind the scenes of the making of ""Tron: Evolution!""
And some classic ""Tron"" goodness for good measure!

""Tron: Evolution"" hits stores December 7, 2010!

59,"0","Pop Weekend: Golden TV!","Golden Globes, what else is on TV?","","",,"

Pop Weekend: Golden TV!
by Andy Dugan

It's Golden Globes weekend, and I've got my party plans, but will I actually watch the show, or something else? ...and the nominees are: The Golden Globes, Californication, Big Love, Iron Man, and Transformers.
Let's start with The Golden Globes, and check out the ""actual"" nominees.

Wow, that was pretty boring. However, there were some pretty good selections this year, including ""Inception"" and ""The Social Network."" I think it's time to check out the trailer from ""Inception"" since we all know it's not really going to win.

I personally wasn't a huge fan of ""Inception,"" I thought ""The Social Network"" was much better. Anyway, the Golden Globes will be airing this weekend, so if you feel inclined to watch people get awards, check out NBC around 8pm.

I will be watching Showtime and enjoying the crazy life of Hank Moody on ""Californication."" I'm a big fan of most shows on Showtime, but Californication is only bested by ""Dexter"" in my opinion. Here is a clip for this week's episode, Suicide Solution:

17,"0","Pop Games: Undead Nightmare","Pop Games: Undead Nightmare","","",,"

Strap on your six shooters and prepare to battle the undead, because out today on the PS3 is Red Dead Redemption's ""Undead Nightmare."" Are you psyched? Or sick and tired of f-in' Zombies?

column1:
56,"0","Pop Film: ""The Green Hornet""","Instant Review","Pop Film","Instant Review",,"

""The Green Hornet""
by Matt West

Does the idea of a wisecracking Seth Rogen disguised as an underworld heavyweight in a domino mask strike fear in your heart? If you had high hopes for the big-screen adaptation of ""The Green Hornet"" it should... but not in a good way. It's a hornet's nest of bad ideas... in eye-popping 3D!

Full disclosure: ""The Green Hornet"" has NOT been on my list of films to see in theatres since it was announced a few years back. In fact, if it wasn't for being presented with the opportunity to check out an advance screening in Los Angeles this week, I might never have seen the film at all...

The very idea of Seth Rogen taking a turn as a big-screen comic book hero was laughable when it was announced. The addition of visionary director Michel Gondry certainly lent some intrigue to the project, but early reports about troubles with the film's production, the game-time decision to present it in 3D -- and that nagging Seth Rogen issue has kept me from taking ""The Green Hornet"" too seriously.

It would appear that neither the star, who also served as ""The Green Hornet's"" writer and Executive Producer, nor the director took the project seriously leaving the audience with a movie that doesn't seem to know what it wants to be. Is it a comic book movie? Is it a parody of comic book movies? Is it an homage to the short-lived, campy 1960's television series? The answer seems to be ""D,"" all of the above. The trouble is, ""The Green Hornet"" never rises to the level of what the movie ASPIRES to be.

The new film stays close to the hero's origin story first made famous on radio in the 1930's: Newspaper publisher by day, Britt Reid (Rogen), disguises himself as the masked vigilante ""Green Hornet,"" by night. He is accompanied on his adventures in the underworld by his sidekick, martial arts expert Kato, (Jay Chou) who drives their technologically advanced car: ""The Black Beauty"".

Following the untimely death of Reid's father, newspaper publisher James Reid (Tom Wilkinson), Britt and Kato make their debut as drunken vandals turned accidental crime-stoppers. This not-so-dynamic duo is quickly painted as a new breed of criminal in the Los Angeles media, thanks in part of Reid's influence as the newly installed publisher of the city's Daily Sentinel Newspaper.

Posing as criminals, The Green Hornet and Kato work their way through the Los Angeles underworld, taking out various drug dealers and thugs, ultimately attracting the attention of the city's crime-boss, Chudnofsky (Christoph Waltz). The pair manages to stay one-step ahead of both the police and Chudnofsky's gang aided by Daily Sentinel secretary Lenore Case, (Cameron Diaz) and a fleet of bad-ass super-cars.

The story's seemingly simple premise ends up being unnecessarily complicated thanks to a script that tries too hard to balance being a clever crime story with being a comedy that ends up feeling campy. Forget about plot development: we have montages and car-chases in 3D! Hollywood's latest gimmick falls unbelievably flat in some sequences, reducing many shots to a shaky, blurry mess that is unintentionally, simply bad. And while some of the fight sequences featuring Jay Chou's ""Kato"" are enhanced by the treatment, they are not enough to distract the audience from the fact that the movie is too long, the plot too convoluted and the relationship between Rogen and Kato too forced.

As co-writer on the project, Seth Rogen turns in a script with dialogue so perfectly written for Seth Rogen, the notion that he's supposed to be playing a character is lost in his rapid-fire, stream-of-consciousness stoner delivery. Add Jay Chou's sometimes hard to decipher accent and it's Rogen who ends up carrying nearly every scene... badly. By the end, the ""Green Hornet's"" plot becomes so convoluted, that it's up to an elaborately choreographed, effects laden Michel Gondry montage narrated by both Rogen AND his dead father to explain it away.

With visual nods to the 1960's series, including an end-credit sequence inexplicably added before the end of the film, as well as musical references to the original radio series ""The Green Hornet"" pays great respect to the source material, but ends up disgracing it by adding this loud, messy mash-up to its nearly 50 year legacy.

According to this interview from our friends at Buzzine.com, Rogen and Gondry tried to toe the line between making a comic book movie and making a commentary about comic book movies. Is the movie about ""The Green Hornet,"" is it about ""Kato,"" or is it about the ""Black Beauty?"" Unfortunately, the audience isn't given a clear answer and instead is given a movie that doesn't know what it wants to be and ultimately ends up being bad.

column5:

30,"0","Pop Comics: 99 cent Comics Extravaganza!","Pop Comics: 99 cent Comics Extravaganza!","","",,"

It's Wednesday and we here at Pop Galaxy are jonesing for two things: comics and deals. Luckily, we've got the best fix for our pulp addiction&hellip
column2: it's WOWIO's 99 cent comics promotion. That's right, 20 kick-a$$ titles all for the price of a beefy five-layer burrito at Taco Bell!

column4: src=""http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5248/5242738032_b52f59e48f.jpg"" alt=""driver-for-the-dead-comic-1"" width=""322"" height=""500"" />First up, ""Driver For the Dead.""

column1: Radical introduces a new supernatural horror set in the heart of Louisiana, from John Heffernan and illustrator Leonardo Manco (Hellblazer). Alabaster Graves is a driver for the dead. As a veteran of funeral homes, mortuaries, and coroners&rsquo
column2: offices across the Deep South, Graves chauffeurs hundreds of bodies to their final resting places. But now, Alabaster must cover the distance from Shreveport to New Orleans to retrieve the remains of Mose Freeman, renown voodoo priest, with Freeman&rsquo
column3: s sultry granddaughter riding shotgun. What he doesn't know is that he's being pursued by a resurrectionist named Fallow &ndash
column4: a necromancer who gets his power from stealing body parts...and for whom the corpse of Mose Freeman would be the ultimate prize.
src=""http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5164/5242738052_8d9cb83c77.jpg"" alt=""massive_awesome1"" width=""330"" height=""495"" />Our next pick, is Massive Awesome!

column1: From Stephen Lindsay, the creator of ""Jesus Hates Zombies"" and ""Lincoln Hates Werewolves,"" comes ""Massive Awesome""! - the story of best friends, Commando Bacon and Zombie Pickle, as they try to unravel the mystery of who is attempting to destroy their lives. Ninjas, Giant Robots, Shadowy Government Figures, Scottish Luchadors and insatiable appetites for DESTRUCTION are but a few things standing in their way! Featuring an all new, never before seen FULL COLOR one shot of ""Jesus Hates Zombies.""

column4: src=""http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5284/5242738096_6481b6cb52.jpg"" alt=""pagecover"" width=""323"" height=""500"" />And don't forget, just in time for the holiday season, Adventures of Chrissie Claus.

It's Wednesday and we here at Pop Galaxy are jonesing for two things: comics and deals. Luckily, we've got the best fix for our pulp addiction&hellip
column2: it's WOWIO's 99 cent comics promotion. That's right, 20 kick-a$$ titles all for the price of a beefy five-layer burrito at Taco Bell!

column4: src=""http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5248/5242738032_b52f59e48f.jpg"" alt=""driver-for-the-dead-comic-1"" width=""322"" height=""500"" />First up, ""Driver For the Dead.""

column1: Radical introduces a new supernatural horror set in the heart of Louisiana, from John Heffernan and illustrator Leonardo Manco (Hellblazer). Alabaster Graves is a driver for the dead. As a veteran of funeral homes, mortuaries, and coroners&rsquo
column2: offices across the Deep South, Graves chauffeurs hundreds of bodies to their final resting places. But now, Alabaster must cover the distance from Shreveport to New Orleans to retrieve the remains of Mose Freeman, renown voodoo priest, with Freeman&rsquo
column3: s sultry granddaughter riding shotgun. What he doesn't know is that he's being pursued by a resurrectionist named Fallow &ndash
column4: a necromancer who gets his power from stealing body parts...and for whom the corpse of Mose Freeman would be the ultimate prize.
src=""http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5164/5242738052_8d9cb83c77.jpg"" alt=""massive_awesome1"" width=""330"" height=""495"" />Our next pick, is Massive Awesome!

column1: From Stephen Lindsay, the creator of ""Jesus Hates Zombies"" and ""Lincoln Hates Werewolves,"" comes ""Massive Awesome""! - the story of best friends, Commando Bacon and Zombie Pickle, as they try to unravel the mystery of who is attempting to destroy their lives. Ninjas, Giant Robots, Shadowy Government Figures, Scottish Luchadors and insatiable appetites for DESTRUCTION are but a few things standing in their way! Featuring an all new, never before seen FULL COLOR one shot of ""Jesus Hates Zombies.""

26,"0","Pop Reads: WOWIO’S Book of the Month - Sudan","Pop Reads: WOWIO’S Book of the Month - Sudan","","",,"

December is here and we&rsquo
column2: re excited to ring in the holiday season with our latest FREE eBook, Sudan, part of WOWIO&rsquo
column3: s Book of the Month series. This month, we have teamed up with Kingstone Media Group and authors Art Ayris and Ninie Hammon to offer you this captivating and inspiring read.

column1: This novel delves into the modern-day slave trade of Sudan, and follows a father&rsquo
column2: s heroic, against-all-odds effort to rescue his daughter after a vicious raid on his village by Janjaweed guerrillas. Sudan is an eye-opening story that tells a suspenseful storyline to shed light on the growing humanitarian crisis on the African continent. &nbsp
column4: This WOWIO special edition eBook features bonus footage, including an interview with one of the authors, Art Ayris, and a book trailer expanding on the novel.

Ok. Here it is.
column2: Out today in theaters is the highly anticipated  sequel to one of my favorite movies growning up.&nbsp
column3: Tron: Legacy, the  second installment to the Tron series.&nbsp
column5: but I sure  hope it doesn't suck.&nbsp

column1: So, back in 1982, when I was a wided eye boy not jaded by the world and all the stupid people in it, I loved the movie Tron.
It looked amazing and I loved the story. I can honestly say that this movie pushed me into a career in video game content creation.
column2: So my expectation for Tron: Legacy has some big shoes to fill.
God bless almost twenty years of digital and movie making development.&nbsp
column4: make sure you check out this amazing comedic parody series by Tron Reboot:

34,"0","Pop Games: Tron: Evolution","Pop Games: Tron: Evolution","","",,"

Out last week was Tron: Evolution, the video game companion of the highly anticipated Tron: Legacy. Does the game do the movie justice or is it worst than Enter the Matrix, that disgusting pile of bile that sank the Matrix franchise?
First up, let's compare Tron: Evolution and the original Tron arcade game that was produced by Bally Midway in 1982.

Wow. It's amazing to see what 19 years of video game development looks like. What I kind of dig about Tron: Evolution is the use of the actual movie actors as VO talent for the video game, and the fact Disney had Daft Punk score the movie and the game is pretty cool.
While the game looks visually awesome, the actual game play is a little wonky. Pop Galaxy gives Tron: Evolution a 84% our of 100.
And finally... PLEASE check out our amazing Fandango cross promotion with the highly anticpated Gulliver's Travel out in theaters Xmas day.
column2:
Buy your tix at the 'dango.... and you get a free digital book download! Can't beat that!

","

36,"0","Pop Comics: 99 cent Comics!","Pop Comics: 99 cent Comics!","","",,"

It's Wednesday and we here at Pop Galaxy are jonesing for two things: comics and deals. Luckily, we've got the best fix for our pulp addiction&hellip
column2: it's WOWIO's 99 cent comics promotion. That's right, 20 kick-a$$ titles all for the price of anything on the Carl's Jr. value menu.

column1: First up, ""Breakneck"" by Mark Bertolini, James Boulton, Matt Brown.

Ethan Shade was one of the most inept, third-string supervillains on Earth. But now he may be the last supervillain on Earth. During a month long war, the world's superheroes banded together and wiped out the villains with the exception of Shade, who quickly went into hiding, fearing for his life. But he soon realized that no one was looking for him. No one was hunting him. No one seemed to know he even existed, and Shade was more than happy to let that continue. He planned to take down one last bank, pick up a major score, and then leave the country. But the robbery doesn't quite go as planned, and at the end, Shade had accidentally murdered a popular local superhero, and goes on the run, the target of the world&rsquo
Next is, ""Brian and Bobbi"" by Adam Wilson

column5: Bobbi is a story for those who feel ignored on a daily basis. Brian has gone completely unnoticed all his life, despite being born with amazing superpowers. Bobbi is the illegitimate daughter of a superhero who can't seem to convince anyone she's just a regular kid. By chance, the two meet and what results is a coming-of-age tale set upon a larger than life superhero backdrop. It's a graphic novel where the super villains, the powers, and the incredible fight scenes are really just the catalyst to tell the much deeper story of two people who couldn't be any more different -- or any more alike.

column1: And finally, don't forget to grab for 99 cents&hellip
""Comic Book Comics 04"" - Fred Van Lente (Writer), Ryan Dunlavey

column4: src=""http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5285/5255286116_4a12caa1ab.jpg"" alt=""comic book comics"" width=""350"" height=""500"" />Our fantastic fourth issue! Featuring: Stan Lee! Steve Ditko! R. Crumb! Hergé
column5: ! Together for the first time in one mighty magazine! (A special Evil Twin Not-Prize for everyone who gets that reference...) The incredible saga of the comic book industry continues, as Fred &amp
column6: Ryan tackle the rise of Marvel Comics, the underground comix revolution, and the story behind ""Tintin""!

column1: Remember... PLEASE check out our amazing Fandango cross promotion with the highly anticpated Gulliver's Travel out in theaters Xmas day.
column2:

It's Wednesday and we here at Pop Galaxy are jonesing for two things: comics and deals. Luckily, we've got the best fix for our pulp addiction&hellip
column3: it's WOWIO's 99 cent comics promotion. That's right, 20 kick-a$$ titles all for the price of anything on the Carl's Jr. value menu.

column1: First up, ""Breakneck"" by Mark Bertolini, James Boulton, Matt Brown.

Ethan Shade was one of the most inept, third-string supervillains on Earth. But now he may be the last supervillain on Earth. During a month long war, the world's superheroes banded together and wiped out the villains with the exception of Shade, who quickly went into hiding, fearing for his life. But he soon realized that no one was looking for him. No one was hunting him. No one seemed to know he even existed, and Shade was more than happy to let that continue. He planned to take down one last bank, pick up a major score, and then leave the country. But the robbery doesn't quite go as planned, and at the end, Shade had accidentally murdered a popular local superhero, and goes on the run, the target of the world&rsquo
Next is, ""Brian and Bobbi"" by Adam Wilson

column5: Bobbi is a story for those who feel ignored on a daily basis. Brian has gone completely unnoticed all his life, despite being born with amazing superpowers. Bobbi is the illegitimate daughter of a superhero who can't seem to convince anyone she's just a regular kid. By chance, the two meet and what results is a coming-of-age tale set upon a larger than life superhero backdrop. It's a graphic novel where the super villains, the powers, and the incredible fight scenes are really just the catalyst to tell the much deeper story of two people who couldn't be any more different -- or any more alike.

column1: And finally, don't forget to grab for 99 cents&hellip
""Comic Book Comics 04"" - Fred Van Lente (Writer), Ryan Dunlavey

column4: src=""http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5285/5255286116_4a12caa1ab.jpg"" alt=""comic book comics"" width=""350"" height=""500"" />Our fantastic fourth issue! Featuring: Stan Lee! Steve Ditko! R. Crumb! Hergé
column5: ! Together for the first time in one mighty magazine! (A special Evil Twin Not-Prize for everyone who gets that reference...) The incredible saga of the comic book industry continues, as Fred &amp
column6: Ryan tackle the rise of Marvel Comics, the underground comix revolution, and the story behind ""Tintin""!

Out on consoles tomorrow, just in time to feed the Sarlacc pit knowns as ""Christmas,"" is Battlefield Bad Company 2 Vietnam.
column2: Probably not the gift for your crazy Ol' Uncle Ronnie who served in Nam and still has his ""episodes.""

column1:
GET READY FOR A WHOLE NEW WAR
Skimming the treetops in your helicopter, Wagner's ""Ride of the Valkyries"" blasts through its loudspeakers. Down in the jungles and rice fields below, the enemy is waiting for a chance to take you down with their T54 tanks and RPG launchers. Battlefield: Bad Company&trade
column2: 2 just made the journey to a new place and time -- back to the 60's and the infamous Vietnam War.

column1: At the heart of this expansion lie four distinct, brand-new multiplayer maps based on the Vietnam War. Each map brings a new gameplay experience and fresh visuals, with characteristics such as foxholes, tunnels and dense jungles from where the enemy can launch surprise attacks. Also, 15 classic Vietnam-era weapons and 6 vehicles are available from the moment you go online.
Do you smell that? I love the smell of Napalm in the morning.
Remember... PLEASE check out our amazing Fandango cross promotion with the highly anticpated Gulliver's Travel out in theaters Xmas day.

Wonder Woman Make-Up!
by Andy Dugan

Have you ever wanted to be as beautiful as Wonder Woman? Sure you have! ...and now you can, thanks to MAC Cosmetics! DC Comics' beautiful heroine has invited Mac Cosmetics into the Justice League with their Spring 2011 makeup collection inspired by Wonder Woman's blue, red and gold.
Don't believe it? Well, check out items below, and then get to your local MAC store so you can paint your face like Wonder Woman!
Lipglass comes in four cool shades that give lips a glassy finish that is vibrantly sassy. Lipsticks in four dazzling shades that add glam to one&rsquo
column2: s look. Mineralize skinfinish in two eye-catching hues i.e. pink power and golden lariat. Nail Lacquer in two glamorous shades for an amazing look. True red and Navy blue colors are bold and daring.

column1: Opulash mascara in purple, green, blue and black shades that will make your lashes more beautiful. So, get ready to enhance your eyelashes in different ways for many killer looks. Penultimate eye liner in true black that will direct all the attention to your eyes.

Pigments are available in two shimmering shades that are sure to last a long time. Powder blush, reflects glitter and utility belt eye brush set, invicible mirror and Wonder Woman makeup bag are also worth buying.
MAC Wonder Woman Collection includes really great shades for coming Spring with strong and powerful looking packaging. The collection goes well with theme and products are also bright and colorful.
MAC Wonder Woman collection for Spring 2011 will release in February 10th in the U.S. and March 2011 everywhere else.

60,"0","Pop Music: Meaning & Rhetoric","The Sonic Explorations of Jose Medeles","","",,"

Pop Music: Meaning &
column2:
Rhetoric
by Andy Dugan

""The Story: As drummer Jose Medeles set out to develop a solo improvisational performance, he enlisted director Kiino Villand to carry his vision from concept to visual fruition. More than merely a demonstration of innovative skills, Meaning and Rhetoric evolved into a full blown documentary exploring the thought process behind the brilliantly dynamic musicianship of a world class drummer.""

column1: I watched this documentary on drummer Jose Medeles of ""The Breeders"" and was quite intrigued! It has a visual style unlike other documentaries, and keeps a pace that doesn't lead to boredom. Jose has a very unique style, and makes sounds out of pretty much anything he can get his hands on. He's a truly talented guy, and it comes through without effort on screen.

I am very impressed with the storytelling of director Kiino Villand, who has a long history of published photography in magazines and books worldwide. In ""Meaning and Rhetoric"" he chooses a very creative shotlist to show Jose in action, and the locations he chose to shoot at are also very unique. I've seen some of his music video work as well, and he has a style that reminds me a bit of Michel Gondry, well, that is prior to Gondry's work on ""The Green Hornet.""
I asked Kiino what inspired him to do this piece, and this was his response:
<div>""I was inspired by the excellence of Frontline Reports. They make  the most compelling documentaries in my opinion. Of course Meaning &amp
column2: Rhetoric is about a musician, so it's not as hard hitting as Frontline.  But it was important for me to examine what makes Jose tick and explore  his story thoroughly. One portion of the DVD is strictly his solo  abstract drum performance. So any avid musician or die-hard fan will be  blown away. The most special part about it is  the response I've been getting. Kim Deal, Jose's bandmate in The  Breeders and bass player in The Pixies, came to a screening we had with  her twin sister Kelley and they loved it! Completely floored. That was  cool.""

column1: This documetary would be a great piece for your library if you are a drummer or musician who likes to learn from others in your field. It is also great for non-musicians who have a fascination with sounds and creativity.
You can get a copy of ""Meaning and Rhetoric: The Sonic Explorations of Jose Medeles"" here: http://www.lensactionproductions.com/Lens/Meaning.html

column4: s some awesome (and awesomely bad)  Christmas themed television.&nbsp
column6: ve scoped the usual Christmas fodder,  but this year has brought me a rare gem. The ultimate Sci-Fi Christmas  crossover if you will. &nbsp

column1: Dr. Who does A Christmas Carol. Yeah you heard me right, Dr. Who and Dickens!
column2: On Christmas Day BBC One will treat the UK to A Christmas Carol done Dr. Who style. I could easily go on about my Dr. Who geekery. My terrible habit that when a new Doctor steps up I have to immediately hate them.
column3: That it took a thirty minute speech, from a girl dressed as Ole&rsquo
column4: Greg might I add, for me to give Eccleston a second chance. Check your local listings for re-broadcast times!

column2: m drawing out is this is my first time seeing Matt Smith in action as the Doctor. I think he&rsquo
column4: m excited to see more. Mostly I&rsquo
column5: m intrigued by the genius of such a classic Sci-Fi franchise taking a crack at a literary classic! Until then, grab your 12 foot long scarf, some jelly babies, and enjoy the trailer.

column2: s better than a stocking full of tribbles!

column1: Let's tease this story just a little bit with some eye candy:

Darkchylde is the hit series about a cursed southern teen who can become any of the creatures from her many recurring nightmares. Haunted by horrible, yet strangely familiar dreams, and forced by her unsympathetic father to move yet again to a new town, beautiful but shy Ariel Chylde hoped to find in Salem, GA what had eluded her elsewhere.

48,"0","Pop Music: PixiesMusic.com","Pop Music: PixiesMusic.com","","",,"

One of my favorite bands of all time are the Pixies. Birthed in Boston in 1986, the band consists of Frank Black, Kim Deal, Joey Santiago, and Dave Lovering. The Pixies is the quintessential punk/indie rock band that was the forebear of the alternative rock boom in the 90's. After breaking up, then reuniting in 2004, the Pixies have finally put together a landing page site with tons of videos, amazing live sets, and band interviews to let their fans know that they ""La La Love You!""

column4: src=""http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5208/5299857063_9780eef571.jpg"" alt=""Screen shot 2010-12-28 at 7.05.50 AM"" width=""500"" height=""287"" />

column1: There are tons of LIVE shows both for free and for sale, interviews, reviews, fan art/recordings, and other nuggets of Pixies awesomeness.
What's great about this site, is the push by the band to have the fans upload any footage that they have secretly recorded from shows all over the world.

column4: src=""http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5124/5300453356_6c6a44a339.jpg"" alt=""Screen shot 2010-12-28 at 7.19.45 AM"" width=""500"" height=""304"" />

column1: Amazing, right? The Pixies. Enough said.

63,"0","Pop Games: Mass Effect 2 on PS3","Pop Games: Mass Effect 2 on PS3","","",,"

Pop Games: Mass Effect 2 on PS3
by Andy Dugan

2010's Game of the Year for XBox 360 is now available for PS3 owners... and with better graphics and 6 more hours of bonus content!

Developed by Bioware and published by Electronic Arts, ""Mass Effect 2"" is the highly anticipated sequel of the award-winning game ""Mass Effect."" The PS3 version allows players to download an interactive comic that gives gamers 6 choices to make - which are the main choices from Mass Effect. It doesn't replace the countless hours Xbox 360 gamers - as well as PC types - spent on the first game. The ability to import your ""Mass Effect"" character into ""Mass Effect 2"" is worth the cost alone. You can play without doing the interactive comic, but the default character is not amazing, and you won't be as tough as Shepard would be had you imported them into Mass Effect 2.

The sequel starts right where the original ended, but if you are a PS3 only gamer, than you probably haven't had any experience with it prior to now. You will become Commander Shepard, and can choose to play with a male or female Commander Shepard. There are six classes, which include Soldier, Infiltrator, Vanguard, Sentinel, Adept and Engineer. When you reach Level 4 in your specialty, you can learn a newer, higher more focused talent. This game is filled with adventures, and you will have plenty of hours ahead of you when you decide to take on this game.

If you haven't played it on Xbox, and want a challenge with awesome graphics and endless missions, this game is for you. Mass Effect 2 is a huge install at 22GB, so make sure you plan to do something else once you load the disc. See the video below for some game play previews!

","

65,"0","Pop Film: Catwoman Rises","Pop Film: Catwoman Rises","","",,"

Pop Film: Catwoman Rises
by Andy Dugan

Warner Bros has announced that Anne Hathaway was cast as Catwoman in the upcoming Batman sequel ""The Dark Knight Rises."" I personally have a hard time questioning Christopher Nolan's casting decisions, so I'm not ready to jump on it yet as bad casting, but I can't say I've ever been a fan of Anne Hathaway's work. When Nolan announced the Heath Ledger choice, I wasn't a hater
column2: I had liked him in about everything he did, same with Christian Bale. Hathaway won the role of the future Catwoman over a impressive list of actresses that included: Rachel Weisz, Naomi Watts, Blake Lively, Natalie Portman and Keira Knightley.

column1: I'm going to hold my tongue on the Hathaway choice for now, perhaps she will find a new fan in me once this film comes out and I see her performance, so instead of bashing on miss Hathaway, let's take a journey through previous Catwoman actresses.
My Favorite Catwoman was Michelle Pfeiffer in 1992's ""Batman Returns."" I can't imagine anyone topping her performance, or her costume! Check her out in this clip:

It's no question that Pfeiffer was amazing, but on the other end of the spectrum was Halle Berry's horrible performance in 2004's ""Catwoman"" directed by Pitof! I don't know why any studio would ask a guy name Pitof to direct a movie in the first place, and then for that movie to be ""Catwoman"" makes it even more of a questionable decision. I can't hate on the casting of Halle Berry, she's definitely got the pedigree to be Catwoman, but the way it was all done just ended up being a disaster, and Catwoman had seen the end of her nine lives because of that film, see here:

It was pretty difficult to find any ""clips"" of the film ""Catwoman"" on YouTube, I think that is telling enough. Moving on. I loved the 1960's Batman series, and Catwoman was always amazing in it regardless of the actress who portrayed her. Julie Newmar was the original Catwoman, followed by Lee Meriwether, and then Eartha Kitt. Here is Julie Newmar:
...and this is how Lee Meriwether portrayed Catwoman:
...and of course, the fantastic Eartha Kitt!
So this wouldn't be a complete without another amazing Catwoman! None other than the one from ""Batman: The Animated Series.""
Let's hope that Anne Hathaway joins the group of awesome Catwomen, and for all of you guys who had wished for Megan Fox to be cast as Catwoman, I am sorry, but you will always have this piece of art:

column2:
src=""http://www.reelcomix.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/09/megan-fox-catwoman.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""421"" />

","

column3: I had liked him in about everything he did, same with Christian Bale. Hathaway won the role of the future Catwoman over a impressive list of actresses that included: Rachel Weisz, Naomi Watts, Blake Lively, Natalie Portman and Keira Knightley.

column1: I'm going to hold my tongue on the Hathaway choice for now, perhaps she will find a new fan in me once this film comes out and I see her performance, so instead of bashing on miss Hathaway, let's take a journey through previous Catwoman actresses.
My Favorite Catwoman was Michelle Pfeiffer in 1992's ""Batman Returns."" I can't imagine anyone topping her performance, or her costume! Check her out in this clip:

It's no question that Pfeiffer was amazing, but on the other end of the spectrum was Halle Berry's horrible performance in 2004's ""Catwoman"" directed by Pitof! I don't know why any studio would ask a guy name Pitof to direct a movie in the first place, and then for that movie to be ""Catwoman"" makes it even more of a questionable decision. I can't hate on the casting of Halle Berry, she's definitely got the pedigree to be Catwoman, but the way it was all done just ended up being a disaster, and Catwoman had seen the end of her nine lives because of that film, see here:

It was pretty difficult to find any ""clips"" of the film ""Catwoman"" on YouTube, I think that is telling enough. Moving on. I loved the 1960's Batman series, and Catwoman was always amazing in it regardless of the actress who portrayed her. Julie Newmar was the original Catwoman, followed by Lee Meriwether, and then Eartha Kitt. Here is Julie Newmar:
...and this is how Lee Meriwether portrayed Catwoman:
...and of course, the fantastic Eartha Kitt!
So this wouldn't be a complete without another amazing Catwoman! None other than the one from ""Batman: The Animated Series.""
Let's hope that Anne Hathaway joins the group of awesome Catwomen, and for all of you guys who had wished for Megan Fox to be cast as Catwoman, I am sorry, but you will always have this piece of art:

column2:
src=""http://www.reelcomix.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/09/megan-fox-catwoman.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""421"" />

Pop Film: 'First Class' Photos
by Andy Dugan

This week's new releases don't scream, ""Go to the multiplex!"" so I'm going to talk about the news in Superhero films that came out this week!
We got an early shot of the X-Men: First Class cast, that was not approved by director Matthew Vaughn
column2: Warner Bros announced that Anne Hathaway was cast as Catwoman in the upcoming ""Dark Knight Rises,"" as well as Tom Hardy as Bane
column3: and Matthew Vaughn then released new photos from X-Men: First Class! Check out three of them below:

column1:
James McAvoy as ""Professor X""


Kevin Bacon as ""Sebastian Shaw"" and January Jones as ""Emma Frost""

I am not really sure that the three photos above really make up for the botched cast photo, but ""thanks"" for the new shots Matthew Vaughn, we really were wondering what James McAvoy looks like! However, anytime January Jones is in any photo, I'll take it.

Moving on... I'm more curious about the story of ""The Dark Knight Rises"" now than anything else related to the film. If you are going to have Catwoman and Bane in the same story, does that mean Bruce Wayne gets a new love interest in Selina Kyle, and then Batman has his back broken at the end of the film to finish off Nolan's trilogy? I'm not sure that would make for a happy ending, but maybe Nolan doesn't want to give us one. Too bad Joel Schumacher didn't follow the Bane storyline in 1997's ""Batman &
column2: Robin"" because that Batman was worth destroying.

column1: The Tom Hardy choice for Bane should pan out pretty good, I'm guessing he's going to work out a lot over the next few months and put on some pounds, because he doesn't appear to be that big of a guy, but I'm sure he can pull it off. I am much more excited to see that performance than Anne Hathaway as Catwoman, but I won't get into that again.

If you do end up wanting to see a film at the theatres this weekend, you choices are pretty limited. Paramount Pictures is releasing the sex-comedy ""No Strings Attached"" starring Ashton Kutcher and Natalie Portman
column2: and New Market Films is pushing out ""The Way Back"" starring Ed Harris and Colin Farrell. The trailers are below, but I can't endorse either film.

67,"0","Pop TV: Gods of the Arena","Pop TV: Gods of the Arena","","",,"

Pop TV: Gods of the Arena
by Andy Dugan

This weekend welcomes the Season 2 release of Spartacus, this time around it's called ""Spartacus: Gods of the Arena."" This season is more of a prequel to last year's ""Blood and Sand"" than a season 2, which is an interesting approach, but after killing off Batiatus, and destroying the arena, was there any other way to do it? I learned a lot about the new season by watching this video:

One thing I will definitely miss from last season is the lead actor, Andy Whitfield, who is being replaced by Liam McIntyre because of a battle with cancer. It's unfortunate that he had to drop out of the show, but Liam looks like a suitable replacement, and I'm looking forward to seeing what he does with the character. I had pretty much written off Starz original shows before I saw ""Spartacus: Blood and Sand,"" because of ""Gravity"" and ""Party Down,"" but now I'm back on their bandwagon. I've always been a fan of HBO and Showtime series, and I feel like Starz really stepped into the arena with ""Blood and Sand,"" so I hope they keep it up with ""Gods of the Arena.""
One thing ""Spartacus"" hasn't refrained from is gratuitous violence and sex. With ""Blood and Sand,"" Starz accomplished everything HBO's ""Rome"" had set out to do, and failed at
column2: I would also argue that ""Blood and Sand"" was more entertaining than ""300."" I can't officially review ""Gods of the Arena"" yet, but I am sure you will see my thoughts on it this upcoming week.&nbsp
column3: Right now, I can only endorse the show by saying: Watch it this weekend!

column2: t easy, it could take way too long and it really wasn&rsquo
column3: t  cool to see all your hard work resting on the long-term health of some  magnetically coated plastic tape. But that was the beauty of it
column4: it was a labor of love. The mixtape was an art and everyone knows good art never comes easy.

column1: Each one contained a story, a struggle and captured a moment in time. Each song stood for something
column2: it was there for a reason. The mixtape  had mythical powers, it could: impress a girl, make you look cool, make  you look weird, keep you up at night, and it could even keep you from  going to the bathroom while you waited for that one song you needed to  come on the radio.  Not to mention, naming the thing &ndash
column3: the perfect name,  written with the perfect pen in your imperfect handwriting&hellip

column2: s most influential artists to recount their  experiences with making mixtapes and renowned photographer and director  Jonathan Mannion captured it all on film. The result is the TDK Life on  Record Chronicles film series that pays tribute to the days of cassette  tapes and the anatomy of the mixtape. The exclusive film  series starts with The Strokes, New York&rsquo
column3: s own Nas and indie rock stalwarts The Walkmen. The Chronicles film series provides a rare look into the lives of these artists that reveals their love of music through songs and stories from their pasts.

column2: m Kate, and I host the She Geek Show.

column1:
Gaming is probably the thing I have done best and most consistently in life. I grew up with a steady stream of consoles: NES, SNES, Genesis, PS1, PS2, Xbox (I have indulgent parents). Then I washed out of college due to a, uh, slight obsession with EverQuest. Now I own all the current gen consoles, a passable PC gaming rig, and an unwieldy Steam library.

She Geek Show started in 2010 as an outlet for my nerdy side after attending Emerald City Comic Con
column2: I wanted to talk about games and comics and headlines to get conversations going and interact with a global geek community. I also aspired to be an average, down to earth female voice in a male-host/female-spokesmodel dominated industry, without calling attention to my anatomy (the title sort of gives it away, but it has such a nice alliterative quality!).
ve started a job as a web/UX designer for ArenaNet, working on Guild Wars 2 -- a game I&rsquo
column3: ve personally been excited about for a long time. If you&rsquo
column4: ve ever dreamed of getting into the industry and imagined how much fun it would be all the time, it&rsquo
column5: s exactly like you picture it... but better. All our meetings are about game mechanics and interactivity. They pay people for this?! (By the way -- I know we&rsquo
column6:
re buddies and all, but I am not going to tell you when Guild Wars 2 is coming out.)

The genres I end up playing the most are action/adventure, RPG, platformer, and puzzle games. Favorite games include but are not limited to: Red Dead Redemption, Assassin&rsquo
column7: s Creed 2 and Brotherhood, Mass Effect 1 and 2, Braid, and Psychonauts. I don&rsquo
column8: t play pure shooters, mostly because the things that I&rsquo
column9:
m bad at make me angry.

I&rsquo
column10:
m crazy excited to be joining the Pop Galaxy team as we launch the site. Come follow me on Twitter at @shegeekshow, Like my Facebook page and say hi!

- Kate
XBL, Steam, PSN: worldasmyth

column1: 71,"0","Pop Games: What's Next for Downloadable Games?","Pop Games: What's Next for Downloadable Games?","","",,"

""Editor's note: Scott Steinberg is the head of technology and video game consulting firm TechSavvy Global, as well as the founder of GameExec magazine and Game Industry TV. The creator and host of online video series Game Theory, he frequently appears as an on-air technology analyst for ABC, CBS, NBC, FOX and CNN.""
(CNN) -- From the Nintendo 3DS's ability to grab titles on demand to the increasing popularity of retail sites like Steam and Direct2Drive.com, downloadable games will be everywhere in 2011.
The days when you had to visit your local store, buy a title and insert a disc into your console to play a game are long gone.

Thanks to new episodic titles (""Back to the Future,"" ""Jurassic Park""), popular indie PC games (""Minecraft,"" ""Recettear"") and a growing range of smartphone apps and console-exclusive downloads, digital game distribution continues to grow.
Whether you're playing on your PlayStation 3, Wii, Xbox 360 or mobile handset, here are five new and upcoming titles that exemplify the expanding breadth of what online game downloads have to offer.
""X-Men Arcade"" (PlayStation Network/Xbox Live Arcade)

Revisit your misspent adolescence with a conversion of the popular side-scrolling 1992 arcade brawler starring Cyclops, Wolverine, Nightcrawler and other comic book favorites -- before they became movie icons.

High-definition multiplayer cartoon action for up to six players takes top billing, as you use fists, laser beams and super powers to bludgeon Magneto's crew of villains, including Juggernaut, Pyro and The Blob.

Read the rest of this entry at CNN: What's next for downloadable games?

72,"0","Pop Comics: Marvel Reveals FF Death","Pop Comics: Marvel Reveals FF Death","","",,"

Marvel Reveals FF Death
by

column4: In a move sure to shock comic fans worldwide, Marvel  unveiled that its ever popular super hero the Human Torch will meet his  demise and die heroically in Fantastic Four #587, hitting stores  today (Wednesday, January 26th). Concluding the &ldquo
column6: storyline that captivated the mainstream media and industry press alike, this issue and the death of such a renowned character from the First Family of comics signals the beginning of major changes for the Marvel Universe as the Fantastic Four lose one of their founding members.

column2: Jonathan Hickman [writer of Fantastic Four] came to us two years ago  with a vision for evolving the characters and concepts introduced to  fans 50 years ago in Fantastic Four #1 &ndash
column3: and quite frankly his vision  blew us away,&rdquo
column4: said Tom Brevoort, Marvel Entertainment SVP of  Publishing. &ldquo
column5: The death of the Human Torch is the first major move in  this incredibly exciting evolution of the legendary Fantastic Four  franchise and a necessary part of the larger story we will be telling  featuring the beloved characters moving forward.&rdquo

73,"0","Pop Games: Guild Wars 2 Reveal","Enter The Guardian","","",,"

By Kate Welch
Last week, fans of Guild Wars 2 got a surprise when PC Gamer hinted at this week's much-anticipated reveal: the Guardian profession.

As with the other professions in Guild Wars 2, the Guardian is designed to take on multiple roles in battle scenarios. A Guardian's virtues -- Justice, Courage, and Resolve -- allow him the variety of attack power and tenacity to deal and take damage, and his special skills include buffs and area-of-effect abilities to support his fellows in combat.
The Guardian may be heavily armored and have a diversity of weapon combinations, but don't confuse him with the Warrior. It sounds like the Guardian's greatest role will be that of support
column2: although each profession can switch their strength on the fly to adapt to anything the battle throws their way, I see the Guardian's abilities and buffs as being an essential part of any group. Personally, I love classes that give group buffs and provide distraction from the glass cannon types, because usually I'm playing the glass cannon. The fact that the Guardian can both buff and protect his groupmates makes him a character everyone is going to want on their side.

column1:
- Kate
XBL, Steam, PSN: worldasmyth

74,"0","Pop Film: The Mechanic","Pop Film: The Mechanic","","",,"

Pop Film: The Mechanic
by Andy Dugan

What do you get when you take Jason Statham and Ben Foster, put them in an old Charles Bronson film, and blow some stuff up? Well, obviously you get a remake of an old Charles Bronson film with Jason Statham and Ben Foster, a lot of guns, and a film titled ""The Mechanic.""

Personally, I'm kind of tired of remakes. Have Hollywood studios and writers really forgotten how to create new content? It seems like every week a new remake is coming out, regardless of genre. That being said, I'm fine with this one, it looks really cool to me, and I love this throwback trailer that was released on YouTube! Check it out:

I always know what I'm getting when I see a Jason Statham film, but this time I'm also seeing a Ben Foster film. Ben Foster is an awesome actor, so I think he gives this film some legitimacy. The truth is, overall, this movie has a great cast, including: Mini Anden, Donald Sutherland, and Tony Goldwyn. It's also directed by Simon West, who has a pretty great resume with action movies (I liked Con Air &
I haven't been able to watch ""The Mechanic"" yet, but I plan to this week. Here is another great clip:

For more ""Mechanic"" fun you can also browse around the web site: www.themechanicmovie.com - there is a pretty awesome ""Red Band"" trailer, and pictures of Mini Anden that anyone should be able to appreciate. Also, here is a link to a great review by Kurt Loder, where he gives it his seal of approval.

column2:

column1: 77,"0","Pop Comics: Superman Casting","Pop Comics: Superman Casting","","",,"

SUPERMAN: A CONTEXT OF SEVENTY YEARS OF CASTING
by Jason Badower

The Brit, Henry Cavill has been cast as Superman in the new film. It's directed by Zach Snyder (Watchmen, 300) and produced by Christopher Nolan (The Dark Knight, Inception). Superman is such an iconic, cultural figure. He's been flying around since 1938 and has been in some sort of mass media syndication ever since. To make an informed decision as to how we feel about Cavill's casting and what our expectations are, it's necessary to evaluate what has gone before. What were the significant Superman performances and how have they shaped our perception of the Last Son of Krypton over the last seven decades?
BUDDY COLLYER, THE ADVENTURES OF SUPERMAN (1940) RADIO

column11: } --> feature Buddy Collyer as the only voice talent of Superman in this list. He played Superman for eleven years until 1951. This is where they actually invented the concept of Kryptonite. Whenever Buddy fell ill or his voice was sidelined, out came the Kryptonite. Buddy was then able to moan and whimper his way through his performances and it was on with the show. Coincidentally both his condition and the kryptonite scenarios were defeated at the same time.

column12: } -->Kirk starred in fifteen movie serials that chronicled Superman&rsquo
column13: s fight against the now-famous Spider Lady. Ok, not every ball they kicked was a goal back then. Later, in 1950 he starred in &ldquo
column15: , which featured something that eleven years later would become the inter-dimensional space prison known as the Phantom Zone. And without the Phantom Zone, the only spinning Terrance Stamp we&rsquo
column16: d ever enjoy would be in &ldquo

column12: iconic seven-year portrayal of the Man of Steel would forever endear him to the hearts of America. He took his newfound popularity and role model status seriously. He avoided smoking in public (and eventually quit), and he raised significant money to combat myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disease. He was also famous for popularizing the &ldquo
column14: that begun with Kirk Alyn. His typecasting was absolute and doomed his acting career. His tragic death by gunshot (ruled as a suicide, but controversially debated as a murder or accidental shooting) fueled the fire of the curse. But his charisma, presence and genuine love for his younger fans cemented him as one of the most iconic portrayals of Superman.

column12: } --> This Broadway musical was directed by Harold Prince and starred Jack Cassidy and then Bob Holiday as Superman/Clark Kent. The musical featured Superman&rsquo
column13: s conflict with the not-so-memorable Dr. Abner Sedgwick. It ran for 129 shows and received three Tony award nominations, which are great ways to pad your resume rather than your fireplace.

column1: This musical has come back from the dead almost as many times as the Man of Tomorrow himself. It&rsquo
column2: s been on and off since the year after it closed all the way through to July of 2010. In fact, it was so popular it even spawned a TV spin-off. If you ask any Broadway musical what it wants to be when it grows up, you will get one answer, &ldquo
s hard to wonder why this apparent lackluster production failed. Apparently it was broadcast to &ldquo
column4: and failed to capture the energy of the original Broadway show. I&rsquo
column5: d like to posit that perhaps casting a Superman that knows what the inside of a gym looks like might have helped? David Wilson looks like he&rsquo
column6: d be more at home walking down the aisles of Comic-Con with an oversized bag as big as his sweat stains.

column1: Christopher Reeve is Superman. He was trained by Darth Vader (David Prowse) for two months and put on 30 lbs. (14kg) of muscle for the role. He contrasted that physique with a softer, emotional, three-dimensional character. But it would be easy to overestimate Christopher Reeve&rsquo
column2: s (no relation to George Reeves) performance as the Last Son of Krypton when you compare it to his co-stars. His incredibly grounded and real character was a bright spot of wonder in a cast of scenery-chewing cartoons. It&rsquo
column3: s his stunning portrayal of Superman playing Clark Kent, however, that makes you realize exactly what a secret identity is. The only question is why an almost omnipotent being would choose to bumble his way through life. Is this how he sees us? Or is this how he really wants to be perceived?  In 1995, Reeve suffered a cervical spinal injury that paralyzed him from the waist down. This was just the first of many health complications that Reeve fought. He bested many conditions that should have killed him. In 2004 he went into cardiac arrest and died at the age of 52. His wife Dana went on to start the Christopher &amp
column4: Dana Reeve Foundation to cure spinal cord injury. Grab a sweet set of Superman dog tags and donate to the cause:

Bill Murray as Superman and Dan Aykroyd as The Flash. I think the proton packs came later. And yes, that&rsquo
column2: s Margot Kidder who played Lois Lane in the Superman movies. Watch and laugh. And then admire all the hair everyone had back then.

column1: The Salkinds, the producers of increasingly mediocre Superman movies, decided to look to a different medium to explore the Superman franchise. For his 50th
column2: celebration, Superboy was born to television. This happened despite the fact that John Byrne had retconned Superman a year earlier in the comics and smartly eliminated the concept of Superboy. But fanboy rage aside, John Newton only wore the cape for a single season. A combination of a dissatisfactory performance, his requests for a 20% salary raise and a very public DUI arrest all combined to get his ass shipped off to the Phantom Zone.&nbsp
column3: But was continuity restored? Were the universes merged into one coherent whole? Did television and comics finally get along? No indeed. A new Kryptonian was shipped in&hellip

column1: Gerard Christopher took over for Newton. Being the prepubescent teenager that I was, I barely noticed his departure. My teenage hormones were firmly fixed on Stacy Haiduk as Lana Lang. But Gerard went on to both produce and write on the show. Eventually WB put a lien on the show as they&rsquo
column2: d only loaned the Salkinds the rights to the Superman franchise. It was said that they had &ldquo
column6: t want two Superman shows on the air. So much for &ldquo
column8: .  Anyway, after he was axed Gerard actually tried out for the role of Superman in &ldquo
column11: and reportedly won the role. After it was discovered that he had already had a room in the Fortress of Solitude, he was kicked to the curb in favor of Dean Cain&hellip

column2: CLARK: THE NEW ADVENTURES OF SUPERMAN (1993)

column3: , so Clark is the star rather than Superman. It followed John Byrne&rsquo
column4: s theory that Clark Kent is the real personality and Superman is the disguise. This take lends an authenticity to the character, but Dean Cain&rsquo
column5: s almost identical portrayal of both characters brought into question the intelligence and perceptive skills of the reporters of the Daily Planet. The real hallmark of the series, however, was the addition of a Lois Lane (Teri Hatcher) that you could fall in love with (thus empathizing with Superman&rsquo
column6: s feelings), as well as a Lex Luthor played by John Shea that was, for the first time, believable, real and scary.

column2: s where I sneak one in. Check the heading. &ldquo
column4: , right? So give a comic book fan his due here. Alex Ross&rsquo
column5: vision of an older, more majestic and statesman-like Superman has had far-reaching cultural influence. His basis for Big Blue is his muse and friend, Frank Kasy. Looking at the above photo reference, it&rsquo
column6: s hard to see The Last Son of Krypton in Kasy&rsquo
column7: s features, but Alex Ross obviously does. Model and artist combine to create a performance greater than the sum of their parts. The seminal graphic novel &ldquo

column1: In this incredibly clever revision of the Superman mythos, it&rsquo
column2: s all about discovering the tights. The show has its ups and downs, and it&rsquo
column3: s not particularly well written in places, but it also has a host of fantastic common sense ideas and additions to the mythos. Tom Welling&rsquo
column4: s restrained and quiet, introspective Clark makes for a great platform for the other actors to work from. Michael Rosenbaum&rsquo
column5: s brilliant exploration of the descent of Lex Luthor took John Shea&rsquo

column2: s a fan film trailer, but Sandy Collera can create some nice visuals. And professional body builder (and ex-American Gladiator) Mike O&rsquo
column3: Hearn brings some serious mass to the big blue tights. You should also find Sandy Collera&rsquo
column4: s Batman: Dead End, which is great until he jumps the sharks. Yes. Multiple sharks.

column2: s exploration of Superman-as-Christ was a film without an audience. The violence was too heavy for children (being shot in the eye was cool though), and the dialog and relationships too simplistic for adults. But Brandon Routh channeled Christopher Reeve beautifully. He brought an alien presence together with the boy-scout charm to create a magnificent performance. In keeping with its preceding films, the only thing worth watching is Superman himself. Brandon Routh brought a fantastic viewpoint to the Superman curse. Bryan Singer asked Brandon Routh, ""Aren't you worried about the Superman curse? What if something bad happens to you?"" Brandon replied, ""Something bad could happen to me and I might not get to be Superman.""

column1: Is it fair to include an actor playing an actor, playing Superman? Sure. Because there are some times where he actually IS Superman. This haunting speculative film suffers from some pacing and gravitas issues on the part of Adrien Brody&rsquo
column2: s character, but is a definite watch for Superman fans.

column1: And the most recent portrayal goes to Dwayne &ldquo
column3: Johnson. I could watch The Rock in anything, so seeing him in a Superman suit stuffed into a three-piece suit was just gold. Enjoy and laugh. See it here: http://www.evanmcb.com/2008/04/saturday-sketch-rock-as-superman.html

column1: So how does Henry Cavill stack up against all these seminal actors? To accurately assess that, we need to evaluate him in the context of the script. Hardcore Iron Man fans were concerned that the witty and flippant Robert Downey Jr. would never be able to convey the businessman-like shark ruthlessness of Stark Enterprise&rsquo
column3: t have to. In a clever piece of writing and casting, those personality traits became embodied in Obadiah Stane&rsquo
column4: s (Jeff Bridges) character. So if we&rsquo
column5: re looking for a younger, more ideal Superman who perhaps hasn&rsquo
column6: t come to terms with his role, identity, or powers, the 27-year-old Henry Cavill might just be the perfect casting.

column2: s depth and intelligence, David Goyer&rsquo
column3: s experience with the genre, and Zach Snyder&rsquo
column4: s extraordinary visuals, we might just finally get ourselves a Superman film that works on all fronts.

column2: s just hope he punches someone.

column2: s a fan film trailer, but Sandy Collera can create some nice visuals. And professional body builder (and ex-American Gladiator) Mike O&rsquo
column3: Hearn brings some serious mass to the big blue tights. You should also find Sandy Collera&rsquo
column4: s Batman: Dead End, which is great until he jumps the sharks. Yes. Multiple sharks.

column2: s exploration of Superman-as-Christ was a film without an audience. The violence was too heavy for children (being shot in the eye was cool though), and the dialog and relationships too simplistic for adults. But Brandon Routh channeled Christopher Reeve beautifully. He brought an alien presence together with the boy-scout charm to create a magnificent performance. In keeping with its preceding films, the only thing worth watching is Superman himself. Brandon Routh brought a fantastic viewpoint to the Superman curse. Bryan Singer asked Brandon Routh, ""Aren't you worried about the Superman curse? What if something bad happens to you?"" Brandon replied, ""Something bad could happen to me and I might not get to be Superman.""

column1: Is it fair to include an actor playing an actor, playing Superman? Sure. Because there are some times where he actually IS Superman. This haunting speculative film suffers from some pacing and gravitas issues on the part of Adrien Brody&rsquo
column2: s character, but is a definite watch for Superman fans.

column1: And the most recent portrayal goes to Dwayne &ldquo
column3: Johnson. I could watch The Rock in anything, so seeing him in a Superman suit stuffed into a three-piece suit was just gold. Enjoy and laugh. See it here: http://www.evanmcb.com/2008/04/saturday-sketch-rock-as-superman.html

column1: So how does Henry Cavill stack up against all these seminal actors? To accurately assess that, we need to evaluate him in the context of the script. Hardcore Iron Man fans were concerned that the witty and flippant Robert Downey Jr. would never be able to convey the businessman-like shark ruthlessness of Stark Enterprise&rsquo
column3: t have to. In a clever piece of writing and casting, those personality traits became embodied in Obadiah Stane&rsquo
column4: s (Jeff Bridges) character. So if we&rsquo
column5: re looking for a younger, more ideal Superman who perhaps hasn&rsquo
column6: t come to terms with his role, identity, or powers, the 27-year-old Henry Cavill might just be the perfect casting.

column2: s depth and intelligence, David Goyer&rsquo
column3: s experience with the genre, and Zach Snyder&rsquo
column4: s extraordinary visuals, we might just finally get ourselves a Superman film that works on all fronts.

column2: s just hope he punches someone.

79,"0","Pop Film: Sanctum 3D","Pop Film: Sanctum 3D","","",,"

The Frame Rate: Sanctum
by Crix Lee

Sanctum is the new 3D epic from Executive Producer James Cameron, Directed by Alister Grierson and stars Richard Roxburgh, Ioan Gruffudd, Rhys Wakefield, Dan Wyllie and Alice Parkinson. Inspired by Co-Writer Andrew Wight's near-death experience leading a diving expedition miles into to an underwater cave system and finding their way out after the entrance collapsed due to a freak storm, Sanctum looks to feed some of our most basest of fears (heights, drowning, fear of the unknown) and turn it into a 109 minute thrill ride.

One thing I've noticed over the years about Australian directors (Luhrmann, Miller, Weir) is that they are absolute MASTERS of giant, sweeping panoramic shots that suck you into the story within the first five minutes of the film
column2: and Grierson is no different. What Sanctum is VERY successful at is a lot of 'wow' moments during the film. I would hear the occasional 'wow' and 'whoa' in the theatre (including myself), and coupled with the 3D landscapes created by Team Cameron/Grierson make you feel like you're the 7th member of the expedition team, fighting for your life.

column1: The sets are so realistic, I found myself hyperventilating a lot during a lot of the underwater sequences. There are TONS of shots where the actor on screen looks to be about the size of a single rice krispie floating in a swimming pool.
column2: Couple that with 3D and you will find yourself thinking you need a re-breather too.&nbsp
column3:
A few times I was so blown away by what the environment looked like, it would turn into a ""Where's Waldo"" situation trying to find the actors, but I couldn't help myself, there is SO much to look at.

Unfortunately, the weak point of Sanctum is the storyline. I just wish a little more time would've been invested into the father/son dynamic of Frank (Richard Roxburgh) and Josh (Rhys Wakefield) as well as the one between Frank and uber millionaire/friend/benefactor, Carl. I really wanted to know more about them and the only characters I felt a connection to were Josh and Crazy George (Dan Wyllie), who provided a lot of the film's comic relief. I was also a little disappointed by the ending
column4: it felt slightly abrupt and I was surprised that it ended in that matter. I would've LOVED some kind of postmortem before the end credits.

column1: Sanctum was the PERFECT film to be shot in 3D, really beautifully done, guaranteed Oscar noms for tech stuff next year
column3: but the acting, not so much.&nbsp
column4: (And that is REALLY hard for me to say because I LOVE LOVE LOVE Richard Roxburgh&hellip
column5:
but he sounded like he was bucking to replace Christian Bale for The Dark Knight sequel. It made me sad in the face AND the pants. ha.)

Sanctum opens nationwide today, February 4th.

Frame Rate: Fun

Crix Lee is best known as Editor in Chief at GirlGamer.com and contributing staff writer for GeekWeek.com and DreadCentral.com's video game departments. A video game journalist and host for 3 years, Lee is relishing her residency at Pop Galaxy with her column, The Frame Rate. She also loves the color pink and Star Wars possibly a LITTLE too much... she would also like to make out with Dead Space icon Isaac Clarke (if he actually existed, that is).
