82,"1","Pop Games: She Geek - Bulletstorm","Pop Games: She Geek - Bulletstorm","","",,"

BULLETSTORM
by Kate Welch (SheGeekShow)

I remember Bulletstorm's first public demo last year. My reaction was: ""Are they serious right now?"" Sometime between then and now, however, Bulletstorm placed itself firmly in the hilarilously-overwrought-violence category and captured the attention of the media and shooter fans everywhere.
The story starts out pretty standard -- space pirates crash-land on a post-apocalyptic Earth, killer mutants are everywhere, gotta kill your way out.
column2: However, it's not story that's going to keep you playing Bulletstorm. I get the feeling it's a little light on story.

src=""http://media.giantbomb.com/uploads/0/30/1358225-bulletstorm_screen_8_super.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""317"" />

You'll keep playing Bulletstorm because of the lovingly crafted, almost decadent number of ways you will get to create video game carnage.

In the tutorial intro, which outlines what each of the buttons do before you actually jump into the game itself, the narrator challenges you to kill mutants as creatively as possible to earn bonuses. He also teaches you what button to press to kick enemies in the beanbag. (His words, not mine.) It perfectly sets the tone for the unapologetic killfest that you're about to unleash.

column1: Graphically speaking, the game looks good. Really good. You'd expect this from Epic, the folks who made the Gears of War games: gorgeous guns, luscious environments, great physics.

And now we come to the killing.

You're going to see a lot of the same bonuses if you stick with just shooting your enemies the same way over and over. What pushes Bulletstorm over the line from shockingly juvenile to genuinely creative is their use of environment in the bonus system. Each map looks to be set up with a huge amount of traps, machines, heights, spikes, exposed wires -- pretty much everything your mom warned you to steer clear of. The more you utilize these environments in your murders, the more likely it is that you'll discover a sweet new bonus you haven't seen before. Kick a guy in the groin and send him over a ledge for a Vertigo bonus. Shoot him with the Flail gun (it shoots two grenades connected by a chain as ammo -- naturally) to hook the grenades around his neck for a Grenade Gag bonus.

The list, as they say, goes on.

And that's where the appeal lies. This is a shooter, make no mistake, and it's not easy for me to love console shooters
column2: man was not meant to slaughter video game foes with thumb-sticks. &nbsp
column3: What I'm hoping to see when the game is released is a wider variety of clever murder bonuses, more environmental traps, and more potty humor from the pirate gang. Excessive violence has been done before -- Bulletstorm stands apart by making you giggle at poop jokes while you figure out the most creative and violent way to kill your way through the map.

column1: Fox News asks whether Bulletstorm is ""the worst game in the world?"" (Answer: Possibly, but that's why it's gonna sell so well!)
Check out the latest episode of the She Geek Show!

column2:
>Pop Comics: Arkham City Miniseries
by Andy Dugan

Ever wonder what happened between the end of Batman: Arkham Asylum and the beginning of the upcoming game, Batman: Arkham City? This May you can find out with the release of the BATMAN: ARKHAM CITY comic book miniseries that was announced today by DC Comics!
column3: The new miniseries is written by Batman: The Animated Series writer Paul Dini (who also penned both Arkham games) and drawn by Batman: Arkham Asylum and Batman: Arkham City concept artist Carlos D&rsquo
column4: anda. The miniseries picks up one year after the game ended, and the former Arkham Warden, Quincy Sharp, is now the Mayor of Gotham City. As Mayor, he decides to shut down the Asylum and open up a district known as ""Arkham City,"" where the inmates can roam free and do as they please. It kind of sounds like a Batman version of ""Escape from New York."" This urban prison is being run by Dr. Hugo Strange, the only man who knows that Bruce Wayne is Batman.

column2: >I am really looking forward to reading this comic miniseries in preparation for the hours I'm destined to spend on my PS3 this year playing Arkham City!
>BATMAN: ARKHAM CITY will double-ship in its first month, with issues 1 &amp
column3: 2 landing in May. Each issue of the miniseries will be available day-and-date digitally worldwide for $2.99 each. These releases will alternate with 8-page digital-first interludes that will expand on the story included in the miniseries. Written by Dini and drawn by a variety of artists, these digital stories will focus on The Dark Knight&rsquo
column4: s many enemies as they vie for power in this new city within a city. Each eight-page digital-first interlude will be available for .99 cents, releasing in between issues of the miniseries, and will later be included in print in the BATMAN: ARKHAM CITY collected edition.
column6: The digital first stories offer a unique incentive for fans to experience interesting and exciting stories beyond the pages in the printed comic,&rdquo
column7: said Jim Lee, DC Comics Co-Publisher, &ldquo
column8: The additional pages will serve as interludes within the regular issues and won&rsquo
column9: t be necessary to follow the main story of the miniseries. Fans will also be able to read these interludes in print later, when we publish the collected edition.&rdquo

column2: >For more Arkham City madness, check out the Facebook page: Batman: Arkham City.

>This week on the latest episode of the She Geek Show here on Pop Galaxy, Kate talks the game screenshots that were released, and gives us a history in Batman video games. Arkham City is bound to be a hit, and I'm pretty sure the comic miniseries will too.

85,"0","Pop TV: The Unpoppables","Pop TV: The Unpoppables","","",,"

The Frame Rate: Meet The Unpoppables
by Crix Lee

Okay, I think we can all agree that there's Eleventy Billion (exact count) cooking, baking and ""Hey, I own a cake shop"" shows out there but where's the show about the people who make balloon sculptures for a living?

THAT would be The Unpoppables.

Like everyone else, I was attracted to the show on the name alone. I had glossed over a snippet about it before the premiere and thought it was about people who do twisty things with balloons (like the backyard birthday clown) or make helium balloon bouquets like you get from the florist.

While they DO do twisty things with balloons, it goes SO much deeper than that: they make eclectic, intriguing, scary good and completely charming works of art and have the personalities to match.
column2:
src=""http://static.howstuffworks.com/gif/unpoppables-102-3.jpg"" alt="""" width=""400"" height=""288"" />

Los Angeles based New Balloon Art is owned and operated by self taught veteran Addi Somekh who is to balloon art what Duff Goldman is to cakes. Along with colleagues Katie Balloons (balloon dressmaker) and chef turned artist Brian Asman, these three make pieces of art that shows there is NO limit to what you can do with a few bits of colored rubber and air. NEVER in a million years did I think you could construct balloons in such a way that you could actually have people SIT ON THEM&hellip
column3:
but now I do!

The first two episodes aired February 7th on TLC and OMG, I was BLOWN AWAY.
column4:
There is a science to what they do and each episode is like a lesson, like it seems like they DO want you to explore your own imagination and try this at home.

The pilot episode revolved around creating a 3-piece install for the Firefighters Museum in Hollywood. Here's a small recap with the end product.

Prepare to say 'WOW'.



Frame Rate: EFFING COOL and #CrixApproved

The Unpoppables airs Mondays at 8 PM (ET/PT) on TLC

The Frame Rate: Meet The Unpoppables
by Crix Lee

Okay, I think we can all agree that there's Eleventy Billion (exact count) cooking, baking and ""Hey, I own a cake shop"" shows out there but where's the show about the people who make balloon sculptures for a living?

THAT would be The Unpoppables.

Like everyone else, I was attracted to the show on the name alone. I had glossed over a snippet about it before the premiere and thought it was about people who do twisty things with balloons (like the backyard birthday clown) or make helium balloon bouquets like you get from the florist.

While they DO do twisty things with balloons, it goes SO much deeper than that: they make eclectic, intriguing, scary good and completely charming works of art and have the personalities to match.
column5:
src=""http://static.howstuffworks.com/gif/unpoppables-102-3.jpg"" alt="""" width=""400"" height=""288"" />

Los Angeles based New Balloon Art is owned and operated by self taught veteran Addi Somekh who is to balloon art what Duff Goldman is to cakes. Along with colleagues Katie Balloons (balloon dressmaker) and chef turned artist Brian Asman, these three make pieces of art that shows there is NO limit to what you can do with a few bits of colored rubber and air. NEVER in a million years did I think you could construct balloons in such a way that you could actually have people SIT ON THEM&hellip
column6:
but now I do!

The first two episodes aired February 7th on TLC and OMG, I was BLOWN AWAY.
column7:
There is a science to what they do and each episode is like a lesson, like it seems like they DO want you to explore your own imagination and try this at home.

The pilot episode revolved around creating a 3-piece install for the Firefighters Museum in Hollywood. Here's a small recap with the end product.

Prepare to say 'WOW'.

Pop Music: Grammy Upset
by Andy Dugan

It's about time an album wins the Grammy that wasn't recorded by Britney Spears, Usher, Justin Bieber or Lady Gaga. Oddly enough, a very creative album called ""The Suburbs"" by The Arcade Fire won Album of the Year (beating out Lady Gaga, Eminem, and Katy Perry). ""The Suburbs,"" also spawned an interactive film by director Chris Milk, featuring ""We Used To Wait""
column2: > called ""The Wilderness Downtown,"" check it out! (best if viewed in Google Chrome)

>Arcade Fire wasn't the only upset of the night, Esperanza Spalding won Best New Artist, which most believed was going to Justin Bieber. Turns out, it wasn't the best weekend for Bieber afterall, because his film, ""Never Say Never"" also didn't open to #1 like eveyone predicted. I kinda feel bad though, because I also snubbed Bieber in my write up about weekend movies, so in all fairness, here is the trailer to his movie.

Pop Extra: Captain America Toys!
by Andy Dugan

Marvel and Hasbro have released images of the forthcoming Captain America toys, and they look a lot like repainted G.I. Joe figures. I remember back in 94' when Hasbro made ""Street Fighter II"" toys, which also ended up being repainted ""Duke"" and ""Storm Shadow"" figurines. I hope kids today aren't as disappointed as I was when I was left with another ""Flint"" toy disguised as ""Guile."" Take a look at these new G.I. Joes, I mean Captain America toys!

So feel free to let us know your thoughts on these bad boys... I personally think the ""Zartan"" character above goes one step too far. I do kind of like the ""Aquaman"" version of Captain America though...

91,"0","Pop Games: Stacking","Pop Games: Stacking","","",,"

Pop Games: Stacking
by Kate Welch (She Geek)

Creativity has never been in short supply at Double Fine. Their last downloadable offering, Costume Quest, was adorable and hilarious -- exactly what you'd expect from genius superhero game deity Tim Schafer. (Yeah, I'm a little biased.)

Stacking is another downloadable morsel, available for both Xbox Live Arcade and PSN (for 1200 MS Points or $14.99, respectively -- free if you're a Playstation Plus member!). Stacking is set in the industrial start of the 20th century, right at that moment where the future could have deviated toward steampunk rather than electric futurism. Characters are grubby, there are coal mines, there's a level on a zeppelin, and cut scenes are told as silent movies. The soundtrack is excellent, comprised of jaunty piano music taking its influence from dramatic silent film scores. It definitely nails down the feeling of an era.

You are Charlie Blackmore, the smallest member of a family of Russian stacking dolls (or ""matryoshka"", in case you like cool Russian words). Your siblings are abducted and forced into child labor across a variety of levels, and naturally, you gotta save 'em. As the smallest stacking doll in Stacking-land, your job is to stack inside other, bigger dolls with various abilities that allow you to solve puzzles.

The dolls vary widely in ability. There are a set of basic dolls you learn to identify on sight -- the little paperboys with the ""throw paper"" ability, the lady doll who sips tea on command, the larger man with the noxious belch. There's also a couple dozen special dolls per level whose abilities are unique
column2: find and stack with every unique doll in each level to complete your collection. It's more than a little addictive.&nbsp

column1: It's up to you and Charlie Blackmore to try out each doll type you see, get a feel for its abilities, and keep them in mind when you're up against puzzles in the game. Each puzzle has at least three possible ways it can be successfully completed. This is actually my favorite part of the game: once you solve a puzzle, you can move right along to the next part, or you can approach the puzzle again and try to figure out the alternate solutions. Sometimes they're pretty blindingly obvious. Sometimes, not so much. (Hint: you're gonna want to fart into that air vent.)

In addition to solving the puzzles, certain unique dolls have ""Hi-Jinks"" to complete. These are mini-challenges that require you to use the doll's special ability a certain number of times in certain situations. Stack with every unique doll, complete all the Hi-Jinks, and find each solution for every puzzle to get 100% in Stacking. You completionists will have no lack of things to do.

All in all, Stacking is tremendous title for those of you who are looking for a little break from your Halos or your Calls of Duty. It's unlike anything out there. So far I've played it for about 4 hours, and I'm still only at about 55% complete
column2: I'd say it gives great bang for the buck. Support Double Fine! Support indie! Champion the proletariat!

92,"0","Pop Comics: The Digital Age","Pop Comics: The Digital Age","","",,"

Pop Comics: The Digital Age.
by Matt Jacobs

column2: s 2011, and there is no denying that the digital content revolution is here to stay and is only going to become stronger. No matter the industry (mostly talking entertainment here), the digital age has transformed how we consume and produce content. &nbsp
column4:
ve seen the effects that the digital revolution has had on many industries throughout the years, possibly the most notable being the Film/TV industry. When I was in film school 10+ years ago now, the debate of film vs. video was always a hot topic. You had the die-hard film lovers that would throw down with the video lovers in an all out rumble over who was right. But where are the die-hards today? Most of them are shooting video...or now digital video.

I know because I was one of those die-hards. I swore I would be the last one to shoot digital, if ever. In film school I championed film and threw down against the video crowd. It&rsquo
column5: s transient. No one will take you seriously. You&rsquo
column8: if you shoot on video. Then technology began to creep up. Riddled with guilt, I bought by first digital Nikon camera. You have to know your enemy, right? With each click my resolve waned. I could now afford to shoot thousands of pictures instead of a couple rolls of negatives. I&rsquo
column9: m sure I made the money back I spent on my camera in the first week from not having to buy stock, process it and then print it. It wasn&rsquo
column10: t too long before the same was true for filmmaking.

column1: So now like many independent filmmakers I could actually afford to make a movie without having to sell my soul for production costs. Filmmakers could shoot, edit and distribute their creation all on their own. And people could even see it... online! Then digital hit the music industry. Bands can now do everything themselves too.

column2: ve now come to the final frontier: the world of publishing comics and books. This debate has been building over the past years and will likely be around for a few more. But this is what I&rsquo
column4: ve tried to help digital comics.

column1: I believe publishing companies need to rethink their strategy and stop going broke pushing out books that may or may not sell. I don&rsquo
column2: t think print books will ever fully go away, at least not in my lifetime, but when it comes to mass consumption they will be obsolete. I can see the die-hard paperback readers rolling their eyes. But when was the last time you bought a cd and didn&rsquo
column3: t rip it to your mp3 player? The fact is that digital just makes the entire experience easier, cheaper, immediate and more interactive.

column1: But the creative currency of the digital age is not money, it&rsquo
column2: s knowledge. Do you know how to build and maintain a website for your creation? Probably not. You&rsquo
column3: re too busy creating. So I built a digital publishing platform called WEvolt (www.wevolt.com). It&rsquo
column4: s code-free, easy to use, and a fully featured platform that allows creators and publishers to hit the ground running. And it was recently bought by WOWIO (www.wowio.com).

column1: But why would I go to all the trouble of building a digital platform? Why would WOWIO see the benefit of owning the platform? Here&rsquo
column2: s a list of fun and serious reasons:

column1: 1) Moving! Yeah, the silly one first, I know this shouldn&rsquo
column2: t be number 1, but I just moved again and had to hire an entire team of day laborers to move my book collection to my new place. I&rsquo
column3:
m running out of room! And now to find stuff or reference anything, I have to sort through boxes and boxes. There comes a point when this just gets ridiculous unless I have enough money to build a 10 level library with a cool sliding ladder and a butler. Or, I could just hold my entire collection on a portable hard drive.

2) Reach a new audience. A lot of people say that by putting their content for sale online they are cannibalizing their sales. People that used to buy their books will now be getting the $.99 pdf instead of buying the book. This simply isn&rsquo
column4: t true, or enough for it to really make a difference. At the moment it&rsquo
column5: s two different audiences. The people that are buying the digital version are not buying the print version. So you are really reaching a whole new group of readers that may have not even heard about your book and will give it a try for a buck. Another approach if you are really worried about this is offer stuff in print you don&rsquo
column6:
t get online and vice-versa. Integrate the two so one side feeds the other.

3) Costs. Above everything else, going with a digital distribution model first will save Creators/Indy publishers thousands, potentially hundreds of thousands of dollars. Put all that money you would have spent printing towards marketing your book. Gain an audience, and then make prints available for those that want the book. Digital gives you the ability to make sure you have an audience that will even buy your book before you print. Or do test runs of new series and see what kind of reader feedback you get before doing 3 more issues. With the quality of Print on Demand houses out these days, you can still offer prints without shelling out thousands of dollars and appease the need for your print readers.

4) Interactivity. This is one of the greatest things about the digital age when it comes to consumption of content. In a print book, other than the foreword by the creator, or attending a convention, there was no way for a reader to interact with the creator, or get inside views like DVD features do for film. There is no forum or comment system in the back of a print book, but in digital, you have the ability to interact directly with the creator. Or taking it a step further, interact with others that love or hate the content as much as you do. By giving readers this option, you are further gaining their readership and a sense of ownership and loyalty to the content.

5) Easy and Immediate. Whether you have a tablet, kindle or iPad or just a web browser, it&rsquo
column7: s just easy and fast to get new content. I don&rsquo
column8: t have to sit in traffic driving to the bookstore and then hoping the book is in stock. I just log in, search and download. For the generation that is coming up, this is what they want. They want it now! And the new generation is for the most part being raised on digital content and technology. They would rather have their content served through a screen. Once the new generation becomes the &lsquo
column11: d have to pay them to get their content in print and they will become your audience if they aren&rsquo
column12:
t already.

6) Cinematic. This one I&rsquo
column14: ll get some push back on, but I personally find comics that have been made for the digital experience vs. print have a more cinematic feel. By &lsquo
column16:
I mean the actual pages are half the size of a typical comic and made to fit on your screen or iPad. To me, this format feels much more cinematic and also keeps the reader flowing through pages. Not to mention when it comes to producing an ongoing series, the artist now has to do half the work to hit deadlines.

Anyway, that&rsquo
column17: s my take on why digital will be the dominating the industry in the coming years. I for one, am very excited about how the industry is changing. The comics business has been led by the big two with one distributor for too long and I think this type of change is exactly what this industry needs. Maybe some creators that couldn&rsquo
column18:
t afford it before will now come out of the woodwork and create the next masterpiece without having to rely on Diamond, Marvel, DC or a publishing partner. Maybe it will be you?

But now with all that said, how do you make money online?
column19:
Well more revenue models pop up everyday, and we at WOWIO are always striving to find new and inventive ways to answer that question. But... that sounds like a new blog post to me.

","

93,"0","Pop Games: Dead Island ","Pop Games: Dead Island ","","",,"

...from She Geek.

The announcement trailer went up yesterday for the zombie title Dead Island. The trailer is excellent and may have you sniffling a little bit by the end -- feels like a trailer for one of the better zombie movies to come out in the last decade. Dead Island is a survival horror game (naturally) set on a tropical island
column2: beat up the zombies, escape the island. But it's got a few elements we haven't seen before. Combat will mostly be melee
column3: very few stores of guns and ammo exist on a tropical island, after all. Weapons will degrade and eventually break. There's four-player co-op (the seamless drop-in, drop-out kind -- bless you, devs). And there's actually a semblance of compelling RPG to it. Melee combat can get repetitive, no matter how gruesomely rendered the mutilation may be -- but this is one to keep an eye on.

94,"0","Pop Interactive: Lost Art Of Killing","Pop Interactive: Lost Art Of Killing","","",,"

The Frame Rate: Space 150 Goes Interactive In ""Lost Art Of Killing""
by Crix Lee

Digital advertising agency, Space 150, has again set the bar for all to follow with the release of an interactive music video for King Fantastic's ""Lost Art of Killing"".
column2: Known for specializing in branding and strategy/product development, Space 150 doesn't mess around when it comes to capturing the public's attention. Last year, it was an interactive billboard for Forever 21 in Times Square&hellip
column3:
this year, it's the ability to render YOURSELF into a music video where you can not only witness yourself being murdered, but you get to see your own beheading.

Yep! Beheaded!!!!

After the success of the Forever 21 campaign, Space 150 once again turned to director Nicholaus Goossen (Grandma's Boy, Nick Swardson's Pretend Time) to give the video life and the horrifically awesome chance for people around the world to have a little fun.

column1:
When approached for the project, Goossen said ""My first thought was, ""Really? But then I remembered I thought the same thing when they told me their idea for the Forever 21 billboard in Times Square, and that turned out pretty cool. So I trusted that they could pull it off.""

Goossen met artist King Fantastic through DJTroublemaker (Rad Omen) and directs many of the RO videos including ""Rad Anthem"", the infamous music video featuring fast food icons doing very naughty things on a typical night in L.A.

Because he's directed several videos for artists like Rad Omen, Dirt Nasty, Good Charlotte and We The Kings, shooting the video wasn't the real challenge&hellip
column2:
it was what needed to happen in post to make it successful and really pull off the overall concept.

""We had to shoot slightly different lighting setups for the interactive shots, but that wasn't really that challenging. It's what they do with the footage and how they make it work - that's the tough part. There were certain limitations that we had to adhere to creative guidelines for, but aside from that, it was just the normal pressure of shooting a cool looking music video without a very large budget.""

Here's the non-interactive version NSFW:

column1:
To put yourself in the video is no trouble at all, merely head over to http://www.lostartofkilling.com, then click 'Make Your Own'. Then all's you gotta do is load up a pic of yourself, wait 3-5 minutes for it to render, then be ready to see yourself sliced, diced and served on a plate!

Here's a quickie of what I looked like before my ""death""
column2:
src=""http://flashinglives.com/Media/head2.jpg"" alt="""" width=""585"" height=""271"" />

Best part? You can share your 'killing' with the world on Twitter and Facebook, just keep in mind the video will be NSFW (for language and well, violence. ha).

One last thing: don't panic if it doesn't look EXACTLY like you, you'll be able to recognize yourself just fine. Just stay within the photo's parameters. I did it with 3 different pics and while I looked a little scary, I knew it was me.

Did the director make a vid? Bet your bippy, kid!

""I did make a video of myself getting beheaded. I hate the way I photograph.""

Ha. Welcome to the lost art of killing.

The Frame Rate: Palatial. Crix Approved.

","

column14: s technology has changed the game for up and coming directors to show their talent, and I want to collaborate with some of you to create some fun videos for Pop Galaxy.

column1: You really never know what an awesome viral video can do for your directing career, so I&rsquo
column2: m going to give you a few good examples.

column3: s Satacracy 88. This was an interactive sci-fi web series that I produced in 2005-2008, and went on to win a Webby Award and Emmy Award. The beauty of it was that it eventually excelled Brad to a position at Marvel Studios, and while we still await his first feature, it&rsquo
column4: s definitely coming. He executed a high level of production value, with little to no money, and on the Internet before anyone was doing web series. Look for more from Brad Winderbaum in the future.

Another awesome director is Gary Shore. He made a very slick Wolverine fan film using his skills, and he is now directing commercials for Adidas and Kodak. The fan film was on his own dime and his own time, but I can guarantee you the Adidas and Kodak shoots were great paychecks for him.
Rick Darge has been a Director of Photography for years, shooting a lot of web video content, mostly on his own. He shot Brad Winderbaum&rsquo
column2: s Satacracy 88, and numerous other web series and music videos. He also created and directed his own show, Moonshine, which saw a pretty decent amount of online views in 2008 and 2009. As of recent, he&rsquo
column3: s known for directing LCD Soundsystem&rsquo
column6: music video, which he did on his own, without LCD on board, but it&rsquo
column7: s a creative journey that caught the eye of the band, and has been made the unofficial-official music video for the song. He&rsquo
column8: s now doing commercials for Xbox video games, and Sun Chips.

column1: One of my favorite viral video director stories is &ldquo
column3: which was directed by Kevin Tancharoen, who had hoped to use it to lobby Warner Bros. to sign him on to do a reboot MK film, and it worked, he is now behind a fully funded Mortal Kombat web series with Warner Premiere. &ldquo
column5: was of his own doing, and we wouldn&rsquo

column2: s The Bannen Way trailer. Jesse teamed up with his co-writer Mark Gantt to create a &ldquo
column4: trailer for a film/web series the wanted to make, so they shot a slick trailer and put it out there, a year later Sony released &ldquo
column6: on Crackle.com, and now you get watch it on TV or buy it on DVD. That&rsquo

column2: ll get flack from some people, that it&rsquo
column3: s all being done for free, and people should be paid. Yes, I know that, I&rsquo
column4: m also one of those producer/directors who made a lot of stuff with favors and for free, but I wouldn't be where I am today had I not done that. I know you need resources, or need to have your own &ldquo
column8: and Final Cut, and some skills to use all those things, but isn&rsquo
column9: t that the point? Maybe you're not a writer, so collaborate with someone who is. Do you take yourself seriously as a director? If you do, create, make things, and make something for me.

column1: I want to see what you can do for Pop Galaxy. The slogan: This Is Pop! Music : Movies: Comics : TV : Video Games. Does that give you an idea? Can you make me a viral video for Pop Galaxy? Something quick, fastpaced, creative? Something that will drive people to want to find out what Pop Galaxy is? Send me your best treatment to adugan@wowio.com and I&rsquo
column5: m not expecting you to do this all for free, but if I like your idea, we&rsquo
column6: ll talk what we can do budgetary wise. Overall, let's just have some fun with it.&nbsp
column7: So, show me what you got, and let&rsquo
column8:
s shoot some videos!

column14: s technology has changed the game for up and coming directors to show their talent, and I want to collaborate with some of you to create some fun videos for Pop Galaxy.

column1: You really never know what an awesome viral video can do for your directing career, so I&rsquo
column2: m going to give you a few good examples.

column3: s Satacracy 88. This was an interactive sci-fi web series that I produced in 2005-2008, and went on to win a Webby Award and Emmy Award. The beauty of it was that it eventually excelled Brad to a position at Marvel Studios, and while we still await his first feature, it&rsquo
column4: s definitely coming. He executed a high level of production value, with little to no money, and on the Internet before anyone was doing web series. Look for more from Brad Winderbaum in the future.

column2: s Satacracy 88, and numerous other web series and music videos. He also created and directed his own show, Moonshine, which saw a pretty decent amount of online views in 2008 and 2009. As of recent, he&rsquo

97,"0","Pop Music: The Playlist - 5 Videos Worth Watching","Pop Music: The Playlist - 5 Videos Worth Watching","","",,"

Pop Music: The Playlist - 5 Videos Worth Watching
by Andy Dugan

It's Music Monday, so I'm gonna give you 5 music videos I think you should check out this week. I picked these purely based on how creative I thought the film maker took the song and put it into video form.

Let's start with Dr. Dre's Kush. This video was directed by Joseph Kahn and had a very large budget, but overall, I think Joseph Kahn did a great job turning this song into a video. Let's be honest, the song is about lighting it up and getting high, so that could go a lot of different directions, however, Kahn stops time, and I like that approach.

I really like Brandon Flower's solo album, and it turns out the videos have so far been just as impressive. ""Only The Young"" is a brilliant journey with fire. Yes, fire. Quite frankly, anytime you have large flames in a music video, it's a win.

I almost hate to add this next video to this list, because I really don't like Kanye West the person, but damn, the dude has some talent. The video for ""All of the Lights"" is creative, period. Kanye performs on top of a police car that has flashing lights, and at one point in the intro I wasn't sure if it was the Rocky theme or a Star Wars prologue, and this was all after the sad intro. It's definitely worth a view.
Radiohead's ""Lotus Flower"" is amazing. The song, the video, the whole thing. Watch it, love it, that's it.
Calvin Harris - You Used To Hold Me. Models dancing with Tonka Trucks? That's pretty much it, and I like it. It's an enjoyable video, and a dance anthem. Well done team Calvin Harris, well done.

98,"0","Pop Games: Marvel Vs. Capcom 3","Pop Games: Marvel Vs. Capcom 3","","",,"

Pop Games: Marvel Vs. Capcom 3
by Kate Welch (She Geek)

Marvel vs. Capcom 3 is the latest installment in a long tradition of pitting Marvel characters against characters of other canons and making them beat each other up. It does this thing very well, and looks very good doing it, bringing back some of the classic characters and adding more into the mix.

Now, for many years, I have considered myself something of an astonishing genius when it comes to fighting games. Battle Arena: Toshinden was my proving ground. I did the rounds with Street Fighters and Mortal Kombats in arcades, and I think I even got my grabby little hands on Marvel vs. Capcom 2 in the dark time when it was a rarity (now it's available for download on XBL and PSN). My tactic, which is unstoppable against an unwitting opponent, involves nothing resembling skill. Unfortunately, in Marvel vs. Capcom 3, that kind of tomfoolery didn't get me very far.

The story (which is rather thin) is spun during the opening cinematic: characters are fighting each other! The art is lovely! Morrigan's very well endowed in the chest area! Then Dormammu shows up and shoots fireballs? And then Galactus is hungry. Therefore, teams of three heroes from the universes of Marvel and Capcom must battle each other. These cinematics may not make a lick of sense, but they do look excellent -- highly detailed models with inked outlines that look like comics come alive.

Perhaps the strongest part of this game is how lovingly the characters themselves are treated. From a huge variety of disparate art backgrounds, somehow all of these characters take on a united art direction in Marvel vs. Capcom 3. The animation from both the characters and the backgrounds is enough to make you stop and stare (and get your butt handed to you while you're gawking -- not that this happened to me or anything). Not only that, but the Capcom characters' behaviors stay extremely true to their game backgrounds, and the Marvel characters behave they way they do on the page. Don't worry
column2: you'll get all your customary sass and fourth-wall-destruction from Deadpool. And the characters interact with one another depending on who's fighting! You'll get different interactions based on actual canon histories and sexual proclivities. It's a blast to try new matchups just to see how they'll talk to each other.

column1: To me, in a fighting game, the least telling thing about the game is the fighting itself. I've always been under the impression that a blind box turtle could be a fighting game ace as long as he could mash buttons fast enough. However, you've gotta love the fighting in Marvel vs. Capcom 3 -- even if you're terribly unskilled, or if you're just observing from the sidelines. They've done away with the traditional punch/kick button set, opting for light/medium/heavy attacks, two buttons for tagging your teammates, and one special attack button. In addition, there's a crazy new X-Factor element: press all four of the face buttons on your controller to get faster, stronger, heal your character, and negate chip damage (or damage you take while shielding). If all this sounds too complex, there's a new ""Simple"" mode available where combos are just one press of a button and you don't have to memorize button sequences -- but this is not a terribly rewarding mode, and definitely feels like the old folks' home version of the game.
Here's the stuff that's less than great:

Multiplayer matches are, at the time of this post, terribly broken. You'll have more luck playing through arcade mode with ""fight requests"" turned on than you will trying to find a multiplayer match -- basically, this will match you with other people in the background while you battle the AI, and it will save you a lot of frustration.

There's no official tutorial. For people whose barrier to entry into fighting games is high, this can be a deal breaker. There is a Mission mode where you can use each of the game's characters through a series of missions that teach you their combos and what sets them apart from other characters, which is very useful, but it can be extremely frustrating to progress through if you can't quite time the combos perfectly. Those of you with significant others who may not be into the idea of fighting games aren't going to be easy to sell on this one.

Marvel vs. Capcom 3 is a lovely game with a shocking amount going on under the hood. If you've got the wherewithal to learn the strengths and weaknesses of each character and form your own personal dream team, and really appreciate everything this game can offer you as a player, you're going to love it.
By the way, my ever-evolving dream team currently stands at Dante, Chun-Li, Sentinel. What's yours?
Check out the latest episode of my show on Pop Galaxy! I cover my 5 most anticipated mainstream games of 2011!

100,"1","Pop Comics: Batman in Ten Graphic Novels","Pop Comics: Batman in Ten Graphic Novels","","",,"

Pop Comics: Batman in Ten Graphic Novels
by Jason Badower
Was it Batman Begins, The Dark Knight or the amazing video game, Arkham Asylum?
I'm sure you've always known who Batman was. But I'm guessing it was one of those three that managed to get its bat-grappling hook into you.

But where to start? The streets of Gotham City are old and circuitous. Some stories are must-reads and others are forgettable. And there's the sheer quantity. Detective Comics has been going since May of 1930, and the series called Batman has been going since 1940. If you include the current eight ongoing series and countless graphic novels, collections, mini-series, maxi-series, tie-ins and features you'd probably be able to wallpaper all of Gotham in Batman comics.

Here's a list of ten Batman graphic novels that undoubtedly influenced Christopher Nolan, Christian Bale and the late Heath Ledger in Batman Begins and The Dark Knight. It also includes a couple of seminal books by the writer of Batman: Arkham Asylum. Those of you familiar with just the films might be surprised to discover that Batman is also known as ""the world's greatest detective"". It's an aspect of the character that was omitted from the films.
So forearmed with that knowledge, bat-boys and bat-girls, I present to you:

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/batmanyearone.png"" alt="""" width=""303"" height=""468"" />1. The origin of the Batman...

column1: Unlike Batman Begins, this seminal graphic novel is more about Batman&rsquo
column2: s return to Gotham after his time training abroad. Paralleling Bruce&rsquo
column3: s journey is the gripping story of Captain Jim Gordon&rsquo
column4: s life as the only honest cop in Gotham. It&rsquo
column5: s dark, smart, very grounded and unanimously on every Bat-fan's utility belt.

column2: NOTE: Selina Kyle (Catwoman) in this story appears black. In proceeding books the higher-ups at DC returned Catwoman to her original ethnicity: Caucasian. One can only surmise that some sort of Michael Jackson-like condition befell Selina.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/batmanprey.png"" alt="""" width=""320"" height=""494"" />2. Batman's oldest villain: Hugo Strange

column1: Who the hell is Hugo Strange? Originally conceived back in 1940, Professor Hugo Strange was an early re-occurring villain before the debut of the Joker. Once the clown prince of crime entered the scene, Strange was benched. So why should you care about a forgotten villain? Well, he&rsquo
column2: s not only the villain of the upcoming videogame Arkham City, but he&rsquo
column3: s also a rumored villain in The Dark Knight Rises.
column4: And you know what sets him apart? He&rsquo
column5: s the only villain that knows Batman is Bruce Wayne. PREY is very much like a sequel to Batman: Year One, so I&rsquo
column6: ve included it early on your reading list.

column1: NOTE: While the two creators are first class, this book is a product of mainstream 1990s style of storytelling which may cause it to seem a little dated compared to the others on the list.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/thekillingjoke.png"" alt="""" width=""331"" height=""496"" />3. The clown prince of crime: The Joker

column1: Written by Alan Moore (Watchmen, V for Vendetta)
What is a hero without his villain? If Batman: Year One was our Batman Begins, then The Killing Joke is our The Dark Knight. It&rsquo
column2: s a very different take than the movie and instead poses an origin to the Joker. Whether it&rsquo
column3: s true or, like the movie, simply one of the Joker&rsquo
column4: s many lies about how he got his scars, is up for debate. But the book&rsquo
column5: s insight into the Joker, Batman, and their relationship is groundbreaking, heartbreaking and rendered uncomfortably real. Of interest, the events in this story were later folded into &ldquo
column7: Batman continuity and one specific character bears very permanent wounds to this day.

column1: NOTE: Brian Bolland's vision of the Joker can still be found plastered all over t-shirts over twenty years later. Bolland hated the coloring and re-colored it himself, but in retrospect, John Higgin's bold palette really added something to the story.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/harleyquinn.png"" alt="""" width=""362"" height=""557"" />4. How do you love a psychopathic killer? Harley Quinn

column1: Written by Paul Dini (Arkham Asylum, Batman: The Animated Series)
Drawn by Yvel Guichet and Aaron Sowd
This entry is for those fans of Batman: Arkham Asylum who are eagerly awaiting this year&rsquo
column2: s release of Batman: Arkham City. Who exactly is the Joker&rsquo
column3: s main squeeze? Created just for the animated series, Harley proved herself too popular and made her way into &ldquo
column5: Batman continuity. Her start in the comics begins here. This is written by the man who would later write Arkham Asylum. You may not physically recognize her on these pages, but just imagine she decided to commandeer a nurse&rsquo
column6: s costume for the video game.

column1: NOTE: Writer/Director Kevin Smith actually named his daughter Harley Quinn Smith

column2: s art director Mark Chiarello collected an all-star team of some of the greatest comic book artists and writers to do short Batman stories. I include this not so much as a piece of continuity, but rather as the greatest summation of Batman&rsquo
column3: s adventures through popular culture. Art-wise, my favorite is issue four, but it&rsquo
column4: s only a bare nose ahead of the others because of the tremendous talent involved. This collection is pretty much the highlight reel of all of Batman&rsquo
column5: s adventures over the last 80 or so years.

column1: 6. The quintessential femme fatale anti-hero: Catwoman
CATWOMAN: THE DARK END OF THE STREET

This fantastic team examines the moral ambiguity of a person outside a system of law that's been long broken. The take home points here are to examine the shades of grey as the book examines Selina Kyle's origin and motivations. While the artwork may seem cartoony, the content is very much otherwise.
NOTE: Recent continuity has tried to theorize that Selena was only posing as a prostitute to try and relieve men of their money.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/batmanwar.png"" alt="""" width=""315"" height=""472"" />7. The Batman visualized

column1: Another great book written by the writer of Arkham Asylum (maybe you can see why he got the job?). Alex Ross and Paul Dini ground Batman visually and narratively. It&rsquo
column2: s a good story brilliantly illustrated by Alex Ross. This wonderful, oversized book makes you believe a guy could run around in a bat suit.

column1: NOTE: Alex Ross is one of the few artists who wouldn't white out the eyes of his heroes, instead employing the cinematic mask and eye paint we know so well. He also gave Batman brown eyes to visually distinguish him more from the blue-eyed Superman.
8. The effect the Batman has on his world

This is hailed as one of the quintessential tales that pulls together almost all of the Batman mythos into one story without betraying or compromising any element. Masterfully rendered, Loeb and Sale examine the entirety of the Batman&rsquo
column2: s world and the effect he has on it.

column1: NOTE: This was followed up by BATMAN: DARK VICTORY which went into greater depth on the narratives started in this storyline.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/arkhamasylum.png"" alt="""" width=""315"" height=""472"" />9. Inside Batman's mind

column1: This is my favorite on the list. I believe the reason Batman is so enduring is because of how his rogues&rsquo
column2: gallery offers unique insights into him. The Joker is the man over the edge
column3: Batman is the man on the edge. Two Face is the man who can't deal with his dual identities, Batman is just managing to deal with them. The Scarecrow abuses fear, Batman uses fear. Catwoman uses her gifts for herself, Batman uses them for others.

column1: Arkham Asylum is multi-layered. You can read it as Batman going into the asylum, or as Batman confronting his own psychosis, as a tale of Alice in Wonderland or as the passion play: the story of Jesus Christ.
NOTE: Until the Watchmen movie, Arkham Asylum had sold more graphic novels than any other. It is also a text on storytelling in most good film courses.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/darkknightreturns.png"" alt="""" width=""360"" height=""540"" />10. The end that never was

column1: And the oldest book, that started all this, comes last. If the other works are seminal, then this piece of genius from 1986 is biblical. This conjectural last Batman story redefines the Dark Knight and reinvigorated his place in our society. No character could ask for a better bookend.
NOTE: Decades later, Frank was asked to do a sequel and came up with the controversial THE DARK KNIGHT STRIKES AGAIN. A far more irreverent take, lovers of the Dark Knight should beware.

There are many great Batman stories omitted from this list. But these ten will fill you in on everything you need to know before picking up the controller for Arkham City or buying your ticket for The Dark Knight Rises. Those are the essential sights, sounds and smells of Gotham. Consider yourself warned.

So we are now beginning our descent towards Gotham City. Please place your tray tables in their upright position. Put all your canisters of fear gas, utility belts and batarangs away and do buckle your seat belts.
You're in for the bat-ride of your life.

","

Pop Comics: Batman in Ten Graphic Novels
by Jason Badower
Was it Batman Begins, The Dark Knight or the amazing video game, Arkham Asylum?
I'm sure you've always known who Batman was. But I'm guessing it was one of those three that managed to get its bat-grappling hook into you.

But where to start? The streets of Gotham City are old and circuitous. Some stories are must-reads and others are forgettable. And there's the sheer quantity. Detective Comics has been going since May of 1930, and the series called Batman has been going since 1940. If you include the current eight ongoing series and countless graphic novels, collections, mini-series, maxi-series, tie-ins and features you'd probably be able to wallpaper all of Gotham in Batman comics.

Here's a list of ten Batman graphic novels that undoubtedly influenced Christopher Nolan, Christian Bale and the late Heath Ledger in Batman Begins and The Dark Knight. It also includes a couple of seminal books by the writer of Batman: Arkham Asylum. Those of you familiar with just the films might be surprised to discover that Batman is also known as ""the world's greatest detective"". It's an aspect of the character that was omitted from the films.
So forearmed with that knowledge, bat-boys and bat-girls, I present to you:

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/batmanyearone.png"" alt="""" width=""303"" height=""468"" />1. The origin of the Batman...

column1: Unlike Batman Begins, this seminal graphic novel is more about Batman&rsquo
column2: s return to Gotham after his time training abroad. Paralleling Bruce&rsquo
column3: s journey is the gripping story of Captain Jim Gordon&rsquo
column4: s life as the only honest cop in Gotham. It&rsquo
column5: s dark, smart, very grounded and unanimously on every Bat-fan's utility belt.

column2: NOTE: Selina Kyle (Catwoman) in this story appears black. In proceeding books the higher-ups at DC returned Catwoman to her original ethnicity: Caucasian. One can only surmise that some sort of Michael Jackson-like condition befell Selina.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/batmanprey.png"" alt="""" width=""320"" height=""494"" />2. Batman's oldest villain: Hugo Strange

column1: Who the hell is Hugo Strange? Originally conceived back in 1940, Professor Hugo Strange was an early re-occurring villain before the debut of the Joker. Once the clown prince of crime entered the scene, Strange was benched. So why should you care about a forgotten villain? Well, he&rsquo
column2: s not only the villain of the upcoming videogame Arkham City, but he&rsquo
column3: s also a rumored villain in The Dark Knight Rises.
column4: And you know what sets him apart? He&rsquo
column5: s the only villain that knows Batman is Bruce Wayne. PREY is very much like a sequel to Batman: Year One, so I&rsquo
column6: ve included it early on your reading list.

column1: NOTE: While the two creators are first class, this book is a product of mainstream 1990s style of storytelling which may cause it to seem a little dated compared to the others on the list.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/thekillingjoke.png"" alt="""" width=""331"" height=""496"" />3. The clown prince of crime: The Joker

column1: Written by Alan Moore (Watchmen, V for Vendetta)
What is a hero without his villain? If Batman: Year One was our Batman Begins, then The Killing Joke is our The Dark Knight. It&rsquo
column2: s a very different take than the movie and instead poses an origin to the Joker. Whether it&rsquo
column3: s true or, like the movie, simply one of the Joker&rsquo
column4: s many lies about how he got his scars, is up for debate. But the book&rsquo
column5: s insight into the Joker, Batman, and their relationship is groundbreaking, heartbreaking and rendered uncomfortably real. Of interest, the events in this story were later folded into &ldquo
column7: Batman continuity and one specific character bears very permanent wounds to this day.

column1: NOTE: Brian Bolland's vision of the Joker can still be found plastered all over t-shirts over twenty years later. Bolland hated the coloring and re-colored it himself, but in retrospect, John Higgin's bold palette really added something to the story.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/harleyquinn.png"" alt="""" width=""362"" height=""557"" />4. How do you love a psychopathic killer? Harley Quinn

column1: Written by Paul Dini (Arkham Asylum, Batman: The Animated Series)
Drawn by Yvel Guichet and Aaron Sowd
This entry is for those fans of Batman: Arkham Asylum who are eagerly awaiting this year&rsquo
column2: s release of Batman: Arkham City. Who exactly is the Joker&rsquo
column3: s main squeeze? Created just for the animated series, Harley proved herself too popular and made her way into &ldquo
column5: Batman continuity. Her start in the comics begins here. This is written by the man who would later write Arkham Asylum. You may not physically recognize her on these pages, but just imagine she decided to commandeer a nurse&rsquo
column6: s costume for the video game.

column1: NOTE: Writer/Director Kevin Smith actually named his daughter Harley Quinn Smith

column2: s art director Mark Chiarello collected an all-star team of some of the greatest comic book artists and writers to do short Batman stories. I include this not so much as a piece of continuity, but rather as the greatest summation of Batman&rsquo
column3: s adventures through popular culture. Art-wise, my favorite is issue four, but it&rsquo
column4: s only a bare nose ahead of the others because of the tremendous talent involved. This collection is pretty much the highlight reel of all of Batman&rsquo
column5: s adventures over the last 80 or so years.

column1: 6. The quintessential femme fatale anti-hero: Catwoman
CATWOMAN: THE DARK END OF THE STREET

This fantastic team examines the moral ambiguity of a person outside a system of law that's been long broken. The take home points here are to examine the shades of grey as the book examines Selina Kyle's origin and motivations. While the artwork may seem cartoony, the content is very much otherwise.
NOTE: Recent continuity has tried to theorize that Selena was only posing as a prostitute to try and relieve men of their money.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/batmanwar.png"" alt="""" width=""315"" height=""472"" />7. The Batman visualized

column1: Another great book written by the writer of Arkham Asylum (maybe you can see why he got the job?). Alex Ross and Paul Dini ground Batman visually and narratively. It&rsquo
column2: s a good story brilliantly illustrated by Alex Ross. This wonderful, oversized book makes you believe a guy could run around in a bat suit.

column1: NOTE: Alex Ross is one of the few artists who wouldn't white out the eyes of his heroes, instead employing the cinematic mask and eye paint we know so well. He also gave Batman brown eyes to visually distinguish him more from the blue-eyed Superman.
8. The effect the Batman has on his world

This is hailed as one of the quintessential tales that pulls together almost all of the Batman mythos into one story without betraying or compromising any element. Masterfully rendered, Loeb and Sale examine the entirety of the Batman&rsquo
column2: s world and the effect he has on it.

column1: NOTE: This was followed up by BATMAN: DARK VICTORY which went into greater depth on the narratives started in this storyline.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/arkhamasylum.png"" alt="""" width=""315"" height=""472"" />9. Inside Batman's mind

column1: This is my favorite on the list. I believe the reason Batman is so enduring is because of how his rogues&rsquo
column2: gallery offers unique insights into him. The Joker is the man over the edge
column3: Batman is the man on the edge. Two Face is the man who can't deal with his dual identities, Batman is just managing to deal with them. The Scarecrow abuses fear, Batman uses fear. Catwoman uses her gifts for herself, Batman uses them for others.

column1: Arkham Asylum is multi-layered. You can read it as Batman going into the asylum, or as Batman confronting his own psychosis, as a tale of Alice in Wonderland or as the passion play: the story of Jesus Christ.
NOTE: Until the Watchmen movie, Arkham Asylum had sold more graphic novels than any other. It is also a text on storytelling in most good film courses.

column3: src=""http://www.flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/darkknightreturns.png"" alt="""" width=""360"" height=""540"" />10. The end that never was

column1: And the oldest book, that started all this, comes last. If the other works are seminal, then this piece of genius from 1986 is biblical. This conjectural last Batman story redefines the Dark Knight and reinvigorated his place in our society. No character could ask for a better bookend.
NOTE: Decades later, Frank was asked to do a sequel and came up with the controversial THE DARK KNIGHT STRIKES AGAIN. A far more irreverent take, lovers of the Dark Knight should beware.

There are many great Batman stories omitted from this list. But these ten will fill you in on everything you need to know before picking up the controller for Arkham City or buying your ticket for The Dark Knight Rises. Those are the essential sights, sounds and smells of Gotham. Consider yourself warned.

So we are now beginning our descent towards Gotham City. Please place your tray tables in their upright position. Put all your canisters of fear gas, utility belts and batarangs away and do buckle your seat belts.
You're in for the bat-ride of your life.

by Jason Badower

102,"0","Pop Film: Exit Through The Oscar Gift Shop","Pop Film: Exit Through The Oscar Gift Shop","","",,"

Pop Film: Exit Through The Oscar Gift Shop...
by Crix Lee

For most Angelenos, this Sunday means ""avoid Hollywood and Highland,"" but for the rest of the world it means one thing and one thing only: The Oscars.
column2:
src=""http://flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/banksygirl.jpg"" alt="""" width=""415"" height=""625"" />

The most buzzed about story from the Academy isn't about the dubious choice of hosts or the proposed changes to this year's telecasts (no more music montages, thanks) but rather their decision to deny mystery street artist Banksy's
column3:
request to attend in disguise (in order to protect his anonymity) to accept the award for Best Documentary should his film, ""Exit Through The Gift Shop"" win. In fact, we've learned that the elusive graffiti artist won't be attending the ceremony at ALL.

First of all, FAIL for allowing trainwrecks like Gary Busey to attend year after year. (Once nominated, you've got an automatic invite for life) Second, FAIL for denying a NOMINEE an invitation, period.

What the Academy is basically saying is ""We LOVE everything about your movie but we don't 'do' fun, so your director (who we think is FANTASTIC, btw) can't come. We're a SERIOUS awards ceremony&hellip
column4:
Most of all, FAIL for missing a GOLDEN opportunity to get a much needed shot in the arm ratings wise. I can understand not allowing Banksy to show up to the Kodak Theatre in disguise as it would pose some potential security risks, but as he had never demanded to be in disguise on the red carpet, what would've been the harm to have him escorted through the back door ""Goodfellas"" style and hide him in a room backstage with a security detail hired by the Academy but PAID for by the film's producers?

The Academy's executive director, Bruce Davis, said they were forced to turn down the request due to the 'fears imposters would attempt to gatecrash the ceremony.""

When Banksy was nominated, he said: ""This is a big surprise. I don't agree with the concept of award ceremonies, but I'm prepared to make an exception for the ones I'm nominated for. The last time there was a naked man covered in gold paint in my house, it was me.""

Rumor has it that Banksy's been running around L.A. these past few days leaving his mark (pun intended) on random walls. And thanks to those in the know, armed with smart-phones and Twitter - the rest of the world is privy to the 'here today gone tomorrow' works of the world's best kept secret.
column5:
src=""http://flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/banksycharlie.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""382"" />

If you're not into watching the Academy Awards, do yourself a favor - fire up the ol' Netflix Instant Queue, find 'Exit Through The Gift Shop"". It beats sitting through a bunch of goofy bits read awkwardly by actors through the magic of a teleprompter.

Here's a wee smackerel.

column1:
The Frame Rate:
Banksy/Exit Through The Gift Shop: Crix Approved.
The Academy Awards: FAIL.

Full disclosure: I hope True Grit wins everything they're nominated for. Team Coen Bros.
column2:
src=""http://flashinglives.com/popgalaxy/banksydog.jpg"" alt="""" width=""455"" height=""271"" />

More disclosure: I am Keyser So- I mean, I am Banksy. BOOM.

104,"0","Pop Music: The Playlist - Give These Videos An Oscar","Pop Music: The Playlist - Give These Videos An Oscar","","",,"

Pop Music: The Playlist - Give These Videos An Oscar
by Andy Dugan

The Oscars were last night... and there were 10 nominees, which is a new trend for the show. I personally liked it better when they narrowed it down to 5. That being said, forget the Oscars, I'm going to give you 5 music videos from 2010 that could win an Oscar, if there were such a thing for music videos.

Let's start with the celebrity driven video, ""Gorillaz: Stylo."" This video stars Bruce Willis, and none other than the Gorillaz themselves in classic revved up cars that would make Vin Diesel smile. It's a fun filled ride with a twisted ending.

Who doesn't like cat videos? I'm sorry, but it seems to never get old on YouTube, and with this music video by ""Holy Fuck"", it's still not old. The song, ""Red Lights"" could probably be interpreted into a lot of different ideas, but I'm pretty happy about the direction this video went, with the cats and all...

As always, you've got to have a really dark glimpse into something with nominees, and I'm going to let M.I.A.'s ""Born Free"" get this nod. It's violent, and well done, and really, what more could you want from M.I.A. besides this video?

Did everyone already forget about the Academy Award winning film ""Walk The Line""? I'm going to bring Johnny Cash back to the discussion, and it's because of the video ""Ain't No Grave"" which is always in a changing pattern. This version of it is from 9/30/2010 - and it's amazing. I'm a big fan.

...and finally, my favorite video of 2010 involves Star Wars. Yes... Star Wars. This video basically takes us through the trilogy, but is giving all the credit to time spent on Tatooine. Check out Jeremy Messersmith's ""Tatooine.""

So that's it, my favorite videos of 2010, feel free to share your picks below.

105,"0","Pop Games: What to Expect from GDC 2011","Pop Games: What to Expect from GDC 2011","","",,"

Pop Games: What to Expect from GDC 2011
by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)

This week marks the 25th Game Developers Conference (GDC) at the Moscone Convention Center in San Francisco, CA. GDC is a gathering of development professionals from around the world, coming together for five days of seminars, lectures, panels, discussions, award presentations, networking opportunities, and a huge expo hall.

GDC has been the site of many exciting revelations and announcement in years past. This year holds a lot of potential for huge announcements, as it's the first major games conference of 2011. Here are some highlights of what we'll see this year, as well as what we can fiercely hope to see.
column2:
src=""http://www.gdconf.com/img/logos/download/GDC2011_logo_25th_color.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""212"" />

- Satoru Iwata, President of Nintendo, gives his keynote address about the history and future of the games industry on Wednesday at 9AM. While that might not be the most interesting-sounding talk in the world, Iwata would be the one who'd be making any exciting announcements in store for Nintendo for 2011 (Skyward Sword trailer, anyone?).
column3:
src=""http://www.infendo.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/Skyward-Sword.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""300"" />

- Epic Games will be demoing the next generation of Unreal Engine to a select audience of professionals as well as a few members of the media. This will give us a glimpse into what the future of graphics might look like for games -- and rumor has it that we'll be impressed with what we see. Epic is also supposedly announcing a new IP this year, which will add to their impressive lineup of Bulletstorm and the Gears of War series.

- The Game Developers Choice Awards, hosted by TIM SCHAFER! Peter Molyneux, head of Lionhead Studios and creator of the Fable series, will be receiving a lifetime achievement award. They will award the prestigious GDCA Game of the Year award. The frontrunner nominee at present is the indie hit game Limbo, which in my opinion is highly deserving. It's going up against major studio titles like Red Dead Redemption, Assassin's Creed Brotherhood, and Mass Effect 2 -- so it'll be an exciting reveal.

- Sony's lecture on the new NGP handheld device. This is the first time Sony will be talking officially about the device since it was revealed in January of this year.
column4:
src=""http://mobilenews.blog.com/files/2011/01/Sony-PSP2-NGP-21.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""361"" />

- Batman: Arkham City gameplay footage. This is on a lot of people's wishlists
column5:
at a recent Microsoft conference, some hands-on demos were available to a select few people. I suspect this may be on the expo floor at GDC, maybe with a publicly playable demo. If so, I'll watch the demo footage from home, and my lower lip will tremble mightily.

Be sure to follow me on Twitter.com/shegeekshow for all the latest news coming out of GDC 2011!

column1: Here is the latest episode of the She Geek Show!!!

column2:
Pop Comics: Horrified
by Matt Jacobs

column9: >So  I was sitting around pondering that state of things as I often do, and  my mind wandered to horror comics. I was wondering with the almost  spam-like releases of new horror movies why we don&rsquo

108,"0","Pop Film: Rango","Pop Film: Rango","","",,"

The Frame Rate: Rango
by Crix Lee

Directed by Gore Verbinski.
Starring: Johnny Depp, Isla Fisher, Ned Beatty, Bill Nighy

While at the 2011 Game Developer's Conference, I was invited to see a demo for the upcoming EA game, Rango, based on the film of the same name starring Johnny Depp. The cherry on top? A private screening of the film!
Johnny Depp and Pirates Of The Caribbean director Gore Verbinski reunite once again to tell this animated tale of a chameleon with a bit of an overactive imagination and a need to belong somewhere.

Rango (Depp) is a chameleon who likes to write/stage/direct his own plays with the only two friends he's ever known - a headless, one armed doll and a wind up fish (popular underground toy, Mr Timms). Due to a very ODD chain of circumstances, Rango finds himself in the town of Dirt
column2: where water is used as currency, the townsfolk are down on their luck and the Mayor (Ned Beatty) is of questionable virtue. Made Sheriff in a town where the cemetery is filled with others who held the title for a short time (one stone read ""Tuesday to Saturday""), Rango has to look inside himself to save the town and in turn, figure out who he REALLY is.

column1: <param name=""wmode"" value=""transparent"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""520"" height=""242"" src=""http://www.paramount.com/webmaster/player/paramount_epk.php"" flashvars=""cid=56d1b2d59bf724cf5d97885535e7ce310ffdc927"" wmode=""transparent"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>
What makes this latest outing from Nickelodeon so special is that they not only teamed up with Industrial Light &
column2: Magic to make some OUTSTANDING landscapes and lifelike animals, Verbinski and his team worked to give each character depth and emotion.&nbsp
column3: ILM's Tim Alexander said that during recording, the actors spent a great deal of time at Universal and were given costumes and sets to help them really get the feel of the Old (and Wild) West.

column1: Yes, it's a film geared and marketed toward children but there's a STRONG possibility that adults will love this movie MORE than their kids.
column2: There are some VERY recognizable pop culture 'easter egg' characters that when they appeared on screen, people (myself included) lost our minds with laughter and in one instance, elicited a ton of ""NO WAY"" and ""OMG"" responses followed by a round of applause once the scene was over. What makes this a big deal is that there was still 20 minutes to go.

column1: The animation is so meticulous and so crisp that there were times I was convinced that there HAD to be some live action and animatronic animals mixed in.
column2: I must've said ""Wow"" at least 20 times during the film.

column1: It's been a VERY long time since an animated film has made me cry and Rango is the first film in AGES where I not only found myself emotionally invested in EVERY character but I actually cried (quietly, of course). It's a testament to Depp because I was VERY skeptical that he could hold up a film where he couldn't rely on snarky looks or doing ""Jack Sparrow-like"" behaviors. I was so wrong. Depp has restored my faith in his acting abilities because after the POTC series, I wasn't so sure he could do or be anything else.

Other highlights include a roving quartet of Mariachi owls who serve as your humble, singing narrators that made me wonder if the film's writers (Verbinski, John Logan, James Byrkit) love the films Blazing Saddles and Cat Ballou as much as I do.
At film's end, the entire audience clapped and cheered&hellip
column2: for a media screening, that's a pretty rare occurrence.&nbsp
column3: We're a pretty jaded bunch, lol.&nbsp

column1: The Frame Rate: OUTSTANDING and worth seeing more than once. I'm definitely going again! Crix Approved Infinity +1.

Rango is rated PG and opens nationwide March 4th

Pop Music: Herd Rock Band Bracket
by Andy Dugan

I spend my mornings on the PCH driving to the Pop Galaxy office, and sometimes I listen to sports talk radio. This morning, on ESPN Radio, they announced the ""Herd Rock Band Bracket"", where you can vote for the best rock band of all time. It's set up in a bracket, the same way as the NCAA Tournament.
They have ""The Rolling Stones"" vs. ""Blink 182"" and ""Nirvana"" against ""Foreigner"" so I'm thinking some of these are no-brainers. That being said,
column2: match=108248#top"" target=""_blank"">go there, check it out, and cast your vote... I'm predicting that ""The Doors"" end up taking the whole thing.

column1: ""Colin Cowherd and ""The Herd with Colin Cowherd"" staff need your help crowning the best rock band.

We've got 64 bands seeded in the bracket and your votes will crown a winner at the end of the month. Vote at http://es.pn/gv8ouf and sound off on the bracket in the comments or by e-mailing us at theherd@espnradio.com.""
