114,"0","Pop Games: 5 Games That Defined My Youth","Pop Games: 5 Games That Defined My Youth","","",,"

Pop Games: 5 Games That Defined My Youth
by Kate Welch (She Geek)

These days, the announcement of an anticipated sequel to a successful franchise or (less frequently) an inventive new IP is followed almost immediately with a proclamation of how breathtaking the new graphics system will be, how realistic the facial animation, how lush the environment. Technology is moving forward in leaps and bounds in this regard, and it's terribly exciting to see it unfold. Remember how the first Tomb Raider looked? That was only fifteen years ago. Kinda mind-blowing, right? Well, it is to me. You kids today, with your hippity hoppity.

I'm personally of the opinion that the storylines and interactivity of games have taken a backseat to the power of modern graphics engines. There are exceptions, of course, and many games are bringing terrific writing to bear as well, but sacrifices get made for the sake of visual effects. Why, back in my day, story and creativity were king, I tell you!
Presented here are the top five games (of many) that completely enraptured me as a kid, and which I'd gladly pick up and play even today.

5. The Incredible Machine
Something in the water at Sierra just spoke to me in the '90s. Between this series and the Castle of Dr. Brain, I credit Sierra with a large part of my present genius. For those of you who never played this game, the objective was to use a given set of objects and pieces to create a Rube Goldberg device and accomplish an objective. Objects ranged from the obvious (electric fans, basketballs, trampolines) to the bizarre (cats, mice, people). There have been many games like this since then, and every time I run across one, I always want to pour one out for the Incredible Machine.

4. Super Bomberman
Before you ask: yeah, I own the modern Bomberman game for the 360 and all the expansion packs for it. There was and remains almost no party game more fun than Bomberman. There, I said it and I meant it. For the uninitiated, Super Bomberman is a top-down game where you and three friends/CPU players control four little multicolored dudes running around dropping bombs. You have to clear your way out of your particular corner and pick up powerups along the way to annihilate your three friends, who are doing the same thing. Something about this game is utterly hypnotizing to the young mind, and it's a game that is actually based on skill -- you will get better the more you play. And the first time you play, you will get decimated. Just the way it goes.

3. King's Quest VI: Heir Today, Gone Tomorrow
Again with the Sierra love. King's Quest VI is usually heralded as the best one in the series -- I've since played a few of the others, and I have to agree. In an era where point-and-click adventure games were in their heyday, King's Quest VI really stood above the pack. The storyline was engaging and wickedly clever
column3: and the puzzles, though sometimes a little bizarre, were never totally impossible. AGD Interactive has started remaking the King's Quest games with updated assets. King's Quest III is their latest offering
column4: if you've never experienced King's Quest, do yourself a favor and check it out.  <strong>&nbsp

column1:
2. Creatures
I still don't quite know how popular this game was to the outside world, but I was completely consumed by it. Creatures was an ""artificial life"" game. You hatched cute little bug-eyed mammalian critters called Norns, who lived in a donut-shaped world called Albia. Norns were incredibly cute, trusting, and naive, which, if left untended, led them almost always into certain doom. From their infancy, you taught them words (which you could change to any language or nonsense if you chose), praised them, punished them, and so raised them to live in a perilous world. The coolest part of this game was that your Norns had a genetic structure: you could breed adult Norns for certain traits, which would become extremely pronounced down through their offspring. Later expansions had extremely advanced genetic and neural panels for the obsessive Norn breeders like myself. I've played Spore and Black &
column2: White and plenty of the Sim games since my experience with Creatures, but nothing comes close to that bizarre connection I had to my little Norns. Sniffle.

column1:
1. Star Wars: TIE Fighter
As far as single player games go, there's never been anything that has held my attention so fiercely as TIE Fighter did, playthrough after playthrough. It's probably fairly obvious from the title, but TIE Fighter was a space combat/flight simulator game. You start as a young TIE fighter pilot at the bottom of the Empire's ranks, hunting down pirates, traitorous Imperials, and of course stymying the occasional Rebel attack. In addition to advancing through the Imperial ranks, you can optionally complete secondary objectives which earn you an increasingly respected position in the Emperor's Inner Circle, a secret society that gets a sweet tribal tattoo.
(I'm using the word ""sweet"" here pretty loosely. Hey, it glows under blacklight, that's pretty awesome, right?!)

Sadly, this game is ridiculously hard to track down, and I think the one time I was able to find it, it didn't run at all on modern Windows. Someday I'm gonna wake up and they'll have rereleased it, just for me. I hope Emperor Palpatine will forgive my absence.

- Kate

","

Pop Games: 5 Games That Defined My Youth
by Kate Welch (She Geek)

These days, the announcement of an anticipated sequel to a successful franchise or (less frequently) an inventive new IP is followed almost immediately with a proclamation of how breathtaking the new graphics system will be, how realistic the facial animation, how lush the environment. Technology is moving forward in leaps and bounds in this regard, and it's terribly exciting to see it unfold. Remember how the first Tomb Raider looked? That was only fifteen years ago. Kinda mind-blowing, right? Well, it is to me. You kids today, with your hippity hoppity.

I'm personally of the opinion that the storylines and interactivity of games have taken a backseat to the power of modern graphics engines. There are exceptions, of course, and many games are bringing terrific writing to bear as well, but sacrifices get made for the sake of visual effects. Why, back in my day, story and creativity were king, I tell you!
Presented here are the top five games (of many) that completely enraptured me as a kid, and which I'd gladly pick up and play even today.

5. The Incredible Machine
Something in the water at Sierra just spoke to me in the '90s. Between this series and the Castle of Dr. Brain, I credit Sierra with a large part of my present genius. For those of you who never played this game, the objective was to use a given set of objects and pieces to create a Rube Goldberg device and accomplish an objective. Objects ranged from the obvious (electric fans, basketballs, trampolines) to the bizarre (cats, mice, people). There have been many games like this since then, and every time I run across one, I always want to pour one out for the Incredible Machine.

4. Super Bomberman
Before you ask: yeah, I own the modern Bomberman game for the 360 and all the expansion packs for it. There was and remains almost no party game more fun than Bomberman. There, I said it and I meant it. For the uninitiated, Super Bomberman is a top-down game where you and three friends/CPU players control four little multicolored dudes running around dropping bombs. You have to clear your way out of your particular corner and pick up powerups along the way to annihilate your three friends, who are doing the same thing. Something about this game is utterly hypnotizing to the young mind, and it's a game that is actually based on skill -- you will get better the more you play. And the first time you play, you will get decimated. Just the way it goes.

3. King's Quest VI: Heir Today, Gone Tomorrow
Again with the Sierra love. King's Quest VI is usually heralded as the best one in the series -- I've since played a few of the others, and I have to agree. In an era where point-and-click adventure games were in their heyday, King's Quest VI really stood above the pack. The storyline was engaging and wickedly clever
column3: and the puzzles, though sometimes a little bizarre, were never totally impossible. AGD Interactive has started remaking the King's Quest games with updated assets. King's Quest III is their latest offering
column4: if you've never experienced King's Quest, do yourself a favor and check it out.  <strong>&nbsp

Pop Music: The Playlist - Superhero Music Videos
by Andy Dugan

In the mid-90's, about the time that Joel Schumacher decided to destroy the Batman movie franchise, he also got a trend going with Superhero movies, this trend was to go big with the Soundtrack, and produce music videos on the set. Today, we're going to check out the 5 best (or worst - depending on how you look at it) superhero movie music videos.

Let's start with the obvious - SEAL's ""Kiss From A Rose"" - if this video doesn't get you in the romantic mood, than what would?! You really can't ask for more ""cheese"" from a song, or a music video, and this ""Batman Forever"" tie-in delivers!
Shaquille O'Neal Feat Ice Cube, B-Real, Peter Gunz &
column2: KRS One - Men Of Steel. Should I even say more? This track and music video is from Shaq's movie ""Steel"" - which was a huge failure, but the soundtrack didn't do bad, and it turns out, Shaq is a Platinum Selling artist! Yeah... who knew.

column1: I really wasn't sure what was better/worse... R. Kelly's ""Gotham City"" or Jewel's ""Foolish Games"" - both videos are a disaster, or brilliant, but after watching R. Kelly's again, I couldn't help but put it in this list. Turns out, it's a really hard video to find the original version of, so it's being hosted out of Japan!

Another brilliant ballad is ""Hero"" which is a duet by Nickelback's Chad Kroeger and Saliva's Josey Scott - this was the theme song to the first Spider-Man film. I'm curious what the reboot is going to bring us, but until then, we have this 'masterpiece'.

Dare Devil's ""Bring Me Back To Life"" from Evanescense has also made my list. For some reason, the superhero movie genre gets a lot of really emotional songs, and Dare Devil was probably victim to the worst soundtrack in superhero history.

Pop Games: Why Mortal Kombat was the Surprise Hit of GDC: It's Awesome
By Ben Kuchera of

A game writer at a large convention will occasionally book a variety of meetings with a company just to be polite. Such was the case with the latest Mortal Kombat game. I agreed to the meeting only because of my interest in Batman: Arkham City, as both games are being published by Warner Bros. In such cases, writers go into the meeting, dutifully play for a few minutes while listening to the pitch, and never think of the game again. Yes, it sounds dishonest, but it's also a defense mechanism against being overwhelmed.

Here's the problem with that plan: Mortal Kombat is very good. The 15-minute meeting I had with the game turned into an hour of simply playing it and talking about it, concluding with the PR folks prying the arcade stick out of my hands. Here's why I fell in love with this bloody return to form.

s artwork is nothing short of epic, and seminal. You can see from these pages the level of detail and intensity he places into his work. If this book had a visual production budget, it would be in the hundreds of millions.

117,"0","Pop Film: Happily Ever After Or Out Of Ideas?","Pop Film: Happily Ever After Or Out Of Ideas?","","",,"

Pop Film: Happily Ever After Or Out Of Ideas?
The Frame Rate by Crix Lee
Once upon a time, fairy tale movies were all the rage and we couldn't get enough of them&hellip
column2: then we grew up. In the last year, we've seen some fairly strange decisions come out of Hollywood (INCLUDING making U.S. versions of foreign films that had BARELY BEEN OUT A YEAR) and now we're once again looking at a resurgence of a genre that really should've been left to the two people that did it best: Disney and HBO (Fairy Tale Theatre).

column1: Fairy tale films are being sliced, diced, revamped and remade into live action ho-hum fare that makes me wonder if Hollywood has truly run out of ideas. I mean, there are SO many versions of Jack and The Beanstalk that I could LITERALLY construct a beanstalk out of the miles of film devoted strictly to this story.

Beastly - ""A modern-day take on the ""Beauty and the Beast"" tale where a New York teen is transformed into a hideous monster in order to find true love."" is an absolute JOKE to me. I have NO clue why people consider THIS ugly (insert image) when I see dudes like this EVERY DAY in Los Angeles who have ZERO problems getting laid. The 'Beast' in this film looks like a weak version of the Tattooed Man from the Jim Rose Circus Sideshow. It was nice to see Mary-Kate Olsen doing something without Ashley but this movie SUCKS and apparently the SMART kids skipped this superficial P.O.S. and opted to see Rango instead, which both opened March 4th weekend. If you REALLY want to see this movie (or take your significant other as a form of punishment), I'd go soon because I don't see this movie staying in theaters past next weekend.

<param name=""allowFullScreen"" value=""true"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""288"" src=""http://www.hulu.com/embed/SgEz-s8lBkdc_lrdjlSkrw"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>
Red Riding Hood - From the teasers and trailers, I honestly have NO clue what is going on in this film OTHER than it stars Amanda Seyfried and Gary Oldman
column2: is directed by Catherine Hardwicke (Twilight) and opens March 11th.&nbsp
column3: EVERY TIME I see the trailer, my brain starts to trail off like the SNL version of Miley Cyrus, ""So is she like in love with a guy who's also a werewolf or does she know he's a werewolf or is he a bad guy who killed someone she loved or is he her one true friend and the only one who can set him free or what and where does Grandma play into all this?"" (taken from ACTUAL phone conversation with my EIC at Pop Galaxy last night).

column1: <param name=""allowFullScreen"" value=""true"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""288"" src=""http://www.hulu.com/embed/xiZ7opT4fw9_fDUnxWqNlA"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>
So of course, your humble narrator HAD to consult the 'bible' a.k.a. IMDB
column2: here's the SHORT version: ""Set in a medieval village that is haunted by a werewolf, a young girl falls for an orphaned woodcutter, much to her family's displeasure.""

column1: Okay, FIRST of all, in EVERY version of Red Riding Hood that I KNOW, the woodcutter has ALWAYS been portrayed as an older man who BEFRIENDS Red and subsequently saves her and Grandma from the Big Bad Wolf. NEVER once have I seen a version where there's Romeo and Juliet action going and I really STILL have no desire to see that. Also, Red's name has ALWAYS been ""RED"" - NOW I'm supposed to call her 'Valerie'?! WHATEVER.

<param name=""allowFullScreen"" value=""true"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""288"" src=""http://www.hulu.com/embed/KpUpERgcXjxbUmvhttxR8Q"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>
But considering who's directing it, NOT too surprised to see forbidden love mixed with a werewolf's existence AND 'a werewolf killed my sister' theme (BOO, btw) in this so-called 'adult re-telling'.
Not even Gary Oldman will get me to see this film. PASS.
***As there are currently TWO Snow White films in production and at this point I have little to no desire to see either one, here's why.

The Brothers Grimm: Snow White - Scheduled for release in 2012, the imdb blurb says it's 'A dark twist on the classic fairy tale, in which Snow White and the seven dwarfs look to reclaim their destroyed kingdom.'
column3: Okay, sounds great in theory but then I see who's directing and who's signed on so far and now I'm not so sure. Directed by Tarsem Singh, best known for R.E.M.'s 'Losing My Religion' video DOES have some visually impressive films like 'The Cell' under his belt so the frosted, fun side of me has NO doubt the film will be great to look at but the snarky, wheat side will wonder when some Michael Stipe-type of icon will pop up in the film. Whoever is playing Snow White has not been confirmed but Julia Roberts as The Evil Queen? GIVE ME A BREAK. I'd go see it if ERIC Roberts played The Evil Queen, at least THEN it would be something worth talking about.

column1: Snow White and The Huntsman - Also scheduled for release in 2012 (hey, maybe you two should've talked), THIS film HAS their Snow White&hellip
column2: are you ready for this? It's Kristen Stewart. That's right Kristen 'Hey, I'm really not that talented, have ONE expression and am completely monotone yet have managed to make a career out of it so I better make while the getting's good' Stewart has confirmed that she is indeed Snow White for this latest go-round. The problem? Snow White is extroverted, beauty, grace, charm and PURE innocence. Kristen Stewart is introverted, awkward, boring, dark, can't act for s**t and I grow increasingly tired of her one-note performances. Matter of fact, a couple years ago I started the 'Kristen Stewart Drinking Game' where you take a drink every time she messes with her hair on screen.

column1: Other problems? The film is CALLED Snow White which means Snow White should be the main focus but with the casting of Academy Award winner Charlize Theron as The Evil Queen and Academy Award nominee Viggo Mortensen as The Huntsman, I'm pretty sure Snow will be taking a back seat to these two powerhouses. Because unless the RIDICULOUSLY good looking Theron 'uglies up' like she did in 'Monster', there's NO WAY anyone will even remember Stewart's name when the film is over.

column2: ? I really hope that's a working title because right now it sounds like a 50's kitch music act like Sam The Sham And The Pharaohs (Wooly Bully, you heathens).

column1: While I am in TOTAL agreement with the age appropriate casting of Mortensen as The Huntsman, I am wondering WHY he's a huntsman and NOT a woodsman&hellip
column2: but who cares? Viggo is much like a groundhog now, only popping up once a year to make a film so in THAT vein&hellip
column3: I'm a LITTLE curious to see what he's going to do with it. I just wish he was coming to the surface to somehow be in The Hobbit but I'll settle for this. Did I also mention that I have a wicked crush on him? Okay, this one will go in the 'maybe' pile.

column1: **AND just like Snow White, there's ALSO two Hansel and Gretel films slated to come out over the next 12 months.

Hansel and Gretel in 3D - Is still in development and I hope it stays there. They don't even have a prelim casting and are boasting it will be an 'action packed visual FX filled version of the classic tale' with the tagline ""If you end up lost in the woods&hellip
column2: you may just find yourself"". Neat, is that the day the Teddy Bears have their picnic? Because otherwise, PASS.

column1: Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters - In this film, we catch up with brother/sister team Hansel and Gretel 15 years after the famous ""Gingerbread House"" incident, who've now become bounty hunters who hunt witches.
Why this particular film of all the bunch could work: it's co-written/directed by Tommy Wirkola (Dead Snow)
column2: produced by Will Ferrell, Chris Henchy, Adam McKay, Kevin J. Messick
column3: and stars Jeremy Renner, Gemma Arterton, Famke Janssen AND Peter Stormare.

column1: This film is being billed as a horror comedy and I feel that it's the PERFECT way to go
column2: it's not taking itself seriously and doesn't expect you as an audience member to, either. Jeremy Renner has come a LOOOOOONG way from his 7-11 'Slurpee Brain Freeze' commercial (remember the one where you hear a guy off camera alternately yelling in pain and sighing in pleasure while his dog's ears go up and down in curiosity? YEP!) And has made his bones in this industry as a solid go to guy when it comes to making slightly tweaked out characters accessible. With films like 'Dahmer' and 'The Hurt Locker' under his belt, I can't WAIT to see what he does in this one!!

column1: NOT a fan of Gemma Arterton (Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time) BUT knowing Famke Janssen and Peter Stormare (Fargo, The Big Lebowski) are there to round out the principal cast makes me kind of giddy. Stormare can go from scary as EFF to funny as EFF in nothing FLAT and I LOVE him for it!!!

What this film sounds like it'll be to me is Dead Snow meets Buffy The Vampire Slayer (FILM VERSION, heathens) with HILARIOUSLY gory results. Paramount's been pretty consistent with horror as of late and since it'll be in 3-D, I'll wager 50 bucks that it'll be 'Piranha 3-D' campy levels of gore and fun - which is the way it should be.

column2: G: WH is slated for release in 2012 and I am SO READY! Put this one in the ""ABSOLUTELY I'm seeing this pile!""

column1: Beastly - WHATEVER. Superficial tripe aimed at teenagers who opted to either stay in for a Teen Mom 2 marathon or saw the BETTER film that weekend: Rango.
Snow White and The Huntsman - Meh (but I love me some Viggo, so I'll probably go).
Hansel and Gretel in 3-D - GET OUTTA MY FACE BEFORE I KILL YOU.
Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters - Jeremy Renner, I seriously love you. Please make out with me. I mean, uh, SOOOOO Crix Approved.
So some people are getting their wish - Zombies are out and Fairy Tales are in&hellip
column2: but bigger doesn't necessarily mean better, so be careful what you wish for.

column1: P.S. the BEST version of Jack and The Beanstalk is the 1974 animated version starring Jack Grimes as the Giant (who we learn is named 'Tulip'). This film STILL scares the absolute hell out of me and is unlike ANY animated fairy tale film EVER. (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0074705/)

","

Pop Film: Happily Ever After Or Out Of Ideas?
The Frame Rate by Crix Lee
Once upon a time, fairy tale movies were all the rage and we couldn't get enough of them&hellip
column2: then we grew up. In the last year, we've seen some fairly strange decisions come out of Hollywood (INCLUDING making U.S. versions of foreign films that had BARELY BEEN OUT A YEAR) and now we're once again looking at a resurgence of a genre that really should've been left to the two people that did it best: Disney and HBO (Fairy Tale Theatre).

column1: Fairy tale films are being sliced, diced, revamped and remade into live action ho-hum fare that makes me wonder if Hollywood has truly run out of ideas. I mean, there are SO many versions of Jack and The Beanstalk that I could LITERALLY construct a beanstalk out of the miles of film devoted strictly to this story.

Beastly - ""A modern-day take on the ""Beauty and the Beast"" tale where a New York teen is transformed into a hideous monster in order to find true love."" is an absolute JOKE to me. I have NO clue why people consider THIS ugly (insert image) when I see dudes like this EVERY DAY in Los Angeles who have ZERO problems getting laid. The 'Beast' in this film looks like a weak version of the Tattooed Man from the Jim Rose Circus Sideshow. It was nice to see Mary-Kate Olsen doing something without Ashley but this movie SUCKS and apparently the SMART kids skipped this superficial P.O.S. and opted to see Rango instead, which both opened March 4th weekend. If you REALLY want to see this movie (or take your significant other as a form of punishment), I'd go soon because I don't see this movie staying in theaters past next weekend.

<param name=""allowFullScreen"" value=""true"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""288"" src=""http://www.hulu.com/embed/SgEz-s8lBkdc_lrdjlSkrw"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>
Red Riding Hood - From the teasers and trailers, I honestly have NO clue what is going on in this film OTHER than it stars Amanda Seyfried and Gary Oldman
column2: is directed by Catherine Hardwicke (Twilight) and opens March 11th.&nbsp
column3: EVERY TIME I see the trailer, my brain starts to trail off like the SNL version of Miley Cyrus, ""So is she like in love with a guy who's also a werewolf or does she know he's a werewolf or is he a bad guy who killed someone she loved or is he her one true friend and the only one who can set him free or what and where does Grandma play into all this?"" (taken from ACTUAL phone conversation with my EIC at Pop Galaxy last night).

column1: <param name=""allowFullScreen"" value=""true"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""288"" src=""http://www.hulu.com/embed/xiZ7opT4fw9_fDUnxWqNlA"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>
So of course, your humble narrator HAD to consult the 'bible' a.k.a. IMDB
column2: here's the SHORT version: ""Set in a medieval village that is haunted by a werewolf, a young girl falls for an orphaned woodcutter, much to her family's displeasure.""

column1: Okay, FIRST of all, in EVERY version of Red Riding Hood that I KNOW, the woodcutter has ALWAYS been portrayed as an older man who BEFRIENDS Red and subsequently saves her and Grandma from the Big Bad Wolf. NEVER once have I seen a version where there's Romeo and Juliet action going and I really STILL have no desire to see that. Also, Red's name has ALWAYS been ""RED"" - NOW I'm supposed to call her 'Valerie'?! WHATEVER.

<param name=""allowFullScreen"" value=""true"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""288"" src=""http://www.hulu.com/embed/KpUpERgcXjxbUmvhttxR8Q"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>
But considering who's directing it, NOT too surprised to see forbidden love mixed with a werewolf's existence AND 'a werewolf killed my sister' theme (BOO, btw) in this so-called 'adult re-telling'.
Not even Gary Oldman will get me to see this film. PASS.
***As there are currently TWO Snow White films in production and at this point I have little to no desire to see either one, here's why.

The Brothers Grimm: Snow White - Scheduled for release in 2012, the imdb blurb says it's 'A dark twist on the classic fairy tale, in which Snow White and the seven dwarfs look to reclaim their destroyed kingdom.'
column3: Okay, sounds great in theory but then I see who's directing and who's signed on so far and now I'm not so sure. Directed by Tarsem Singh, best known for R.E.M.'s 'Losing My Religion' video DOES have some visually impressive films like 'The Cell' under his belt so the frosted, fun side of me has NO doubt the film will be great to look at but the snarky, wheat side will wonder when some Michael Stipe-type of icon will pop up in the film. Whoever is playing Snow White has not been confirmed but Julia Roberts as The Evil Queen? GIVE ME A BREAK. I'd go see it if ERIC Roberts played The Evil Queen, at least THEN it would be something worth talking about.

column1: Snow White and The Huntsman - Also scheduled for release in 2012 (hey, maybe you two should've talked), THIS film HAS their Snow White&hellip
column2: are you ready for this? It's Kristen Stewart. That's right Kristen 'Hey, I'm really not that talented, have ONE expression and am completely monotone yet have managed to make a career out of it so I better make while the getting's good' Stewart has confirmed that she is indeed Snow White for this latest go-round. The problem? Snow White is extroverted, beauty, grace, charm and PURE innocence. Kristen Stewart is introverted, awkward, boring, dark, can't act for s**t and I grow increasingly tired of her one-note performances. Matter of fact, a couple years ago I started the 'Kristen Stewart Drinking Game' where you take a drink every time she messes with her hair on screen.

column1: Other problems? The film is CALLED Snow White which means Snow White should be the main focus but with the casting of Academy Award winner Charlize Theron as The Evil Queen and Academy Award nominee Viggo Mortensen as The Huntsman, I'm pretty sure Snow will be taking a back seat to these two powerhouses. Because unless the RIDICULOUSLY good looking Theron 'uglies up' like she did in 'Monster', there's NO WAY anyone will even remember Stewart's name when the film is over.

column2: ? I really hope that's a working title because right now it sounds like a 50's kitch music act like Sam The Sham And The Pharaohs (Wooly Bully, you heathens).

column1: While I am in TOTAL agreement with the age appropriate casting of Mortensen as The Huntsman, I am wondering WHY he's a huntsman and NOT a woodsman&hellip
column2: but who cares? Viggo is much like a groundhog now, only popping up once a year to make a film so in THAT vein&hellip
column3: I'm a LITTLE curious to see what he's going to do with it. I just wish he was coming to the surface to somehow be in The Hobbit but I'll settle for this. Did I also mention that I have a wicked crush on him? Okay, this one will go in the 'maybe' pile.

column1: **AND just like Snow White, there's ALSO two Hansel and Gretel films slated to come out over the next 12 months.

Hansel and Gretel in 3D - Is still in development and I hope it stays there. They don't even have a prelim casting and are boasting it will be an 'action packed visual FX filled version of the classic tale' with the tagline ""If you end up lost in the woods&hellip
column2: you may just find yourself"". Neat, is that the day the Teddy Bears have their picnic? Because otherwise, PASS.

column1: Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters - In this film, we catch up with brother/sister team Hansel and Gretel 15 years after the famous ""Gingerbread House"" incident, who've now become bounty hunters who hunt witches.
Why this particular film of all the bunch could work: it's co-written/directed by Tommy Wirkola (Dead Snow)
column2: produced by Will Ferrell, Chris Henchy, Adam McKay, Kevin J. Messick
column3: and stars Jeremy Renner, Gemma Arterton, Famke Janssen AND Peter Stormare.

column1: This film is being billed as a horror comedy and I feel that it's the PERFECT way to go
column2: it's not taking itself seriously and doesn't expect you as an audience member to, either. Jeremy Renner has come a LOOOOOONG way from his 7-11 'Slurpee Brain Freeze' commercial (remember the one where you hear a guy off camera alternately yelling in pain and sighing in pleasure while his dog's ears go up and down in curiosity? YEP!) And has made his bones in this industry as a solid go to guy when it comes to making slightly tweaked out characters accessible. With films like 'Dahmer' and 'The Hurt Locker' under his belt, I can't WAIT to see what he does in this one!!

column1: NOT a fan of Gemma Arterton (Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time) BUT knowing Famke Janssen and Peter Stormare (Fargo, The Big Lebowski) are there to round out the principal cast makes me kind of giddy. Stormare can go from scary as EFF to funny as EFF in nothing FLAT and I LOVE him for it!!!

What this film sounds like it'll be to me is Dead Snow meets Buffy The Vampire Slayer (FILM VERSION, heathens) with HILARIOUSLY gory results. Paramount's been pretty consistent with horror as of late and since it'll be in 3-D, I'll wager 50 bucks that it'll be 'Piranha 3-D' campy levels of gore and fun - which is the way it should be.

column2: G: WH is slated for release in 2012 and I am SO READY! Put this one in the ""ABSOLUTELY I'm seeing this pile!""

column1: Beastly - WHATEVER. Superficial tripe aimed at teenagers who opted to either stay in for a Teen Mom 2 marathon or saw the BETTER film that weekend: Rango.
Snow White and The Huntsman - Meh (but I love me some Viggo, so I'll probably go).
Hansel and Gretel in 3-D - GET OUTTA MY FACE BEFORE I KILL YOU.
Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters - Jeremy Renner, I seriously love you. Please make out with me. I mean, uh, SOOOOO Crix Approved.
So some people are getting their wish - Zombies are out and Fairy Tales are in&hellip
column2: but bigger doesn't necessarily mean better, so be careful what you wish for.

column1: P.S. the BEST version of Jack and The Beanstalk is the 1974 animated version starring Jack Grimes as the Giant (who we learn is named 'Tulip'). This film STILL scares the absolute hell out of me and is unlike ANY animated fairy tale film EVER. (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0074705/)

","

Comic Creators Report on Earthquake, Tsunami
by

The 8.9 magnitude earthquake that hit off the coast of Japan earlier today, and the tsunami that followed, have been the subject of a flurry of tweets and news updates from comics creators, translators and bloggers in Japan and the affected areas. The aftershocks are continuing as of this writing, as is the flow of news through social media.

Tokyopop CEO Stu Levy, who arrived in Tokyo two days ago, described the experience in a blog post at America's Greatest Otaku: ""My apartment rattled, rolled and kept shaking for what seemed like forever. Very, very scary. We've all been on Twitter and Facebook and skype - the cell phones aren't working! People are so nice to each other - helping out. Hotels are letting people all stay there because the trains are stopped and even Apple is giving away free iPhone charges for people. But Tokyo has it good - the incredible damage up north in Miyagi and Iwate is horrifying. The ocean has drowned the cars and buildings, washing them away.""

The offices of Manga University, a small American publisher of manga and how-to books located north of Tokyo, suffered some damage, but in a direct message via Twitter, CEO Glenn Kardy said no one was hurt.

119,"0","Pop Film: The Aliens Are Coming...","Pop Film: The Aliens Are Coming...","","",,"

Pop Film: The Aliens Are Coming...
by Andy Dugan

This year reminds me a little bit of 1996... mostly because it's filled with alien movies. Last year ""Skyline"" covered the side of a hotel next to the Convention Center at San Diego Comic Con, and ""Battle: LA"" sent troops through the Gas Lamp District. That was only the beginning of the marketing push for other films like ""Super 8"" from director J.J. Abrams and Executive Producer Steven Spielberg, and ""Cowboys &
column2: Aliens"" from Jon Favreau. Now we're getting into the season of big movies, and most of them have ties with aliens. I guess we could even argue that ""Thor"" is an alien? Maybe?

column1: Today ""Battle: LA"" was released, and while I've yet to watch it, I'm going to... and it's a big reason why I skipped ""Skyline."" Below I'm going to give you a preview of some of the alien movies on the way... so let's sit back, and enjoy some alien themed movie trailers!
Aliens invade the streets of Los Angeles in this film, and it looks like a mix of Pearl Harbor and Independence Day, with a touch of District 9 since it's directed by the same guy
column2: . With Aaron Eckhart and Michelle Rodriguez starring, it doesn't have the star power of Independence Day or Pearl Harbor, but I'm going to give it a chance considering the director's last film was nominated for the Best Picture Oscar.

column1: J.J. and Spielberg is enough reason for me to see this film, but then you throw in the Coach (Kyle Chandler) from ""Friday Night Lights"" and I end up putting it near the top of my list of films I want to see this year! I think the trailer above is spectacular enough, and I'm going to see this film as soon as I can.

What better case of exploiting aliens is there than Jon Favreau's action flick, with Harrison Ford, Olivia Wilde, Daniel Craig, Sam Rockwell, and Paul Dano? The film is based on a 2006 graphic novel where aliens land in Arizona in the year: 1873. Cowboys take on Aliens, with ""Iron Man"" like special effects. I doubt anyone wouldn't want to watch cowboys fighting aliens, right?

I love Michael Bay, I always have... I loved him in 1995 when ""Bad Boys"" came out and he made Will Smith the action star we love today. The man can make an action film, and I don't go to his movies expecting to see award winning performances or deep thoughtful stories... I go to see EXPLOSIONS, and that's what he delivers. Transformers 3 will offer the Summer fun that we all deserve, let's just hope it's better than Transformers 2.
There are more big alien themed films on the way, but the trailers haven't been released yet, so here is a list for you.

Battleship
Alien 5
Predators 2
Area 51
The Darkest Hour
and... an ""Untitled"" Michael Bay Alien Film.

If you want some thrills at home, it looks like ""Skyline"" will be available on Blu Ray and DVD on March 22, but I am going to vote for hitting the theatres for Battle: LA since it's something you can do right now.

120,"0","Pop Music: What Pi Sounds Like","Pop Music: What Pi Sounds Like","","",,"

Pop Music: What Pi Sounds Like
via Cord Jefferson from Good.is
The late Russian composer Igor Stravinsky once said, ""Musical form is close to mathematics&mdash
column2: not perhaps to mathematics itself, but certainly to something like mathematical thinking and relationship.""

column1: Musician Michael Blake expands on that idea with this fascinating video, in which he sets pi, the mathematical constant, to music up to 31 decimal places. He then makes a tiny symphony out of the ditty.

Let this serve as a reminder to critics of arts education that, in many ways, arts and sciences go hand in hand.

Pop Music: The Playlist - Indie Covering Mainstream
by Andy Dugan

This week we are going to take a look at what made Justin Bieber famous... YouTube 'music video' covers. A trend that has actually been working for a lot of independent musicians is to cover a mainstream artist on video and post it on YouTube, with hopes of getting SEO views associated with the song.
I've picked out some videos that I think were done well, and may just get some of these artists on an episode of 'GLEE.'
Telephone - Lady Gaga feat. Beyonce - Classical Cover by Aston
Britney Spears - The Big Fat Bass - Till the World Ends - cover by Project Dirty
John Mayer - Clarity - cover by Paul Dateh
Sometimes, an artist that isn't an indie will cover a song, and Bruce Springsteen did a nice job of stepping into Willow Smith's ""Whip My Hair"" with Jimmy Fallon. Take a look...

If you've seen anything online that you think should be included, leave me a comment below, and let's give some of these artists more views!

122,"0","Pop Games: Indie Dev Spotlight: Jumala","Pop Games: Indie Dev Spotlight: Jumala","","",,"

Pop Games: Indie Dev Spotlight: Jumala

Seattle and its nearby suburbs are major hubs for game studios both large and small. Seattle has PopCap and NCSoft, Redmond has Nintendo and Microsoft Games, Bellevue is home to Valve, Bungie, and ArenaNet -- and those are just a few of the bigger names. The entire area is peppered with smaller studios and indie developers creating incredibly cool games that may not get a huge marketing budget.

I'm on a mission to talk about those studios. Today is the introduction to what I hope will be a series of spotlights on local independent game studios, showing off their efforts and exposing more people to what is often pure, concentrated radness.

column2:
URL=http%3a%2f%2fjumala.com"" target=""_blank"">
http://jumala.com
Release: TBA (Closed beta begins March 31)
Price: Free

column1: Jumala is the very picture of indie developer -- a smaller studio, 15 employees, nestled in an office building in Bellevue, WA. A handsome arcade cabinet with a huge array of games greets you on entering, next to a cozy XBOX 360 setup. I immediately feel comfortable here: games are clearly the great love in this office.

I'm greeted by Sara Girard, the community marketing manager, and Frank Savage, the company CTO. A little company background: Jumala may be small and independent, but it is by no means inexperienced. The leadership at Jumala has put in serious time at companies like Nintendo, Disney, and Microsoft. Frank's resume alone is impressive: he worked on MechCommander and other similar titles before moving on to form the Microsft XNA Game Studio team -- famous for releasing XNA Game Studio Express, which allows ""hobbyist"" game developers to rapidly develop their own games.

This love of putting game development in the hands of the layman has clearly been the driving force behind Jumala. Frank, Sara, and I sit down for a hands-on demo, and Frank gives me the lowdown as the game loads.

Jumala is a game whose objective is to build games. Create your own games, play games that your friends have built, participate in the building community, collaborate with others to make something really terrific -- these are the major tenets of Jumala. If you're thinking of Little Big Planet or Minecraft, you're not far wrong, but Jumala has improved on both of these concepts a bit: you're not constrained by Little Big Planet's established aesthetic or two-dimensionality, nor by Minecraft's unit-based brick-building system. Jumala is three-dimensional, and its design and structure is dictated by you.

Boot up Jumala for the first time and you'll see the Dashboard. This is your control panel. Here's where you'll choose what to do: build a game, play someone else's game, participate in the community, do some quests -- you'll never be without something to do.
There's a lot to discuss here, but I'll focus on Jumala's primary objective: game creation.

We load up a premade game as a starting point -- it's a Pirate themed map called Treasure Island. The first thing I notice is that the graphics are very cartoony and skew a bit young. Frank assures me that's a property of this particular map
column2: there are  other premade themes that will be much darker. We bounce around and  collect some glowing pink skulls
column3: an evil pumpkin starts chasing us, hellbent on destruction.

column1: Here's where things get cool: Frank pauses the game, and suddenly we're using sliders and checkboxes to edit the properties of that evil pumpkin. We can change its aggressive behavior pattern, its radius of attack, how much damage it does, how long it chases us, and a handful of other variables normally controlled by code in the background.

We apply a ""sway in wind"" property to a palm tree and unpause the game -- it sways gently in the breeze. We apply a ""sway in wind"" property to a stoic looking pile of boulders -- they sway gently in the breeze. Sure, it doesn't make sense, but it demonstrates just how free the creation really is in this game. You can even create a game whose challenges require the player to edit your map with Jumala's tools in order to solve the puzzles you've set, gamifying the actual game creation process. Layers within layers, friends.

Frank demonstrates how nearly every object, texture, and behavior in this game is editable. Our character is still very low-level, so he's only unlocked a few sets of actions -- as we level up, we'll unlock more functionality.

Jumala is a game that encourages cooperative creation. For example, say you're a great object artist but you hate environment design. You partner up with an environment artist through the community and together you two build a stunning game experience, getting achievements and game rewards in the process.

In my opinion, Jumala is a no-brainer for game development courses. Though it doesn't currently support editing your game's code, it provides a solid introduction to object-oriented programming and could serve as a way to prototype game concepts.
The price tag? Free dollars! Jumala has no retail fee
column2: they're planning to make their money selling game assets -- objects, textures, behaviors -- most for under a dollar.

column1: The potential with Jumala is pretty staggering. They're dreaming big: they want to make co-op gameplay possible, with the ability to set your own achievements in-game for your players, and even eventually be able to create and sell your OWN game assets and level designs in the Jumala store.

Interested? You should be! Jumala enters closed beta at the end of this month, and I've got some beta keys to give away. Just come follow me on Twitter @SheGeekShow and send me a tweet with ""JUMALA BETA!"" in it somewhere, and I'll enter you in the drawing!
Check out the latest episode of the She Geek Show!!!

Seattle has PopCap and NCSoft, Redmond has Nintendo and Microsoft Games, Bellevue is home to Valve, Bungie, and ArenaNet -- and those are just a few of the bigger names. The entire area is peppered with smaller studios and indie developers creating incredibly cool games that may not get a huge marketing budget.

I'm on a mission to talk about those studios. Today is the introduction to what I hope will be a series of spotlights on local independent game studios, showing off their efforts and exposing more people to what is often pure, concentrated radness.

column2:
URL=http%3a%2f%2fjumala.com"" target=""_blank"">
http://jumala.com
Release: TBA (Closed beta begins March 31)
Price: Free

column1: Jumala is the very picture of indie developer -- a smaller studio, 15 employees, nestled in an office building in Bellevue, WA. A handsome arcade cabinet with a huge array of games greets you on entering, next to a cozy XBOX 360 setup. I immediately feel comfortable here: games are clearly the great love in this office.

I'm greeted by Sara Girard, the community marketing manager, and Frank Savage, the company CTO. A little company background: Jumala may be small and independent, but it is by no means inexperienced. The leadership at Jumala has put in serious time at companies like Nintendo, Disney, and Microsoft. Frank's resume alone is impressive: he worked on MechCommander and other similar titles before moving on to form the Microsft XNA Game Studio team -- famous for releasing XNA Game Studio Express, which allows ""hobbyist"" game developers to rapidly develop their own games.

This love of putting game development in the hands of the layman has clearly been the driving force behind Jumala. Frank, Sara, and I sit down for a hands-on demo, and Frank gives me the lowdown as the game loads.

Jumala is a game whose objective is to build games. Create your own games, play games that your friends have built, participate in the building community, collaborate with others to make something really terrific -- these are the major tenets of Jumala. If you're thinking of Little Big Planet or Minecraft, you're not far wrong, but Jumala has improved on both of these concepts a bit: you're not constrained by Little Big Planet's established aesthetic or two-dimensionality, nor by Minecraft's unit-based brick-building system. Jumala is three-dimensional, and its design and structure is dictated by you.

Boot up Jumala for the first time and you'll see the Dashboard. This is your control panel. Here's where you'll choose what to do: build a game, play someone else's game, participate in the community, do some quests -- you'll never be without something to do.
There's a lot to discuss here, but I'll focus on Jumala's primary objective: game creation.

We load up a premade game as a starting point -- it's a Pirate themed map called Treasure Island. The first thing I notice is that the graphics are very cartoony and skew a bit young. Frank assures me that's a property of this particular map
column2: there are  other premade themes that will be much darker. We bounce around and  collect some glowing pink skulls
column3: an evil pumpkin starts chasing us, hellbent on destruction.

column1: Here's where things get cool: Frank pauses the game, and suddenly we're using sliders and checkboxes to edit the properties of that evil pumpkin. We can change its aggressive behavior pattern, its radius of attack, how much damage it does, how long it chases us, and a handful of other variables normally controlled by code in the background.

We apply a ""sway in wind"" property to a palm tree and unpause the game -- it sways gently in the breeze. We apply a ""sway in wind"" property to a stoic looking pile of boulders -- they sway gently in the breeze. Sure, it doesn't make sense, but it demonstrates just how free the creation really is in this game. You can even create a game whose challenges require the player to edit your map with Jumala's tools in order to solve the puzzles you've set, gamifying the actual game creation process. Layers within layers, friends.

Frank demonstrates how nearly every object, texture, and behavior in this game is editable. Our character is still very low-level, so he's only unlocked a few sets of actions -- as we level up, we'll unlock more functionality.

Jumala is a game that encourages cooperative creation. For example, say you're a great object artist but you hate environment design. You partner up with an environment artist through the community and together you two build a stunning game experience, getting achievements and game rewards in the process.

In my opinion, Jumala is a no-brainer for game development courses. Though it doesn't currently support editing your game's code, it provides a solid introduction to object-oriented programming and could serve as a way to prototype game concepts.
The price tag? Free dollars! Jumala has no retail fee
column2: they're planning to make their money selling game assets -- objects, textures, behaviors -- most for under a dollar.

column1: The potential with Jumala is pretty staggering. They're dreaming big: they want to make co-op gameplay possible, with the ability to set your own achievements in-game for your players, and even eventually be able to create and sell your OWN game assets and level designs in the Jumala store.

Interested? You should be! Jumala enters closed beta at the end of this month, and I've got some beta keys to give away. Just come follow me on Twitter @SheGeekShow and send me a tweet with ""JUMALA BETA!"" in it somewhere, and I'll enter you in the drawing!
Check out the latest episode of the She Geek Show!!!

","

124,"0","Pop Film: Darby O'Gill And The Little People","Pop Film: Darby O'Gill And The Little People","","",,"

Pop Film: Darby O'Gill And The Little People
by Crix Lee
Everyone is Irish on St Patrick's Day&hellip
column2:
Even Sean Connery

There was a time where Disney live action films ruled the world: Escape To Witch Mountain, The Apple Dumpling Gang, The Love Bug, Bedknobs and Broomsticks, Mary Poppins, Pete's Dragon&hellip
column3:
man, SO many great films.

But in honor of St. Patrick's Day, I'm here to talk about one of my fave Disney films of all time:
column4: Darby O'Gill And The Little People

column2:
src=""http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_yp4Erjgdzj8/TSLLKg_5OVI/AAAAAAAACH8/lPfI5tZFIDA/s640/Darby+O%2527Gill+and+the+Little+People+%25281959%2529.jpg"" alt="""" width=""349"" height=""500"" />

Darby O'Gill lives in the town of Rathcullen with his young adult daughter, Katie, in a gatehouse on the estate of Lord Fitzpatrick (where Darby has served many years as caretaker).
column3:
Darby has a love of drink and a knack of telling a good story, his favorite being his numerous attempts to catch leprechauns - especially Brian Connors (a.k.a. King Brian). One day Darby learns from Lord Fitzpatrick that because Darby is past his prime, another caretaker needs to be hired but that Darby and his daughter will still live on the estate in another cottage.

So when Michael McBride (Sean Connery) arrives, Darby convinces him not to tell Katie he's been replaced and while hesitant, Michael agrees. That night, Darby is kidnapped by the leprechauns while chasing his runaway horse, Cleopatra.
column4: Darby soon learns his capture was NOT accidental
column5: King Brian tells Darby he's taken him so that he can avoid having to tell Katie he was forced to retire.

column2:
src=""http://www.junkyardclubhouse.com/images/darby-ogill-and-king-brian-shar.jpg"" alt="""" width=""500"" height=""426"" />

Here's where it gets fun.

Darby tricks the leprechauns into looking for a violin and as they leave through a giant crack in the mountainside, Darby flees&hellip
column4:
King Brian then comes for Darby again and gets so drunk on Irish Whiskey that King Brian fails to make it home before sunrise, stripping his powers until sunset. Trapped, he is forced to give Darby wishes before he can go home...

Katie and Michael (played by a very young and VERY tasty Sean Connery) begin to become closer and true to form, a rival soon appears to not only take Michael's job but is out to win the affections of Katie as well by any means possible (think Gaston from Beauty And The Beast with a stupid hat).

And of course, there are musical numbers and yes, Sean Connery DOES sing!!



I COULD tell you how it ends but where's the fun in that?!

Now, keep in mind this film was made in 1959 and is HIGHLY stereotypical but underneath all the overblown Irish brogues (including the really weird one by Connery) and leprechauns running around everywhere, this film's message is one of friendship and love. And I know that I'm not the ONLY one who gets it - it shows up on a lot of ""Top 10 St. Patrick's Day/Irish films"".

column2:
src=""http://www.junkyardclubhouse.com/images/darby-ogill-fiddles-a-tune-for.jpg"" alt="""" width=""500"" height=""375"" />

So if you're looking to see how fun Disney was back in the day before they went COMPLETELY corporate, check out Darby O'Gill. You'll laugh and cry, guaranteed.

Oh, yeah. Watch out for the banshees
column3:
they're scary!

Tagline for film reads ""A touch O'Blarney&hellip
column4:
.a heap O'Magic and A LOAD O'LAUGHTER"" and I agree. Even after 35 years, I'm still in it for Connery.

The Frame Rate: Erin Go Bragh! Crix Approved

Pro Tip: it is NOT ""St Patty's"". Paddy is derived from Padraig, which is Gaelic for 'Patrick' Patty is short for 'Patricia'. I'm part Irish, I should know!

The Playlist - The 5 Most Expensive Music Videos
by Andy Dugan

It seems it's possible to get a pretty solid music video done these days for a major label band for about $50,000... but in the past, video budgets were pretty large. Let's take a look at the 5 most expensive music videos ever produced.
5. Puff Daddy (featuring The Notorious B.I.G. and Busta Rhymes) &ndash

This ""futuristic"" video features Dennis Hopper and Danny DeVito and feels like a bad rip-off of Demolition Man, The Running Man, and Blade Runner. It's not a good video, but it was made, and cost a lot of money, so perhaps that's a good enough reason to give it a view?

column6: embed=1"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""322"" src=""http://d.yimg.com/static.video.yahoo.com/yep/YV_YEP.swf?ver=2.2.46"" allowfullscreen=""true"" allowscriptaccess=""always"" bgcolor=""#000000"" flashvars=""id=817219&amp

column1: Madonna and expensive are two words that have a place in music video history... she makes this list twice. That being said, I'm not really sure what's going on in this video, but it does have ""something"" going on. I was entertained.

Perhaps if the producers of the movie would have given this $6 million to another screenwriter, 'Die Another Day' would have been a good James Bond film... but instead we are left with this video, that is clearly a set design rip-off of the next most expensive video ever made.
Michael Jackson is awesome. I have nothing bad to say about anything that he's ever done, and this video is as awesome now as it was when it came out
column2: money well spent. One question though... why does Michael always flip off the camera in his videos?

column1: I'm unsure how anything with Jared Leto was given a budget of $13 million, I'm not even sure any feature film he was the lead actor in had a budget that large, and this number has been disputed, but this video still holds the title of ""Most Expensive Music Video Ever.""

Next week, we are premiering the first episode of 'The Playlist' - which is this blog, in the form of a show!

128,"0","Pop Games: Should I Buy a Nintendo 3DS?","Pop Games: Should I Buy a Nintendo 3DS?","","",,"

Pop Games: Should I Buy a Nintendo 3DS?
by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)

Nintendo's new handheld system, the 3DS, hits the street this Sunday, March 27th in North America. At $249 MSRP -- the same price the Wii was when it came out -- it's no small investment. Maybe you've got your solid old DS Lite still kicking around (or if you're like me, you've got the fat old first generation DS still because you're a cheapskate and I mean who really NEEDS a decent backlight, right?), and you're wondering if upgrading to the 3DS is necessary.

column2:
src=""http://free3ds.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/07/free-3DS.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""379"" />

Here are the straight facts on the Nintendo 3DS.

Price: $249
Colors: Blue or black
Release: 3/27/2011 (North America)

- In case the name didn't give it away, the Nintendo 3DS can play games in 3D.

The top of the 3DS's dual screens has a 3D display, which does not require any kind of special goggular eyewear. And it's an impressive effect. The level of 3D being displayed can also be adjusted on the fly with a slider, in case it's giving you a headache.

- Existing DS hardware has been tightened up and improved in many ways.

The graphics are greatly improved, the system is smaller and lighter, the top screen is about 10% bigger, and the controls are easier to use. Much adulation has surrounded the new ""Slide Pad"" controller, which is apparently really slick. The touchscreen, however, is unchanged
column3:
one might have hoped for better touchscreen sensitivity in the age of Apple, but no dice. Early reports also indicate that the battery life is depressingly low, but the 3DS's charge cradle is apparently awesome and supports play-and-charge.

- It has three cameras -- two external, one internal.

These cameras can be used to take photos and insert real life environmental factors into games, which is neat by itself -- but truly amazing is the fact that the Nintendo 3DS is also able to take 3D photos and videos. I have no idea how spectacular (or not) the quality is on these, but it could be a very cool feature to have in your hands. Additionally, it comes with 6 augmented reality cards (or AR cards) -- aim your camera at the cards in certain games to bring your real-life environment into the game.

- The Nintendo 3DS has a gyroscope and accelerometer.

Like the iPhone, you can tilt and turn your 3DS to control the action onscreen -- though not in every game. This seems like it has the potential to really clash with the 3D functionality -- but if it's an annoying feature, you can turn it off. (Can I just say, I LOVE the word gyroscope? Digression, but c'mon, it's so steampunk.)

- The 3DS is backwards compatible.

It'll play both regular DS and DSi games, as well as DSiWare and downloadable Game Boy Color titles through Nintendo's eShop.

- Like the Wii, you'll be able to make Miis with your 3DS.

Even cooler, you can use the 3DS's built-in camera to take a photo of your face and have your system attempt to render a Mii to look like you. You'll also be able to import your beloved Miis from your Wii.

- The Nintendo 3DS has some pretty revolutionary new software.

This is actually the biggest part of what I'm excited about for the 3DS. Street Pass, the name of one particular technology the 3DS uses, is a system that allows your 3DS to link to other 3DS's you pass on the street. You can choose to automatically share your Mii, profile, games, achievements, etc.

Super Street Fighter 4 3D is a game that's using this technology in an interesting way: their Figure Battle Mode allows you to spend coins you earn in-game in a slot machine to buy random character figurines. You then use these figurines to build a team and assign stat points. Once you enter Street Pass mode (which I think activates just by putting the system to sleep), your Nintendo 3DS will automatically seek out other people who've done the same thing and enter battle with their teams.

column2:
src=""http://www.techmagdaily.com/wp-content/uploads/images/Super_Street_Fighter_IV_3D_Clip.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""522"" />

This reminds me a little of the social features of the Zune: extremely cool in theory, but you'll need to be in a place where there's lots of other friendly 3DS owners around to really take advantage of it.

- The lineup of launch titles for the 3DS is fairly weak, but there are a lot of big titles buttoning up development soon.

March 27th will launch the Nintendo 3DS with titles like Madden NFL 3DS, Lego Star Wars III: The Clone Wars, 3D, The Sims 3, Nintendogs + Cats 3D, and a handful of other familiar names -- standard family fare for the DS historically. However, there are some titles to get excited about coming up... Paper Mario 3D, an obvious choice for 3D development, is one that I'm looking forward to, as well as Kingdom Hearts, Metal Gear Solid, Final Fantasy, Bomberman, and plenty of other Mario titles.

src=""http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_c5D67vOMzjg/TRvH9dceG4I/AAAAAAAAADE/qBSfqRDrS_w/s1600/Nintendo%2B3DS%2B2.jpg"" alt="""" width=""480"" height=""492"" />

----

There's much more that can be said about the Nintendo 3DS, but hopefully this gives you a taste of what to expect with this new hardware if you're unsure or didn't know much about it. It's pretty clear that the system has a ton of potential and seems to be a sign that Nintendo is, yet again, pioneering what's possible in gaming. What do you think? Will you be getting a 3DS?

- Kate

","

Pop Comics: Fiction Clemens
by Olivia Duarte

Fiction is Stranger than Fiction

column2: s comic Wednesday and we have another out-of-this-world read from the Spacedog Entertainment library! &ldquo
column4: takes place in the Wild Wild West, but not one you and I know. Instead, this extraordinary tale of a high noon saloon shootout is set in the surreal recesses of a psychedelic mind, where the stunning artwork is reason enough to check this one out.

column1: Fiction Clemens, the main character, is a slow-going slacker who isn&rsquo
column2: t the least bit interested in doing much beyond loafing around town.&nbsp
column3: Much to his dismay, his low-key lifestyle is in for a big change when he encounters the evil Tiberius Kitchens.&nbsp
column4: Tiberius thinks Fiction is after his woman (no thanks to the woman) and he wants to kill him, but before he can give our sleepy-eyed hero a permanent nap, along comes Dune Trixie, the saloon drunk, who accidentally whacks a bottle onto Tiberius&rsquo
column5: s head and knocks him out cold. And this is where the strange becomes stranger, as Trixie and Clemens are taken to the desert and dumped there by the locals in town--for their own safety. They wake up, only to go on a mind-bending trip to another bizarro world with even more unusual characters.

column3: is a wild rollercoaster of a ride into some psychedelic and eye-popping landscapes. Where this ride ends is pretty crazy, but we&rsquo
column4: re not going to spoil the trip for you. Pick it up yourself, and be prepared to turn on, tune in, and drop out.

The Frame Rate: Torchwood comes to U.S.
by Crix Lee

BIG news, Torchwood fans, so I'm here to confirm what the interwebs have been buzzing about these last 24 hours: Torchwood is indeed coming to U.S. soil for reals.

Created by Russell T. Davies in 2005, the popular Doctor Who spinoff ran for three seasons on BBC and found a loving home with sci-fi fans stateside primarily through BBC America and for those late to the dance (like myself), Netflix.

You've never seen Torchwood, you say? Well, here's the short version!

Torchwood Institute is comprised of a small team of alien-hunters whose primary function is to handle and investigate cases where extra-terrestrials are involved. Torchwood is led by Captain Jack Harkness -
column2: a dashing, sarcastic, immortal ex-con man from the future who made Earth his home sometime in the 19th century (played to perfection by John Barrowman).

src=""http://scifipulse.net/wp-content/uploads/2010/01/torchwood10.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""430"" />

Think X-Files meets Buffy turned up to 11 - that's Torchwood.

The fourth in the series (note: UK shows run in series, not seasons and usually run 6 episodes per) will be a little different as creator Davies has extended this run to a whopping 10 episodes, which I'm guessing in part is due to the US show format&hellip
column3:
which means FOUR extra times for me to sigh longingly at Captain Jack, like so: SIIIIIIIIIIIIIGH.

Torchwood: Miracle Day goes a little something like this&hellip

column2:
src=""http://www.bleedingcool.com/wp-content/uploads//2011/03/182346.jpg"" alt="""" width=""500"" height=""750"" />

""Torchwood begins with a day when nobody dies. All across the world, nobody dies. And then the next day, and the next, and the next, people keep aging, they get hurt and sick, but they never die. The result: a population boom, overnight. With all the extra people, resources are infinite. It&rsquo
column3: s said that in four month's time, the human race will cease to be viable. But this can&rsquo
column6: s got to be behind it. It&rsquo
column7: s a race against time as C.I.A. agent Rex Matheson investigates a global conspiracy.&nbsp
column8: The answers lie within an old, secret British institute. As Rex keeps asking &ldquo
column10:
s drawn into a world of adventure, and a threat to change what it means to be human, forever.""

OOH&hellip
column11:
right?!

Miracle Day is currently in production in Los Angeles (trust me, I've nearly crashed my car a few times
column12:
every time I've seen production wagons HOPING to catch a glimpse of John Barrowman) and the BIG time rumor is that actor Bruce Willis' L.A. compound is serving as Torchwood's new base of operations. Pretty snazzy.

Okay, okay&hellip
column13:
you wanna know the REAL stuff. ""Who's in it?!""

Fret not, because YES, the FABULOUS John Barrowman returns as Captain Jack along with series regular Eve Myles reprising her role as Gwen Cooper (yay!). Joining the principal cast will be Bill Pullman as former teacher/convicted child killer (with a twist), Oswald Danes
column14: Mekhi Phifer as CIA operative, Rex Matheson (which sounds oddly similar to his role on ""Lie To Me"")
column15: Alexa Havins as Esther, a CIA agent who dreams of going to 'the big show' and gets her wish in a hurry
column16:
and Arlene Tur as Dr Vera Juarez, a D.C. surgeon who suddenly finds herself the government's (and basically, the WORLD's) medical advisor once Miracle Day hits.

Other notable cast members will include Dichen Lachman, Dillon Casey, Wayne Knight, Ernie Hudson, C. Thomas Howell, and Six Feet Under's Lauren Ambrose as sweet yet ruthless PR agent Jilly Kitzinger.
column17:
It's been rumored that James Marsters wanted to reprise his role as Captain John Hart, but whether or not it came to fruition remains to be seen.

I have to admit that at first I was a wee bit skeptical about this ""American"" move but knowing that writers Jane Espenson (Buffy The Vampire Slayer), John Shiban (The X-Files, ST: Enterprise, Supernatural), Doris Egan (House), John Fay AND creator Davies himself are on board makes me breathe a WHOLE lot easier.
Davies himself explains that with this series, Torchwood focuses on the human condition more than the sci-fi aspect and turns once again to Buffy The Vampire Slayer as his inspiration.

""The best metaphors in Buffy came down to, &ldquo
column19: s it like to be in high school, as a kid?&rdquo
column21: s the same with Torchwood: Miracle Day. It&rsquo
column22:
s about us and our decisions and our lives, and how we live with each other and how we die with each other. That forms the core of the story.""

WHEN DOES IT PREMIERE?!

First of all, calm down. Second of all, Torchwood: Miracle Day will premiere on Starz THIS July 8th, 10 pm PST.

Be excited, B-E excited!

Need to catch up? PLENTY of time! You can find all three seasons in a glorious package in Netflix Instant Queue. Never seen the show before? Here's a wee smackerel!



The Frame Rate: Torchwood is ready&hellip
column23:
and so am I. Crix Approved!

p.s. If ANY of you Torchwood cast members or Russell Davies are reading this, please tell John Barrowman I think he's fantastiballs and I'd like a hug when I meet him! Hell, I'll do a Cole Porter duet with him if it gets me in his airspace, heh heh.

Extra Frame: Marvel vs. 30 Rock
by Crix Lee

Remember last week's episode of 30 Rock titled ""Queen of Jordan""?

I do. I remember laughing a ton&hellip
column2:
but I also remember yelling ""NOOOOOOOOOOOOO"" at a couple places near the end of the show.

This is why:

So the B-story on last week's episode goes like this: The writers learn that schoolteacher Lynn Onkman (Susan Sarandon), who was imprisoned for having an affair with a 14 year old student 20 years prior is being released from prison. The surprises continue as they not only discover that the student in question was FRANK (Judah Friedlander) but that they were 'madly in love' as well. When they're finally reunited for the first time, Lynn is dismayed that Frank has never really grown up, so she leaves him. This snaps Frank back to life and he seeks her out at her day job in a diner to PROVE he's ready to grow up and put away childish things.

Here's where it becomes life-scarring&hellip
column3: ...not only does Frank deep fry a Skeletor action figure but deep fries a copy of Marvel's Avengers Academy #8.
column4:
src=""http://4.bp.blogspot.com/__TUxC_vsVxs/TTkC4vh6Z9I/AAAAAAAAB1w/vXNveBtX5q0/s1600/Avengers%2BAcademy%2B8.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""900"" />

NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO(breath)OOOOOOOOOOOOOO

The following is an open letter from Marvel Comics's Chief Creative Officer Joe Quesada and Sr. Vice President/Executive Editor Tom Breevort to the writers of 30 Rock.



ha haaaaaaaaaaa. I love these boys and I love my 30 Rock&hellip
column5:
but seriously, stop deep frying comic books or else.

133,"1","The Playlist - Celebrity Driven Music Videos","The Playlist - Celebrity Driven Music Videos","","",,"

The Playlist - Celebrity Driven Music Videos
by Andy Dugan

I know that we consider musicians ""celebrities"", but when a musician puts a movie star in their music video, that's something that can really boost the view count! This week on ""The Playlist"" I'm going to give you my 5 favorite music videos starring movie stars.
The future ""Iron Man"" is all that needs to be said for this video. So really, who was more psychic about the future of Robert Downey Jr.'s career
column2: Elton John or Shane Black? I'm gonna credit Elton John for this one.

column1: 4. Tom Petty and The Heartbreakers - Mary Jane's Last Dance
What more can you ask for than appearance by Vicki Vale, I mean Kim Bassinger, in anything... let alone, a Tom Petty music video. This one is a classic.
3. Jamie Foxx featuring T-Pain - Blame It

I guess, in theory, Jamie Foxx is a movie star, but he throws Ron Howard, Jake Gyllenhaal, Samuel L. Jackson and Forest Whitaker in this one, and has Hype Williams direct it... the only thing missing here is an appearance by Keanu Reeves.
2. Paul Simon - You Can Call Me Al
Maybe Elton John's video was a up-to-date version of this, where Chevy Chase is singing the song. This one is from a while back, and deserves mention. Enjoy!

Some argue that this is the best music video ever made... and it very well could be. This is certainly the best celebrity driven music video ever made! Christopher Walken was already amazing, but this video puts him on a level that will be hard for any other actor to reach. Nice work!

I can't say that I like this music video, but it gets honorable mention because it stars Keanu Reeves! That's pretty awesome.

The Frame Rate: ElfQuest: A Fan Imagining
by Crix Lee
So for the last couple of months, I had seen some rumblings on Twitter and Facebook from some female friends and colleagues talking about ""how much fun they were having playing in the woods.""
column3:
I wondered why but then thought ""It's L.A. and they're up to something and I'm sure I'll see it soon.""

And I was right. A WHOLE LOT of ladies (and a few gents) were indeed up to something and it's called ""ElfQuest: A Fan Imagining"", based on the 1978-2007 comic book series created by Wendy and Richard Pini.

Sounds neat, right? Sounded neat to Paula Rhodes and Stephanie Thorpe, too
column4: two well known and well respected names in the New Media world. These two ladies not only share an impressive list of credits between them as actors and producers
column5: they also share a fierce, undying love of Elfquest that made them the successful, feisty women they are today.

column1:
""ElfQuest showed us the heroines that we could aspire to become and its magic shaped us, ultimately leading us into the creative entertainment sphere. So we owe it a lot!""

This shared love then turned into what I like to call a ""four minute and thirty four second love letter"" to EQ creators Wendy and Richard Pini in the form of a fan film trailer starring some very recognizable ladies in the New Media world who know a thing or two about what it takes to survive in a ""man's world"".
column2: The multifaceted cast includes such names as Shannon Nelson, Taryn Southern, Cathy Baron, Casey McKinnon, Taryn O'Neill, Jamie Blair, Angie Cole, Jessica Rose, Melanie Merkosky&hellip
column3: and yeah, there are men in it but who cares? This is about the ladies! (just kidding, gents)

column1: Like any fantasy comic book that you wanna make into live action fare, it simply MUST have a good premise. So after poking around the EQ official website and reading the first issue, it seems to go something like this: several tribes of elves (evolved from an earlier alien like species known as ""High Ones"") vs humans in a never-ending struggle to not only survive, but to coexist on the planet called Abode or ""World of Two Moons"".

column2:
now for the rate.

What works: just about everything. I loved how little they deviated from the story and yes, they're all very attractive women but it wasn't the ""ElfQuest: T&
column3: A"" I feared it could possibly turn into
column4: it was something more. It was suspenseful, inquisitive, and left me wanting to see a fleshed out film or as a web series.&nbsp
column6: all around a beautiful work of art.

column1:
What I wish I would've seen: at least one of the male elves. The three gents (led by Sam Proof) were great as the man-beasts but unfortunately if they're the only men people who haven't been introduced to EQ see, it could very well come across as a battle of the sexes rather than a tale of strength, courage, and survival. But that's being uber nitpicky.

The ultimate goal, according to Rhodes and Thorpe, was to ""create new fans and give existing ones a taste of the world we've loved for so long.""

It worked.

I truly believe that this will inspire people to read or even revisit the entire series much like Peter Jackson did for LOTR. I've bookmarked the official EQ website and am absolutely enjoying every page and becoming immersed in a world I normally wouldn't think about venturing into!

For more info about the ladies and gents of ElfQuest: A Fan Imagining, visit the official website and if you're like me and want to read the ElfQuest series in its entirety (for free)
column2: chat with fans from around the world
column3:
or even learn to draw these wonderful beings, visit ElfQuest.com.

The Frame Rate: Shade and Sweetwater, quest accepted. Crix Approved.
