135,"1","Pop Games: Dynasty Warriors 7","Pop Games: Dynasty Warriors 7","","",,"

Pop Games: Dynasty Warriors 7
by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)

There are a few games that define their many sequels numerically -- Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest come to mind. What makes each sequel successful is that they usually riff on the formula and give an exciting new gameplay and story direction. Each game is its own discrete entity. They share qualities, but they're still individuals.

What makes Dynasty Warriors so amazing is that they have not troubled to do this at all.

I haven't played a Dynasty Warriors game since a bit of 5 when it was first released, but I played the shit out of 2 through 4, especially 3 (my all-time favorite). Characteristics critical to a Dynasty Warriors game include:

- Cheesy heavy metal music

- Awkward English dubbing and melodramatic voice acting

- Hilariously inaccurate portrayal of historical events

- Fruity wizards with fans (very important)

- Effortless, ridiculous, massive hack-n-slash combat (preferably with lots of flames and glowy shit)

When you play a Dynasty Warriors game, you're not there for the story, or the history, or the characters' relationships to each other. You are there to relax, turn off your brain, and see if you can manage to tumble artfully into a crowd and kill a hundred dudes at once.

What Omega Force, the developer, has done this time around is tried to make you care about the things that were usually too vague and poorly translated for you to care about them before. You choose one of the four major families -- Wu, Shu, Wei, and Jin -- to run through the campaign. The story is told in a much more compelling, accessible way through cutscenes and loading screen narration. When you play through Story Mode, unlike games past, your general is chosen for you depending on the level. Each level begins with your character in the base with the doors closed -- you can speak to many of the NPCs around you to get perspective on the level and the characters involved (not necessary, but a cool semi-RPG element that connects you to the story). There are also weapons dealers in the towns where you can buy new gear.

column2:
src=""http://multiplayerblog.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/dynasty-warriors-7.jpg"" alt="""" width=""575"" height=""300"" />

They've added the ability for you to choose two weapons that your general can switch between on the fly. Each character has their ideal weapon, or their EX weapon, which allows them a unique special attack. Most weapons also have a special ""seal"", which once unlocked can be applied to an empty slot on any other weapon. This new approach to weapons is pretty cool, but several characters share EX weapon types now instead of having totally unique ones as in the past, and the animations for those weapon attacks is identical between those characters. Kind of a visual bummer.

Besides Story Mode, Dynasty Warriors 7 also has Conquest Mode. Previous DW games had a Free Mode that allowed you to replay any level with any general. Conquest Mode has unique maps that are character-specific, where an unlocked character can level up, gather items, and flesh out their story a little more. Conquest Mode is also where online co-op lives, although I couldn't get it to connect myself, but I'm hoping that gets ironed out in the coming weeks.

src=""http://digitalnipples.files.wordpress.com/2010/10/dynasty-warriors-7_2010_10-26-10_09_580.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""326"" />

Some other miscellaneous changes in this sequel: the graphics are really nice. From what I've read, the graphics have never quite caught up with the current run of consoles, and that's not the case with this installment: it looks great. The camera is still pretty frustrating, with a sticky tendency to focus on the ground somewhere in front of you rather than let you look around. They've added some platforming challenges in the maps, which is awkwardly executed and feels uncomfortable in context. They also removed the indicator which shows how the battle is swaying, which was always useful to me as a person who likes to get lost in the wilderness killing dudes while my base is being secretly assaulted. You're required to be much more attentive to mission points on the map.

All in all, this is an extremely satisfying addition to the series. If you didn't love Dynasty Warriors before, it's definitely not going to change your mind -- but if you do like the series, or you can appreciate some seriously satisfying mindlessness, it may be exactly what you need.

(Word of advice: don't pursue Lu Bu.)

- Kate

They've added the ability for you to choose two weapons that your general can switch between on the fly. Each character has their ideal weapon, or their EX weapon, which allows them a unique special attack. Most weapons also have a special ""seal"", which once unlocked can be applied to an empty slot on any other weapon. This new approach to weapons is pretty cool, but several characters share EX weapon types now instead of having totally unique ones as in the past, and the animations for those weapon attacks is identical between those characters. Kind of a visual bummer.

Besides Story Mode, Dynasty Warriors 7 also has Conquest Mode. Previous DW games had a Free Mode that allowed you to replay any level with any general. Conquest Mode has unique maps that are character-specific, where an unlocked character can level up, gather items, and flesh out their story a little more. Conquest Mode is also where online co-op lives, although I couldn't get it to connect myself, but I'm hoping that gets ironed out in the coming weeks.

src=""http://digitalnipples.files.wordpress.com/2010/10/dynasty-warriors-7_2010_10-26-10_09_580.jpg"" alt="""" width=""580"" height=""326"" />

Some other miscellaneous changes in this sequel: the graphics are really nice. From what I've read, the graphics have never quite caught up with the current run of consoles, and that's not the case with this installment: it looks great. The camera is still pretty frustrating, with a sticky tendency to focus on the ground somewhere in front of you rather than let you look around. They've added some platforming challenges in the maps, which is awkwardly executed and feels uncomfortable in context. They also removed the indicator which shows how the battle is swaying, which was always useful to me as a person who likes to get lost in the wilderness killing dudes while my base is being secretly assaulted. You're required to be much more attentive to mission points on the map.

All in all, this is an extremely satisfying addition to the series. If you didn't love Dynasty Warriors before, it's definitely not going to change your mind -- but if you do like the series, or you can appreciate some seriously satisfying mindlessness, it may be exactly what you need.

(Word of advice: don't pursue Lu Bu.)

- Kate

","

Pop Games: Dynasty Warriors 7
by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)

Pop TV: Camelot
by Andy Dugan

I had the opportunity to see a sneak peak of the pilot episode of Starz' new series ""Camelot."" I think Starz made a really good play with ""Spartacus: Blood and Sand"" and then even made that franchise better with ""Gods of the Arena!"" I must say, I watched ""Camelot"" with high expectations, and I did enjoy the show, but it's no ""Spartacus.""

column2: s (Sebastian Koch) sudden death, chaos threatens to engulf Britain. When the sorcerer Merlin (Joseph Fiennes) has visions of a dark future, he installs the young and impetuous Arthur (Jamie Campbell Bower), Uther&rsquo
column3: s unknown son and heir, who has been raised from birth as a commoner. But Arthur&rsquo
column4: s cold and ambitious half sister Morgan (Eva Green) will fight him to the bitter end, summoning unnatural forces to claim the crown in this epic battle for control. These are dark times indeed for the new king, with Guinevere (Tamsin Egerton) being the only shining light in Arthur&rsquo
column5: s harsh world. Faced with profound moral decisions, and the challenge of uniting a kingdom broken by war and steeped in deception, Arthur will be tested beyond imagination. Forget everything you think you know&hellip
column6: this is the story of Camelot that has never been told before.""

column2:
src=""http://www.starz.com/SiteCollectionImages/Camelot/Downloads/keyart_1920x1200.jpg"" alt="""" width=""560"" height=""349"" />

The casting in this show is creative. Eva Green's performance as Morgan is great&hellip
column3: I was at first a bit disappointed in the lead actor, Jamie Campbell Bower, who plays an immature and weak Arthur, and while sure, it may be part of the story, it made it hard for me to buy into this hero in the pilot episode as it went on. Then, in the last minutes of this episode, he breaks through, and the conflict he encounters brings out another side of him. Joseph Fiennes does a good job portraying a young Merlin, with a plan to keep evil away from the Kingdom, and is definitely my favorite character on the show at this point. I will stick around, I have faith in the Starz network, but with HBO's ""Game of Thrones"" on the way, every new episode of ""Camelot"" must get better and better. This show moves a lot slower than ""Spartacus"" and in the pilot there are not a whole lot of characters to get behind, unlike ""Spartacus.""

column1: I like this approach much more than Ridley Scott's ""Robin Hood"" film that came out last summer, which was also marketed as the ""story that's never been told.""

The smart move with this show is to not compare it to ""Spartacus"" because it's nothing like it. It does stand on it's own, and I'm going to endorse watching ""Camelot"" based on the faith I have in Starz at the moment&hellip
column2: and Eva Green, you really can't go wrong with her.

column1:
Check out the web site here: http://www.starz.com/Originals/Camelot. They currently have a sweepstakes going, where you can win a trip to England!

The Frame Rate: L.A. Comedy Shorts Film Festival
by Crix Lee

Hey, Kids! Looking for 4 days of non-stop laughs in the form of films, panels, celebs and parties?

Then the L.A. Comedy Shorts Film Festival is for you!

column3: 10 at the Downtown Independent Theater (251 S. Main St), LACSFF is touted as the largest comedy film festival in the US, introducing the freshest comedy talent to the industry in a very tongue-in-cheek kind of way. Even the people involved have a sense of humor!

column1: Actor and Artist Director Gary Anthony Williams (Boston Legal) proudly proclaims &ldquo
column3: ve scoured the solar system for the funniest short films ever seen (and not seen) and strategically crammed them into a jam-packed 4-day weekend of unforgiving stupid-funnility. This is science, folks. Funny Science,&rdquo
column4: and Festival Director Jeannie Roshar chimes in: &ldquo
column5: Some films have the power to change the World.&nbsp
column6: Our films have the power to change your mood. And then once you're in a better mood, go for it on the World-Changing thing!!&rdquo

column1: 85 short films have come from around the world to compete in hilariously titled screening blocks such as:

Filmmakers will compete for over $25,000 in cash and prizes in the following categories: The Funny or Die Best-of-Fest Grand Prize, Atom.com Best Comedy Short Film (30 minutes or less), Atomic Wedgie Best Comedy &lsquo
column3: Short (5 minutes or less) and Atom.com Best Animated Comedy Short (30 minutes or less), Elevate Best Student Short and the State Tax Credit Exchange Audience Choice Award.&nbsp
column5:
The Movie Magic Screenwriter Competition is also run in conjunction with the festival with screenwriters from around the world competing not only for over $10,000 in cash and prizes, but the winning scripts are read by some of the biggest agencies in the industry. The selected screenplays are separated into 3 categories: Feature, Half-Hour TV Pilots, and Shorts

Let's not forget the PARTIES!
column6: Opening night could find you at J Lounge for a little celebrity karaoke hosted by the ""King &
column7:
Queen of Karaoke"", Cedric Yarbrough (Reno 911, The Boondocks) and Mary Elizabeth Ellis (It's Always Sunny In Philadelphia). Sounds like fun, right?

You could also find yourself at Atom.com's ""Grown-Ass Kid"" party at ESPN Zone thrown in celebration of Atom's new series, Matumbo Goldberg, starring Anthony Anderson (Harold and Kumar Go to White Castle).
column8: Not only do you get to be among the first to see the first episode but you also get to run amok at the Zone's 10,000 sq. ft Sports Arena&hellip
column9:
with ALL of the interactive games and attractions set to FREE PLAY ALL NIGHT!!! Score!

BUT WAIT! THERE'S MORE!

Each day begins with insightful and delightful Industry Panels such as the popular &ldquo
column15:
and film screenings throughout the run of the festival in the afternoon and evenings.

TONS of your favorite comedy powerhouses will be in attendance throughout the festival including: Bryan Cranston (Breaking Bad), Julie Bowen (Modern Family), Wayne Brady, Mindy Sterling (Austin Powers),
column16: Scott Thompson (Kids In The Hall), James Urbaniak (The Venture Brothers), Boondocks creator Aaron McGruder, David Higgins (Malcolm In The Middle), Phil Lamarr (MAD TV),&nbsp
column17: Maurice LaMarche (Futurama), and SpongeBob Square Pants&rsquo

column2:
src=""http://www.esquire.com/cm/esquire/images/bryan-cranston-1007-lg.jpg"" alt="""" width=""460"" height=""307"" />

""So how do I get there?""

Simple! Advance tickets are available online at www.lacomedyshorts.com up to 12 hours before the start of the event.
column4: $50 for a Day Pass (which provides access to all screenings, panels and parties for that day)
column5: and $149 for a VIP All-Access Festival Pass, which includes priority entrance to all screenings, panels, parties as well as the Filmmaker Lounge and cocktail receptions at the theater. A limited number of tickets are also available for the Opening Night &ldquo
column7: Party and the Closing Night Red Carpet Awards Gala&hellip
column8:
so GET ON THAT.

For more information about LACSFF (including the festival's film schedule and images/video from last year's festival), just hit up the official website (www.lacomedyshorts.com). You can also follow them on Twitter (@lacomedyshorts) and Facebook facebook.com/lacomedyshorts

And I'll be there the entire time so if you see me, come say HI!

The Frame Rate: Make 'em laugh. Crix Approved

Pop Games: Alex and Kate Predict the Future
from Kate Welch (She Geek Show) and Alex McMillan

In a world cursed by its inability to predict future events in the game industry, fans are shocked by game delays, underwhelmed by hyped releases, and annoyed by pesky price points. Now, two brave individuals emerge from the woodwork of society and make themselves known from the masses of game journalists. Joined by their ability to foresee happenings in the gaming industry, they have but one mission: To write a kick-ass article about just that issue.
I am but one half of this dynamic duo, as guiding me along this long winding road of clairvoyance is none other than &lsquo
column3: herself, KW.  Fortune cookies and palm readings are all well and good, but if you want  hard hitting, on-the-pulse future-telling, you&rsquo
column4: ve found it. Please, join us, as Alex and Kate Predict the Future!

column1: Alex McMillan: Thank you very much for joining me today, Kate
AM: So, without further ado, let's get to our predicting!
KW : I've been exercising my clairvoyancey muscles for just this moment.

AM: Recently, RIFT, a new MMORPG has been released, and it's been getting a lot of praise for doing things differently from the standard MMO. With games like RIFT and Guild Wars 2, coming out and supposedly doing new and original things, do you think any of them can catch up with the momentum that World of Warcraft has, or is WoW now completely unstoppable?

KW: So I should start this prediction with the disclaimer that I currently work for ArenaNet developing Guild Wars 2, and that I am in no way an official spokesperson for them, and all the opinions I express about the MMO world are my own. Just to be clear.

There's a big problem when one talks about ""catching up to WoW"", because as you say, the momentum of it is pretty well established. There's inertia there. Not only do they have a huge chunk of the population already ensnared, but they've also had six and a half years on the market to draw from. They've rebalanced, retuned, and added content countless times.

They've got a base. Coming out with a brand new game can be really tough in that sense, because every MMO needs a little adjustment when it's released. That's usually enough to totally kill a new MMO -- when players start it up and it's not as polished as good ol' WoW, a great majority tend to dismiss it out of hand, because it's easier and comfortable to go back to Azeroth.

And of course, if all you do is parrot WoW with different monsters and different environments, you just simply won't win, because you're asking players to recreate the experience they've spent so much time on in WoW starting from nothing. Some people might like that, but most people, given a choice between WoW with 40 days /played across their characters, will choose WoW again.
So the secret sauce, I'm convinced, is finding out what bugs WoW players -- what makes them quit even if there's no temptation to play another MMO for them at that time -- and fix that.
I think that's what Guild Wars 2 and RIFT have both offered, and it's exciting as hell to WoW veterans who are tired of that formula.

AM: I think for anyone who is creating an MMO it's a very difficult balancing act. Especially as MMOs are a genre that completely relies on its player-base, the number of people playing is integral to the gaming experience. Like you say, you can't mimic WoW as then there's no incentive to switch, but at the same time you really can't be too different, otherwise there aren't enough people to play. Take the unfortunate case of All-Points Bulletin (APB) last year, which got completely shut down due to the lack of popularity. It was going for a very different angle and just didn't have the lasting power. I definitely think there is a way to take a large portion of WoW players, but I don't think anyone's found it yet
column2: like you say, a company needs to find the gripes WoW players have, and make a game without them. I'm really looking forward to Guild Wars 2 as a person who hasn't played MMOs properly before, and I think that is the other key market people making MMORPGs have to tap into, is that group of people who haven't felt the urge to play an MMORPG before, they need to figure out what can make that person want to play, while at the same time getting the audience of people who already play MMORPGs. It's an extremely complex problem with very little room for error.

column1: KW : Yeah, you're telling me! It's basically what I'm holding my head and groaning about all day long at work. But there's a lot of people who are in your same position -- intrigued by Guild Wars 2 because it's doing something different.

AM: I think nearly all MMOs suffer from growing pains in their initial release period. I don't think that's something they'll ever be able to get over, and that is one of those massive stumbling blocks games have. I think for a true WoW-killer, you have to make a great game that has no faults from day one, and that is a real challenge that I'm hoping Guild Wars 2 will overcome.

KW: It is important to be as flawless as possible if you're coming at a behemoth like WoW, certainly, but no game is perfect -- including WoW! Cataclysm was and still is riddled with bugs. When you have a concrete release game that has no evolution to it, just a one-off $60 game you buy on a console, you have to be much more focused on that. But the scope of an MMO is such that you simply can't be perfect at first pass. You're right, it's important. It's just tough to do it, and a lot of people swear it off easily when those problems start cropping up.

AM: So, it's been known for some time now that Gearbox, the studio behind Borderlands, has taken over the role of producing Duke Nukem Forever, which has been vapourware for I believe about 14 years now. If Duke Nukem proves a success, do you think we'll be seeing more old franchises rise from the dead, or is this a rare thing to happen?

KW: Honestly, I don't think it's going to inspire a trend -- and the reason why is because it's been such an infamous hopeless case for so long! There's a famous picture out there on the web of a guy who preordered it so long ago that his receipt is brown from age. It became a joke in the community, you know? Duke Nukem Forever was a metaphor for hopelessness.

Now that it's actually coming out, and looks awesome, that's cause for celebration -- but I don't think we'll see a revival. The generation of young kids who are gaming these days probably have no idea who Duke Nukem even is (which is fine, because I'm sure it's getting an M rating), so it'd be hard to remarket a long-dead series like that. My spidey sense says no on this prediction.

AM: I mean, there are certainly some franchises I would like to see make a comeback (Not as blast-from the past as Duke, but I need me some Timesplitters 4) but I don't know if it's enough of a driving force to bring something back just for the nostalgia factor. I really think DNF is a special case, it's become sort of a cult thing in its own way, but if it did really well, I think we may see studios at least talking more about old franchises. Whether or not that leads to revivals, I don't know, but I do think a lot of companies follow the successful trends, which it is very possible Duke Nukem could inspire.

KW: Studios do tend to follow the money, haha. I just think that it would take just as much energy to develop a captivating new IP as it would to reinvent an old franchise and market it to the current generation -- but that's just me. And don't believe for a moment that I wouldn't be SPRINTING out the door to buy a new Ecco the Dolphin game.

AM: I think if we do see revivals, they won't be well done. I think if a studio is gonna release an older franchise just for the money, they're not going to do it well. So, while a lot of us live in hope of that new Ecco the Dolphin game, I pray it doesn't fall into the wrong hands.
KW: Amen. Don't get me started on studios that make games just because of the name tied to 'em... that's a whole article of Kate Welch ranting her brain out right there.
AM: If I set off the Kate Welch-rant trigger here, I doubt I'll be able to stop it :L
KW: I can nerd rage for days.

AM: One thing that really made me hopeful of Duke Nukem Forever is that Randy Pitchford (Head of Gearbox) says that he ""needs this as a gamer"". I honestly believe he's doing it from the angle of a gamer, rather than that of a businessman.
KW: Oh agreed. At this point, DNF is a labor of love. After all this time... hats off to Gearbox.

AM: And on that optimistic note, we'll move onto our next hot topic: Call of Duty, the unstoppable FPS train. So, there's been a countdown timer supposedly for the next Modern Warfare game. Now whether or not it is for Modern Warfare 3, as far as we know, there are about three Call of Duty games being worked on at the moment. The time between CoD titles is getting smaller and smaller, do you think it's going to continue to shrink, and do you think this will affect the games in any way?

KW: I think this is a question with a complex answer. Activision is getting a lot of bad press lately. There was a big breakdown of how they managed to gut the Guitar Hero series, and they're the first to bump their PC games up to $60 to match console prices. So it's kind of hard to answer this question without thinking it's them being somewhat evil.
But I think it just comes down to dollars and cents, sadly. Call of Duty games are consistently #1 on the sales charts when they release. It's a matter of brand loyalty
column2: people will always go buy a Call of Duty game because they are consistently impressive, but also because they know all their friends are going to be playing it too.

column1: If the window shrinks any more than it currently stands right now, it'll be amazing -- I can't imagine developing a quality title for multiple platforms in less than a year, but that's exactly what they're doing. If they continue to whittle that window down, you'll definitely see a dip in quality and a spike in DLC offerings. It's all a balancing act -- you can't have it good, cheap, AND fast.

AM: I think it's only now that the window between titles has become really noticable, I mean, if we are getting a new one announced soon, that'll be about a three/four month gap between last release and latest announcement. I mean, as you say, you can't keep the quality up and continue to decrease the time they have to make it, so I think Activision have changed their strategy. I mean, obviously

they've been having Infinity Ward and Treyarch rotate throughout the past couple of years, but now they've also apparently got Raven working on a CoD title, and then they're apparently making a game about Ghost, and on top of that you hear about them making a Call of Duty game for the NGP. They seem to be biting a lot off, and if they want to keep the quality standards up I think they need to pace themselves.

KW: Totally agreed. They look at Call of Duty and see a cash cow and they're milking it ferociously. Which, I mean, if it works out, good for them. I feel a little disdainful because FPS games are never my favorites -- I suck at 'em. So I don't get the hype. But millions of other people do, clearly.

AM: I've always liked FPS's but not more-so than other genres, and cetainly Call of Duty has never been a clear favourite, I usually prefer games that do things sort of differently. I reckon it just comes down to ""My friend has CoD, so if I get CoD we can play CoD together!"". And Activision can say it's because they produce the best shooters, but no matter how they spin it, it comes down to having a lot of people playing, and people wanting to play together.
KW: Yep -- and each person has to buy a copy in order to play! Cha-ching!
AM: I mean, you can't really blame Activision for liking money, can you?
KW: No, I can't. We have that in common, Activision and I.

AM: So, we move on swiftly like a greased leopard to a subject I'm sure you'll be able to discuss eternally, Batman (and other superheroes). Arkham City is coming soon and is looking fabulous, and we're seeing a lot of games about Superheroes being announced, most recently we had Thor: God of Thunder announced at the VGAs. Do you think we'll be seeing more characters leaping from the comic book to the console, and do you think they will fall victim to being cash-ins?

Making movie spin-off games isn't a new phenomenon at all, so we'll likely be getting the Thor and Captain America and Green Lantern video games coming out alongside their movie counterparts. Then, of course, you have games like Arkham Asylum and Spider-Man: Shattered Dimensions that didn't have a direct movie correlation
column2: it's my belief that, like the films, these games are a way for Marvel and DC to start making revenue again. It's no secret that the comic book industry has been down on its luck when it comes to people buying comics themselves, but people are voracious about consuming those characters as movies and video games. That's not going to change, I don't think.

column1: There's an upswing in comics readership that's happened since the advent of the iPad and the comic reader/store apps that came along with it. Which is AWESOME, of course. But if anything, I think that introducing these comics to an audience that may never have though to purchase them as individual issues will only increase the interest in seeing those characters in other media forms. Now, whether those games will be any good...

I mean, Arkham Asylum ruled. Shattered Dimensions seemed awesome in concept, but lacked in execution. There aren't many other superhero video games that you can point to and say ""they did it right."" It's a very tough thing to do. Games are mechanical and often lack the grace you want to impart to a character on-screen or in a comic book.

So I don't have the highest hopes in terms of quality -- but I'm always on board to see a character show up in its own video game. Will I buy Thor: God of Thunder? Most def. And that's all they want from me anyway.

AM: So, we move to our final future-telling of the day, and it is on the subject of sequels. This year we could see more game sequels than ever before, with some of the biggest releases of the year announced so far being Uncharted 3, Portal 2, Mass Effect 3, Killzone 3 and Gears of War 3. Do you think in the years to come we'll be seeing more sequels, or are we going to start seeing more original IPs?

KW: 2011 is definitely the year of the sequel. When I did my episode about top five mainstream games, I was making a list of every game I was excited about this year and I think maybe two out of 10 of them were original IPs.

But I don't think that is anything to be concerned about. Every sequel that you just named, and a handful of others I can think of, is massively exciting -- because the properties are totally awesome. Maybe you can call it uncreative to just continue the formula that made you successful and popular the first time around, but I don't think it's such a bad thing. If people want to play another game -- if your community has been demanding a sequel, pounding down your door for one -- and you are excited to do it, I think that's a win/win situation.

I find it really interesting when an original IP comes along in a sea of sequels -- like LA Noire, for instance. It tends to stand out more. It's much easier and more comfortable to gamble on a sure thing.

Will we see more Years of the Sequels in the future? Probably so. There was an article I read recently about how game devs should appreciate their pirates and treat them as future paying customers -- let them pirate your first game, give them great support, and they're more likely to convert when you develop a sequel.
Not IF you develop a sequel -- but WHEN.

And game piracy is so rampant that it's just a fact that you have to figure out how you're going to deal with them, not worry whether you'll have to. So if you release Mass Effect 1, and half the people who play it pirate it and like it, you're more likely to have some of those pirates buy Mass Effect 2, and more who will buy Mass Effect 3.

So yeah, sequels are going to keep coming out. It sort of stinks if you don't like any of the current offerings, but most people are excited, I think. And if you hate 'em, there's always the luscious world of indie gaming that's calling to you.

AM: I think a lot of people see sequels as lazy, and in some cases it's true, but nowadays, it's just good business. People liked Dead Space, that's why we got Dead Space 2. People wanted another Portal, so we're getting Portal 2. It's serving to the general population of gamers, certainly, but if a game is good, people are going to want more, so more sequels could be seen as a blessing and a curse as you say, there is no lack of creativity and innovation, especially in the indie game market. I mean, take breakthrough hit Minecraft for example.
KW: Yeah, that's a great example. Minecraft has been a phenomenon.
I don't think too many of the sequels on track for this year are being developed ""just because"" or anything. I think there was huge demand, and the studios are trying to satisfy that demand.
AM: Kate, I'd like to thank you for taking the time today to predict the future with me
KW: Of course! I also predict that this interview will be a huge hit.
AM: That's very kind of you to say, it's been an absolute pleasure.
KW: The pleasure is all mine! Thanks Alex!

It's no secret that the comic book industry has been down on its luck when it comes to people buying comics themselves, but people are voracious about consuming those characters as movies and video games. That's not going to change, I don't think.

column1: There's an upswing in comics readership that's happened since the advent of the iPad and the comic reader/store apps that came along with it. Which is AWESOME, of course. But if anything, I think that introducing these comics to an audience that may never have though to purchase them as individual issues will only increase the interest in seeing those characters in other media forms. Now, whether those games will be any good...

I mean, Arkham Asylum ruled. Shattered Dimensions seemed awesome in concept, but lacked in execution. There aren't many other superhero video games that you can point to and say ""they did it right."" It's a very tough thing to do. Games are mechanical and often lack the grace you want to impart to a character on-screen or in a comic book.

So I don't have the highest hopes in terms of quality -- but I'm always on board to see a character show up in its own video game. Will I buy Thor: God of Thunder? Most def. And that's all they want from me anyway.

AM: So, we move to our final future-telling of the day, and it is on the subject of sequels. This year we could see more game sequels than ever before, with some of the biggest releases of the year announced so far being Uncharted 3, Portal 2, Mass Effect 3, Killzone 3 and Gears of War 3. Do you think in the years to come we'll be seeing more sequels, or are we going to start seeing more original IPs?

KW: 2011 is definitely the year of the sequel. When I did my episode about top five mainstream games, I was making a list of every game I was excited about this year and I think maybe two out of 10 of them were original IPs.

But I don't think that is anything to be concerned about. Every sequel that you just named, and a handful of others I can think of, is massively exciting -- because the properties are totally awesome. Maybe you can call it uncreative to just continue the formula that made you successful and popular the first time around, but I don't think it's such a bad thing. If people want to play another game -- if your community has been demanding a sequel, pounding down your door for one -- and you are excited to do it, I think that's a win/win situation.

I find it really interesting when an original IP comes along in a sea of sequels -- like LA Noire, for instance. It tends to stand out more. It's much easier and more comfortable to gamble on a sure thing.

Will we see more Years of the Sequels in the future? Probably so. There was an article I read recently about how game devs should appreciate their pirates and treat them as future paying customers -- let them pirate your first game, give them great support, and they're more likely to convert when you develop a sequel.
Not IF you develop a sequel -- but WHEN.

And game piracy is so rampant that it's just a fact that you have to figure out how you're going to deal with them, not worry whether you'll have to. So if you release Mass Effect 1, and half the people who play it pirate it and like it, you're more likely to have some of those pirates buy Mass Effect 2, and more who will buy Mass Effect 3.

So yeah, sequels are going to keep coming out. It sort of stinks if you don't like any of the current offerings, but most people are excited, I think. And if you hate 'em, there's always the luscious world of indie gaming that's calling to you.

AM: I think a lot of people see sequels as lazy, and in some cases it's true, but nowadays, it's just good business. People liked Dead Space, that's why we got Dead Space 2. People wanted another Portal, so we're getting Portal 2. It's serving to the general population of gamers, certainly, but if a game is good, people are going to want more, so more sequels could be seen as a blessing and a curse as you say, there is no lack of creativity and innovation, especially in the indie game market. I mean, take breakthrough hit Minecraft for example.
KW: Yeah, that's a great example. Minecraft has been a phenomenon.
I don't think too many of the sequels on track for this year are being developed ""just because"" or anything. I think there was huge demand, and the studios are trying to satisfy that demand.
AM: Kate, I'd like to thank you for taking the time today to predict the future with me
KW: Of course! I also predict that this interview will be a huge hit.
AM: That's very kind of you to say, it's been an absolute pleasure.
KW: The pleasure is all mine! Thanks Alex!

145,"0","Pop Games: Dance Central","Pop Games: Dance Central","","",,"

Pop Games: Dance Central
by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)

Since Kinect's widely-marketed launch last holiday season, the landscape of Kinect games has been kinda dismal. The Kinect is cool and has really interesting potential (as many excellent Youtube videos of Kinect hacks have shown us), but so far there hasn't been much that's creatively and effectively utilizing the tech.

So today, I'm going to review for you a game that launched with Kinect and is still its best offering: Dance Central from Harmonix.

Harmonix does a lot of things well. They know how to capture the tone of a particular phenomenon and express it through design. Rock Band and Guitar Hero made you feel like an ultra cool rock star, even though you were playing on a dorky little plastic game peripheral. Dance Central has continued this trend through design and interface, capturing the glamour and glitz of the nightclub scene.

Let me pause here and draw your attention to that last bit: the ""nightclub scene"" is not one I frequent. I think I've been to a nightclub once, and I think it was '80s night, so it's not representative of the same club culture that you'll find in Dance Central. About half the songs in the playlist were new to me, and frankly, I found them to be kind of a turnoff. When Guitar Hero came out, I was still pretty young and it introduced me to a lot of great, must-hear music that had passed me by. This is not the case with Dance Central.

That said, they are a hell of a lot of fun to dance to.

The gameplay is exactly what you would expect: a kookily-dressed character dances on screen, you dance the same way, and the closer you match what they do, the higher your score. It starts out easy with some Gaga and M.I.A., but by the time you're in the third tier, you are sweating bullets. Dance Central is a good goddamn workout. (There's even a workout mode, where you enter your weight and it tracks your calories and time. Love it.)

There are a couple downfalls to this game. One, although the game encourages you to get up and join your friends as a ""backup dancer"", your backup moves aren't tracked by the Kinect's sensors, so it's really just for fun and not for points. What this means (in my experience so far, anyway) is that you end up taking turns with friends playing Dance Central, which is sort of embarrassing for someone like me, a master of the awkward flail. There's a dance battle mode where you can compete on the same song for the higher score, but -- eh. This needs multiplayer support or real-time dance battles. Anything else is just a glorified way of handing off the controller.

Things I've learned by playing Dance Central so far: one, I absolutely rule at Maneater
column2:
and two, I absolutely suck at all hip hop dance moves. I'll get you yet, Soulja Boy.

- Kate

Comics @ War
Matt Jacobs

&ldquo
column3: re Oscar Mike for war comics!&rdquo
column4: With the hype of a World War II ""Captain America"" movie releasing this summer, we&rsquo
column5: re going to see an influx of war themed comics and movies as we do every few years. Nothing like we saw back in the Silver Age with ""Sgt. Rock,"" ""Sgt. Fury"" and ""The Unknown Soldier,"" (just to name a few) but there is something about WWII that brings out the inner patriot in all of us.

column2: we knew our enemy and had a unified cause as a nation, the fight for freedom across the globe. Everyone understood why we were fighting and everyone stood behind the soldiers. Regardless of your beliefs on war, you can&rsquo
column3: t deny the entire nation had a sense of &lsquo
column6: t been seen since. With so much controversy surrounding our current military actions, it&rsquo
column7: s nice to think about a time when war was more &lsquo
column9:
.

Here are some other more recent war comics to get your patriotic juices flowing:

1)
column10: Battlefields - Created and Written by Garth Ennis, this series brings to light lesser-known stories and conflicts of WWII.&nbsp
column11: Ennis focuses on the extraordinary stories of relatively ordinary soldiers. Not Super Soldiers or Special Forces, but people that battled against all odds to overcome unimaginable tasks. Ennis is no stranger to war fiction from his other series (War Story, Unknown Soldier, Adventures of the Rifle Brigade) and really brings his A-game to this series.

column1: 2) I Am Legion - The long awaited hardcover edition of Humanoids came out last year and was worth the wait. This series brings a supernatural take on World War II as the Nazis search for a girl with the ability to posses other bodies. The artwork of superstar artist John Cassaday (Astonishing X-Men and Planetary) is beautiful and the roller coaster story will keep you reading.
column4: s Army - This graphic novel is based on the video game of the same name and focuses on the storyline behind the game. One of my favorite parts of this series is actually not the comic itself, but the motion comic that was produced as part of this series. They definitely did their research and the production value is pretty high. The strong voice overs and great sound design really pull you in. Both the graphic novel and motion comics are available for free on the game&rsquo
column7:
/>

4) The Other Side - This series set in the Vietnam war tells parallel stories of an American solider and a VC soldier fighting for their respective countries. Both characters struggle to deal with the horrors of war and how it affects their soul and sanity. Jason Aaron does an amazing job capturing the tone of this war and really brings the human element to an inhumane setting.

column5: re not the only country with our own Super Soldier like Captain America. In the Philippines a new hero named Ameer, a mixture of Batman and Zorro, is fighting terrorists across the Sulu islands which were once a terrorist safe haven. The series depicts real events that took place on the Islands to illustrate the atrocities of the terrorists. 600,000 copies of this 10 part series have been distributed in the country, that&rsquo
column6: s some powerful propaganda.

column1: The truth is that comics have always played a part in propaganda during times of war and conflict, as we saw with Captain America back in the day fighting Hitler. The ability of a comic book to deliver a message to the masses is no doubt a powerful tool.

column3:
/>

If you want to dig deeper into how comics have played a role in propaganda and PSYOPS (Psychological Operations) throughout history, this blog post compiles a great list: http://www.psywarrior.com/PsyopComics.html

Now get your gear and go read some Comics @ War, soldier!

147,"0","The Frame Rate: The New Guys at NBC","The Frame Rate: The New Guys at NBC","","",,"

The Frame Rate: The New Guys at NBC
by Crix Lee

Two gentleman made their debut to NBC's Thursday Night line up in the form of The Paul Reiser Show and Will Ferrell's first day on The Office.
column2:
Let's get started, shall we?

First up, The Paul Reiser Show.
column3: It's pretty much what I thought it was going to be. I've been a fan of Reiser's since the film ""Diner"" and was fairly stoked to see him coming back to network tv, I really was.&nbsp
column4: But the problem is I've seen this show before, when it was called ""The Comeback"" and starred Lisa Kudrow - a mock reality show that followed 80's sitcom star Valerie Cherish (Kudrow) documenting her triumphant yet difficult return to, you guessed it: network tv.

column1: <param name=""allowFullScreen"" value=""true"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""288"" src=""http://www.hulu.com/embed/sxYBQfHNjs5dhtcdXguXQw"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>

The Paul Reiser Show has a similar flavor, only Reiser plays a fictionalized version himself, using it to his advantage and showing people the RIDICULOUS things we as actors will put up with in Hollywood.
column2: It's nice to see him just being him and jokingly admitting to guest star Larry David that he is a ""little bit of a douchebag"" because let's face it -&nbsp
column3:
if you live in L.A., you're a little bit of a douchebag, too.

The Paul Reiser Show is unapologetically a mix of The Comeback + Entourage + Curb Your Enthusiasm and has no problems owning up to it. Larry David sums it up best when he tells Reiser over lunch that he SHOULD do a reality show&hellip
column4:
Like 'Curb Your Enthusiasm', only with you"".

So was it a rousing success? Probably not. Did I enjoy it? Absolutely. I think it's okay if it had a wobbly first night, considering it's awkward premiere date and the now what is quickly becoming known as the ""Kiss of Death""
column5:
8:30 time slot. I know a LOT of my colleagues are drinking the Haterade but I really think this show deserves another episode to find its groove and if it STILL doesn't work, thanks for playing.

Then there's Will Ferrell's first day at The Office.
column8: So as EVERYONE knows, Steve Carell is leaving the show and Ferrell has stepped in as successor to the Dunder-Mifflin management throne, Deangelo Vickers.
column9: In last week's episode, Michael and Holly get engaged (yay!) and announce they're
column10: moving to Colorado to take care of Holly's rather senile parents (boo!). So when Vickers first arrives in this episode, the entire office sees this as a ""do-over"" of sorts to curry favor with the new boss (except for Dwight, of course).&nbsp
column11: He seems like a nice enough fellow - likable, handsome, nice sense of humor&hellip
column12:
Then it gets a little weird.

It's soon evident that Vickers is ready to start changing things in the office that Michael himself implemented during his tenure, much to Michael's dismay (but says nothing).
column13: The more it seems the gang (minus Dwight, of course) loves the new boss, the more Michael starts to feel unappreciated and swiftly begins to resent Vickers' arrival&hellip
column14:
with strange yet funny results.

What works: the chemistry between Michael and Vickers is GREAT. Carell and Farrell are AWESOME as two grown men in a position of power who act like they're in the 5th grade. I've always been a fan of both these men and to see them together in a place like this is like a dream come true. The subtlety of their comedic timing is unparalleled.

In the first few minutes of Michael and Vickers running around together joking and laughing, I was immediately reminded of the Step Brothers music montage when Brennan and Dale become friends and run around and do silly stuff.
column15: I actually said ""So, are they gonna be going to the f***in Catalina Wine Mixer, too, or what?""

column1: <param name=""allowFullScreen"" value=""true"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""288"" src=""http://www.hulu.com/embed/bxPDnQS-LO034TruRUgjuw"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>
Carell's only gonna be around for so long and then it's up to Farrell to fly solo.
column2: While I have no doubts that Farrell's up to the challenge, I'm not too sure if I'll like the new atmosphere, the new boss, you name it - which is pretty much what ANY worker drone feels when an old boss leaves and a new one comes in, a GENIUS move on the writers' part.&nbsp
column3: I'm actually MORE curious to see how much Jim is gonna be able to get away with once Michael is gone. Is Vickers JUST as dumb as Michael or is this all some sort of elaborate ruse? Will Dwight finally find that ally he's always wanted?

column1: <param name=""allowFullScreen"" value=""true"" /><embed type=""application/x-shockwave-flash"" width=""512"" height=""288"" src=""http://www.hulu.com/embed/2Rf-WSQ4LOUdw3rLzMKk2A"" allowfullscreen=""true""></embed>
I REALLY don't want to say this, BUT&hellip
column2: I have a suspicion that The Office has one more season after this and then it's done. And unfortunately, the finger might be pointed at Will Ferrell in an almost ""Cousin Oliver"" kind of way (re: The Brady Bunch) as the catalyst to the show's demise.&nbsp
column3:
Admittedly, it's gonna take a couple more eps for me to fully accept his arrival to Dunder-Mifflin but much like the corporate world, I gotta accept and adapt.

But let's face it: just as David Brent was the heart of The Office UK, Michael Scott is the heart and SOUL of The Office US.
column5:
The Frame Rate

The Paul Reiser Show: Funny and likable. I could use a couple more episodes but all in all, Crix Approved (with reservations).

Will Ferrell/The Office: Welcome to Dunder-Mifflin, sir. I, too, love the Southwest. Crix Approved.

","

148,"0","Pop TV: A GAME OF THRONES","Pop TV: A GAME OF THRONES","","",,"

Pop TV: A GAME OF THRONES
by Jason Badower

column9: >You remember that kid at school. The one with the greasy hair and awkward walk? They had that ever changing roster of thick novels that adorned their pile of math and English books. Maybe you caught a glimpse of those novels. Lord of the Rings? The Hobbit? Dragons of some seasonal time of the day or something.
>Power tripping adventures for pubescent kids to pretend they're great warriors slaying even greater dragons.

>And then Peter Jackson had to go and make Lord of the Rings. And every Christmas, no matter how cool you thought you were, you, or someone you know very well lined up at the cinemas next to that kid to see the next installment of this amazing trilogy. And despite the fact that Lord of the Rings went on to win as many Oscars as Titanic you still think that fantasy is still the realm of greasy, awkward pubescent boys. The exception is not the norm, right?
>But what if I told you that there's another Lord of the Rings on the horizon?

column18: >It's the first book in a series of seven novels by master novelist, George R.R. Martin and it's been made into an HBO tv series. That's right. The people who made Deadwood, The Wire, Band of Brothers, The Sopranos and True Blood are now tackling this epic fantasy series.

column9: >But there's a distinction between Lord of the Rings and A Game Of Thrones.
column49: >. Lord of the Rings is
column65: > a fictional world whose stories are driven by the introduction of bizarre inhuman fantasy races and monsters. A Game of Thrones is
column81: > which creates a fictional world generally set in medieval times to explore complex politics, interactions and the human condition through events that never happened. Sometimes there's magic or monsters, but they're played subtly and quietly and they're more about how they affect us as people and the choices we make.
column89: >A Game of Thrones is an alternate world whose wondrous geography and magnificent politics contribute to a vast story of humanity , complexity and drama. But why should you care about a fictional world? Because the people in it are so unflinchingly us. In reading it, I've been awed by the distinctive characters, memorable names and complex, unflinching relationships between people, cities, churches and states.

column9: >This is not a fantasy for kids. A Game of Thrones is a story for mature, intelligent adults. It's a story for us, about us.

column63: >TAGS:  HBO, George R.R. Martin, A Game Of Thrones, A Song of Ice &amp
column64:
Fire, Sean Bean, Lena Headley, Fantasy, Lord of the Rings, The Hobbit.

149,"0","The Frame Rate: Game of Thrones ","The Frame Rate: Game of Thrones ","","",,"

The Frame Rate: Game of Thrones
by Crix Lee
Last night was THE night that people have been talking about for months: the world premiere of HBO's new series, Game of Thrones.
Based on the first book of George R.R. Martin's 7 book fantasy series, ""A Song of Fire and Ice"", Game of Thrones hit the ground running with an a VERY in your debut&hellip
column2: which I find extremely fitting for this kind of genre. &nbsp

column1: For those like me who haven't read the novels nor have played the card, board, or Role Playing Games before
column2: the idea of having to meet and remember four of the seven families in the Seven Kingdoms in 45 minutes can seem a bit overwhelming, without question. Luckily, HBO thought of that and were smart enough to present a 25 minute ""Making of"" special that aired before the show's premiere. &nbsp

column1: There are times when casting can make or break a show before the pilot even airs&hellip
column2: we've all seen it happen before. While this COULD'VE been the case with GoT, it's clear HBO knew what they were doing casting Sean Bean, best known for his role as Boromir from The Lord of The Rings: The Fellowship of The Ring. &nbsp

column1: In LOTR, Boromir was not only a soldier who was greatly admired for his great strength and prowess on the battlefield
column2: he was also an honorable and noble man who loved his kingdom who would die (and did) to defend it. In GoT, Bean steps into a similar role as Eddard Stark, Lord of Winterfell and Warden of The North
column3: known for his strong sense of honor and loyalty.&nbsp
column4: In this aspect, fans automatically accept Bean in this role and are more willing to invest in not only Stark but the relationships of those in the Seven Kingdoms as well. &nbsp

column1: A lot of comparisons have been made to LOTR and it's hard NOT to, considering the setting, story, and characters (Martin has been called 'The American Tolkien' on more than one occasion) but that's really where the similarities end.
In LOTR, you won't find twins engaged in an incestual relationship (that one, I actually called)
column2: a brother (who is an evil DOUCHEBAG, btw) evaluating his 15 year old sister's naked body for flaws (EW) before marrying her off against her will
column3: or seeing a man disemboweled in a fight after being interrupted mid-coitus with a concubine (in full view of everyone) at a wedding celebration where if at least three people DON'T die, is considered a dull affair&hellip
column4: but you WILL find these things in GoT.&nbsp

column2: but there's NOTHING about this show I didn't like. I audibly gasped a few times and yelled things like ""I KNEW IT"", ""EW"" and ""OH MY GOD"" on several occasions.&nbsp
column3: This show is extremely visceral, violent, and doesn't ""PG"" anything, as evidenced in the first FIVE minutes of the show&hellip
column4: I yelled ""OMG"" ""What the f*** is that?! RUN!!!!""

column1: ""IS this show good for kids under 13?""
Considering the opening sequence shows a tableau of murdered and dismembered villagers (including children), a seemingly dead child spiked to a tree and with what transpires immediately after
column2: probably not. NO one is safe in this series and it could be a hard thing to explain to your kids why it's NOT okay for a brother and sister to have sex or why someone would throw a kid out a window.&nbsp

column1: There's definitely a 'must be this tall to ride' feel to this show. Use your best judgment but if you're considering whether or not your young'un can see this show, I'd HIGHLY recommend watching it first on your own.

The storyline is so intricate that it would be IMPOSSIBLE to be as thorough as I'd like without writing a novel of my own and you really should watch yourself, at any rate. We're talking loyalty, politics, espionage, murder, sex, deception, and VERY strange sibling relationships.
column2: I wouldn't call it ""excessively violent"", though&hellip
column3: I'd actually classify this as ""appropriately violent"" as nothing is gratuitous and serves purpose within the storyline.

column1: Another thing they did that I really dig is that in the opening credits, the corresponding character's crest is shown next to the actor's name&hellip
column2: which also helped me figure out who's who.&nbsp

column1: Again, the first episode may SEEM a bit overwhelming but trust me it'll be worth it. How worth it? I've watched the first episode 4 times yesterday and has been playing in the background as I'm writing this. Game of Thrones is a truly cinematic masterpiece made for the small screen. Even the cast is ridiculously good looking for different reasons and have a feeling that Daenerys (played by Emilia Clarke) who'll give Sookie Stackhouse some SERIOUS competition.

column2: Keep an eye on Peter Dinklage, who is BRILLIANT as Tyrion Lannister -&nbsp
column3: he steals every scene he's in without even trying and looks DAMN sexy as a blonde.

column1: And because I love this show so much, I'm gonna give you a little pressie. Here's the official making of GoT that aired before last night's premiere, provided by their official YouTube channel!
IF you haven't read the books and are afraid you won't be able to catch on quickly, watch this video first and you'll be ready to hit the Seven Kingdoms in no time.

The Frame Rate: Winter is coming. #CrixApproved

column1:
150,"0","Pop Games: A Game Of Thrones: Genesis","by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)","","",,"

Pop Games: A Game Of Thrones: Genesis
by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)

The geek world is all atwitter (no pun intended) with talk of the Game of Thrones premiere on HBO this past Sunday. The premiere did marvelous justice to a book series worshipped by geeks everywhere, with an absolute minimum of tweaks and changes to make it work on the screen. Old fans and new get to enjoy the visual richness that HBO is bringing to life in Westeros and beyond.

But did you know there are video games in the works for Game of Thrones as well? Of course there are.

Cyanide Studio, a 60-person French game developer based in Paris with a smaller 15-person studio in Montreal, secured the rights to George R. R. Martin's book series in 2009. They've been developing two games since then.

The first game slated to be released is titled A Game of Thrones: Genesis, a turn-based strategy game for PC. The campaign was written under direct supervision of ol' George himself, which is reassuring, and spans over 1000 years of Westerosi history, allowing the player to participate in critical events only mentioned in the book series (like the War of the Usurper, where Robert and Eddard won the Iron Throne away from the Targaryens).
In true Game of Thrones style, it isn't just your military prowess or brute strength that'll win battles in this strategy game. There are multiple ways to deal defeat to your enemies
column2: you can choose to force them out through an economic standoff, or manipulate the politics of the realm to fight dirty. The Sid Meier's Civilization series already uses similar tactics to achieve victory, so it will be interesting to see how Cyanide manages to make this feel like something more than a Civ clone.

column1:
A Game of Thrones: Genesis is currently slated as a summer 2011 release.

The second of the two games Cyanide is developing is shrouded much more deeply in mystery. It's an as-yet-untitled RPG being developed for both PC and next-gen consoles, but there's no release date or any other kind of information.

The screenshots that have been released for Genesis look pretty good, albeit pretty generic stuff when it comes to RTS. The RPG looks like an Elder Scrolls game -- not a bad thing, but again, it gives it the feeling of a knockoff.
Cyanide's release titles to date have been sports strategy games like Horce Racing Manager and most recently the adaption of Blood Bowl
column2: they don't have anything RTS or RPG related under their belts. We'll just have to wait and see if they can do justice to the series the way HBO apparently can.

column1:

Pop Games: A Game Of Thrones: Genesis
by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)

The geek world is all atwitter (no pun intended) with talk of the Game of Thrones premiere on HBO this past Sunday. The premiere did marvelous justice to a book series worshipped by geeks everywhere, with an absolute minimum of tweaks and changes to make it work on the screen. Old fans and new get to enjoy the visual richness that HBO is bringing to life in Westeros and beyond.

But did you know there are video games in the works for Game of Thrones as well? Of course there are.

Cyanide Studio, a 60-person French game developer based in Paris with a smaller 15-person studio in Montreal, secured the rights to George R. R. Martin's book series in 2009. They've been developing two games since then.

The first game slated to be released is titled A Game of Thrones: Genesis, a turn-based strategy game for PC. The campaign was written under direct supervision of ol' George himself, which is reassuring, and spans over 1000 years of Westerosi history, allowing the player to participate in critical events only mentioned in the book series (like the War of the Usurper, where Robert and Eddard won the Iron Throne away from the Targaryens).
In true Game of Thrones style, it isn't just your military prowess or brute strength that'll win battles in this strategy game. There are multiple ways to deal defeat to your enemies
column2: you can choose to force them out through an economic standoff, or manipulate the politics of the realm to fight dirty. The Sid Meier's Civilization series already uses similar tactics to achieve victory, so it will be interesting to see how Cyanide manages to make this feel like something more than a Civ clone.

column1:
A Game of Thrones: Genesis is currently slated as a summer 2011 release.

The second of the two games Cyanide is developing is shrouded much more deeply in mystery. It's an as-yet-untitled RPG being developed for both PC and next-gen consoles, but there's no release date or any other kind of information.

The screenshots that have been released for Genesis look pretty good, albeit pretty generic stuff when it comes to RTS. The RPG looks like an Elder Scrolls game -- not a bad thing, but again, it gives it the feeling of a knockoff.
Cyanide's release titles to date have been sports strategy games like Horce Racing Manager and most recently the adaption of Blood Bowl
column2: they don't have anything RTS or RPG related under their belts. We'll just have to wait and see if they can do justice to the series the way HBO apparently can.

153,"0","The Frame Rate: LA NOIRE","The Frame Rate: LA NOIRE","","",,"

The Frame Rate: LA NOIRE
by Crix Lee

Yeah yeah, it's not a film or a tv show&hellip
column2:
but after you read this, you'll know WHY I'm talking about it today.

Working in the gaming industry, I sometimes get caught up in certain game titles from the FIRST day I see a trailer or an early build of said game. Last week, I was summoned to the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel and treated to a private demo of Rockstar Games' HIGHLY anticipated title, L.A. Noire.

OH MY GAH, you guys. Where to begin?

In L.A. Noire, you are L.A.P.D Detective Cole Phelps (Aaron Staton, Mad Men) in a post-war setting where corruption, drugs, and murder are exploding at an alarming rate.
column3: Phelps must dig deep to solve a number of cases that include a serial arsonist, racketeering conspiracies, savage murders, the L.A. underworld and exposing police corruption that could bring the city to its knees.&nbsp
column4: As Phelps, you'll explore every bit of Los Angeles ca. 1947 in ""an open-ended challenge to solve a series of murder mysteries"" from different departments of the L.A.P.D.

column1: If you're sitting there thinking ""Well, this sounds like L.A. Confidential meets Chinatown"", you'd be absolutely right&hellip
column3:
Inspired by infamous cases like The Black Dahlia murders, L.A. Noire does NOT hold back on ANYTHING and nothing is censored.

Phelps has cases in Traffic, Arson, Homicide, and Vice
column4: with a different partner assigned to him in each case.&nbsp
column5: In the case that I was shown, ""The Red Lipstick Murder"" (Homicide desk) is based on the 1947 unsolved murder of Jeanne French and the in game crime scene shows a woman who'd been brutally murdered and things written on her nude body in red lipstick
column6:
including the initials ""B.D."" (Black Dahlia murder had happened weeks before French's death, initially leading police to work both the serial killer and copycat angles)



And when I say ""nude"", I mean NUDE.
column7: But the thing about it is that for a split second, you're like ""Oh wow, she's TOTALLY FULL FRONTAL naked"" then brush it off as you study her body for clues and research the crime scene and because Forensics were on the scene before you, everything is marked so you can go from clue to clue somewhat effortlessly.&nbsp
column8: Each site includes a very subtle music cue similar to what you would find in films in the forms of ""investigation music"" and a two fingered piano trill that indicates that there's a clue nearby and when all clues are collected
column10:
But remember this: NOT everything you find is relevant to the case. IF you want a bit of a challenge, you can turn the music off. Once the crime scene is clear, it's time to start pounding the pavement and interrogating suspects.

Here's where it gets really interesting. Because L.A. Noire uses motion scan technology to capture the actor's subtle nuances and facial expressions in a way that has never been done before. Because the actors performances are recorded in a stark white room surrounded by 32 cameras (where they cannot move around), facial expressions and body gestures are captured from every angle
column11:
meaning even the smallest microexpression (while somewhat obvious) are amazingly realistic and help you decide how to move forward in your investigation. The motion scan technology is so detailed, you can make even make out the wrinkles and veins on hands!



This technology comes into play when interrogating suspects.
column12:
As you ask question your suspect/witness, you can decide ""truth, doubt, or lie"" based on their answer and microexpressions (darting eyes, shifting in seat) and the direction of your case is based on your decisions.

There's ONE important thing you should know:
column13: THERE ARE NO ""THROWAWAY"" MOVES, NO THROWAWAY ACTIONS. You only get ONE shot to question a suspect and once you're done, YOU'RE DONE. You CANNOT quit and go back to an old save, NOR can you can go back and question that person again in that particular area, so pay attention and choose wisely.&nbsp
column14: ""Intuition points"" can be used to remove incorrect questions, evidence, look for clues&hellip
column15:
and will also tie into the Rockstar Social Club.

Your objectives, questions, and recording of clues come in the form of a notebook that you can consult at any time. At the end of the interrogation, you'll find out how many of the questions you got right and you'll move forward from there. But don't panic&hellip
column16:
although this is like ""Choose Your Own Adventure"", you will ALWAYS get to the end result. Whether you take the long or short way, the case will be solved.

All in-game phones are functional and can be used to call dispatch and some of the props can be interacted with as well, rumor has it you might be able to even jump and ride trolleys! Mini games come in the form of ""unassigned cases"" (robberies, muggings, etc) that are not only interesting but can get you experience points. This includes successful interrogations, discovering landmarks, etc.

Each case takes around 45-90 minutes to complete and a case never has the same experience, which means it has an AWESOME replay value.
column17:
Our rep told us that he played the particular case he showed us REPEATEDLY and when a colleague played the same case, found scandals our guy didn't even know EXISTED. THAT is fantastiballs (my word, you like?)

Fans of Mad Men, 24, and Southland will recognize many of the characters - another HUGE testament to the motion scan technology. I am a hardcore Southland fan and when I saw Michael McGrady and how he moves in the game, I thought, ""Jebus, it looks EXACTLY LIKE HIM""

The cut scenes are some of the best I've come across.
column18: In most games, the cut scenes interrupt the flow of gameplay like ""BLAM BLAM BLAM! cut scene, wait for game to load&hellip
column19:
BLAM BLAM BLAM!"". Yuck, right? In L.A. Noire, not the case. Each vignette/cut scene is inserted seamlessly into the gameplay so the game has the richness of a feature film.

Here's the latest video about L.A. Noire that Rockstar Games released earlier today:



So, how amazing IS this game? My colleague and I said ""Wow"" about 15 times during the 30 minute demo while shaking our heads in disbelief at how beautiful and smooth the game looked.

When you play L.A. Noire, you'll see WHY it not only took FOUR YEARS to make but why it was made an Official Selection at the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival, making it the FIRST EVER video game Official Selection at a film festival. THAT'S HUGE, people.

(You'll also be happy to know that it will be available in surround sound, but don't even ask if it'll be in 3D, because it won't and I for one am STOKED about that.)

L.A. Noire will be available for Xbox 360 and PS3 on May 17th, 2011 with bonus items for those who pre-order.

The Frame Rate: Looks like we're on the case, kid. Crix Approved

column1: 154,"0","Pop Television: Treme","HBO's Landmark Series Returns","Pop Television: Treme","",,"<div>
David Simon's unflinching look at life in a post-Katrina New Orleans returns to HBO and continues to cast a light on the recovery of a city, its people and its culture.

After an auspicious debut season which focused on the immediate aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, ""Treme's"" second season premiere picks up the story six months later as residents of the Crescent City continue to rebuild and renew their broken home.

For the most part, this season's opening episode is limited to catching viewers up with the lives of their favorite characters, which is perfectly fine. Fans of the first season will be able to appreciate the changes that have taken place, while new viewers are treated to a solid primer of those characters. The result is the establishing of a foundation upon which Simon and company will hopefully construct another 10 episodes of great storytelling.

Of course, the two cultural touchstones that New Orleans is best known for, food and music, are once again treated as background characters in the show. This season, David Simon has enlisted chef and author Anthony Bourdain to contribute his unique perspective to the storyline for chef (and New Orleans ex-pat) Janette Desatuel (Kim Dickens).
If last night's episode is any indication, the city's deep roster of musical talent will be very well represented this season.
column2: The second season premiere featured guest appearances and performances from the likes of the legendary Subdudes, rock / trombone hybrid Bonerama, troubadour John Boutte and a wild musical performance from Galactic, featuring The Dirty Dozen Brass Band and rapper Juvenile that has to be seen to be believed. &nbsp

column1: You can find a link to the complete performance on iTunes here.
As they did last year, HBO promises they will be posting complete playlists of the music used in each episode.
You can learn more about ""Treme,' get caught up on Season 1 and see previews and behind-the-scenes content on HBO.com.

155,"0","Pop Games: Mortal Kombat","Pop Games: Mortal Kombat","","",,"

Pop Games: Mortal Kombat
by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)

There's a common memory that we twenty- and thirty-somethings all have, I think: it's summertime in the 1990s. Clad in fashionably-questionable jeans and Ninja Turtles t-shirts, we clustered around a Mortal Kombat arcade machine to watch or be watched. To kill or be killed. The graphic violence of it was so over-the-top that it never occurred to us to be grossed out. We just wanted to rip out a spine or two.

I haven't played a Mortal Kombat game since those days of Mortal Kombat I and II. Other titles in the series have come and gone, but none really seemed to live up to the glory days of the franchise. I didn't think I was missing anything. That has now changed.

Mortal Kombat is back and better than ever.

Much has been said about the quality of the combat (kombat?) in this installment. It feels fluid, deadly fast. There's little to none of the clunkiness (klunkiness?) you might expect while playing a fighting game -- you're dizzingly lethal. Every attack connects with a gratifying ""thunk"" or ""scrnch"" of brutalized flesh and bone. The gameplay is pretty simple, with a series of complex combos you can build into which are actually unique for every character. The new tag team functionality works seamlessly and allows you to swap characters out mid-combat or call them in for support (as in Marvel vs. Capcom), but you also have the ability to swap mid-combo for even more complex sets of attacks.

One new, rather spectacular feature in combat is the tiered power meter. As you fight and use special attacks, you level up this meter into three separate power sections. In the first tier, your special attacks get extra oomph. In the second tier, you're able to execute a combo breaker to interrupt your opponent. And in the third tier, you gain the ability to do what is probably the coolest part of this new Mortal Kombat installment: a super sweet, super powerful X-ray attack. This is pretty much exactly what you might expect. You hit your opponent crazy hard, and the game dramatically shifts in to demonstrate in slow motion an X-ray-vision shot of exactly how you're decimating their poor skeleton and other assorted internal organs.

And let's not forget the Fatalities.... I'll let this video do the describing for me.



Another feature I really like is the ability to spectate on other people's matches while waiting in line to challenge the champion of that fight. Your avatar can even cheer or boo as you look on. It's a hypnotizing pastime that any child of the 90s can relate to. (I, however, haven't had a chance to test out much of the online multiplayer, as in my ever-abundant foolishness I was playing the game on PS3 in the Great PSN Blackout of 2011.)

In any case, if you're a fan of Mortal Kombat, you're going to want to check this one out. If you're not, you might want to check it out anyway. There are few things more satisfying than transforming into a dragon and biting a dude in half, or ripping a guy's leg off and beating him to death with it. That's what I always say, anyway.

- Kate

Clad in fashionably-questionable jeans and Ninja Turtles t-shirts, we clustered around a Mortal Kombat arcade machine to watch or be watched. To kill or be killed. The graphic violence of it was so over-the-top that it never occurred to us to be grossed out. We just wanted to rip out a spine or two.

I haven't played a Mortal Kombat game since those days of Mortal Kombat I and II. Other titles in the series have come and gone, but none really seemed to live up to the glory days of the franchise. I didn't think I was missing anything. That has now changed.

Mortal Kombat is back and better than ever.

Much has been said about the quality of the combat (kombat?) in this installment. It feels fluid, deadly fast. There's little to none of the clunkiness (klunkiness?) you might expect while playing a fighting game -- you're dizzingly lethal. Every attack connects with a gratifying ""thunk"" or ""scrnch"" of brutalized flesh and bone. The gameplay is pretty simple, with a series of complex combos you can build into which are actually unique for every character. The new tag team functionality works seamlessly and allows you to swap characters out mid-combat or call them in for support (as in Marvel vs. Capcom), but you also have the ability to swap mid-combo for even more complex sets of attacks.

One new, rather spectacular feature in combat is the tiered power meter. As you fight and use special attacks, you level up this meter into three separate power sections. In the first tier, your special attacks get extra oomph. In the second tier, you're able to execute a combo breaker to interrupt your opponent. And in the third tier, you gain the ability to do what is probably the coolest part of this new Mortal Kombat installment: a super sweet, super powerful X-ray attack. This is pretty much exactly what you might expect. You hit your opponent crazy hard, and the game dramatically shifts in to demonstrate in slow motion an X-ray-vision shot of exactly how you're decimating their poor skeleton and other assorted internal organs.

And let's not forget the Fatalities.... I'll let this video do the describing for me.



Another feature I really like is the ability to spectate on other people's matches while waiting in line to challenge the champion of that fight. Your avatar can even cheer or boo as you look on. It's a hypnotizing pastime that any child of the 90s can relate to. (I, however, haven't had a chance to test out much of the online multiplayer, as in my ever-abundant foolishness I was playing the game on PS3 in the Great PSN Blackout of 2011.)

In any case, if you're a fan of Mortal Kombat, you're going to want to check this one out. If you're not, you might want to check it out anyway. There are few things more satisfying than transforming into a dragon and biting a dude in half, or ripping a guy's leg off and beating him to death with it. That's what I always say, anyway.

- Kate

","

Pop Games: Mortal Kombat
by Kate Welch (She Geek Show)
